text:
We live in Mexico and this is AS CLOSE TO AUTHENTIC as possible.  I love "cheater" recipes like this.  Open a few cans, dump it in, and wa-la!  In Mexico we buy the right variety of peppers, cook them down, throw them in the blender, etc to make meals like this.  This saves all that hassle for a genuine taste.  My entire family says it's as good as the tortilla soups served here in local restaurants.  That's the highest compliment a recipe can be given!  Don't bother cooking the chicken ahead of time.  Throw it in with the rest in the beginning and shred it 2-3 hours later.   Hint:  serve with lime juice, a tsp of sour cream, chopped avocados, or pork rind along with the cheese to really eat it like a Mexican.  BTW, I bought bagged tortilla chips and worked fine.

text:
This recipe would be a little more authentic if you skip the canned enchilada sauce and instead made your own. VERY EASY. Take 3-4 large dried ancho chiles (cut off the stems and remove the seeds) and boil them with a cup or so of water, garlic and onion. After a half hour, whir it all together in your blender with a small can of tomato puree. Add some cumin if you like. Salt to taste. I live in Mexico, and believe me, there is NO such thing as canned enchilada sauce here. Also - the shredded or sliced chicken is usually added as a garnish here, not cooked in the soup.

text:
This was FABULOUS!!!  I used 1 qt. of chicken stock in lieu of broth and water, tossed in 3 raw chicken breasts (shredding 3 1/2 hours after cooking on high in the slow-cooker), doubled the garlic, used frozen roasted corn (Trader Joe's) and added 2 cups cooked brown rice (added the same time as the shredded chicken).  I topped each bowl served with shredded chedder, sliced green onions, a couple of cilantro leaves, the tortilla strips (be sure to make your own!) and chunks of ripe avocado.  I also added a couple of shakes of Tapatio (hot sauce) to my own bowl as I wanted more kick than my husband - who had thirds.  I can't wait to share this recipe!

text:
Wonderful!  Definitely cook the chicken in the soup as suggested by previous reviewers.  This soup will only be hot and spicy if you use hot ingredients - I used mild enchilada sauce, etc. and my kids asked me to make it spicier next time - go figure! I also omitted the salt and used low salt products.  Used a 2nd can of chicken broth in place of the water.  Store bought tortilla chips are the way to go - try melting some sharp cheddar on the chips before adding to the soup along with a sprinkle of fresh cilantro and a dollup of sour cream - yum!

Amazing soup!!  I took advise of other reviewers and added black beans - definitely a good idea.  Also tossed in chicken still frozen and shredded about an hour before serving - worked like a charm.  Just finished the leftovers yesterday and I can't wait to make again!! Tortilla strips are easier with cooking spray instead of oil and I like to add salt, garlic powder and a little cumin to them before baking.

text:
This recipe, unfortunately, is only worth two stars--barely.  Too watery, too spicy, and tasted just like liquid enchiladas. And except for using broth instead of water, which really should have helped this, and black beans rather than corn, I prepared this as the recipe directed.  I had to try and save it! To start with, I removed the majority of the liquid from the slow cooker and replaced it with chicken broth--better, but there still was no substance to the soup.  So I cooked a cup of rice and added it to the soup at the end and...now we're talking!  MUCH better--now it's FIVE stars.  I topped each serving with sour cream, which really mellowed it out and added a rich creaminess, shredded cheddar cheese, and the tortilla crisps (which, by the way, didn't EVEN need 10-15 minutes so watch them carefully!)  Now I had a soup that was not only palatable, but it was just delicious.  But the effort I had to put into it to make it so was too much trouble, a waste of some ingredients, and just simply not worth it.  The soup I ended up with was downright delicious--but it was not THIS recipe.

text:
Started this Friday morning for our church small group meeting Friday night. The house smelled great! I added a can of black beans (drained and rinsed) and 2 more cups of chicken broth to make it soupier. I put "sides" in bowls  for guests to make their own versions (shredded cheese, fresh avocado, and sour cream). Used plain tortilla chips that guests could sprinkle over their own bowls, and made  a pot of brown rice. Add a scoop of rice to your bowl, then put soup on top, then add your choice of sour cream, avocado, and/or cheese, and mix together. Yummy and great for a cold night!

text:
Truthfully, I don't know why you would need a slow cooker if all of the ingredients are pre-cooked...  And, it's probably true that the recipe is better than what you normally get in a restaurant, since most restaurant soups are from commercial package mixes (freeze dried ingredients)...  Truthfully, if you wish to make a good recipe, you really should make the broth yourself and NEVER use canned chilies and canned broth, unless your idea of a wonderful soup is a heated brine solution...

Ross

text:
After reading a review from a reviewer in Mexico I followed his/her lead on preparing this soup. THIS IS THE BEST TORTILLA SOUP THERE IS. I used 3 good sized FROZEN boneless chicken breasts. I mixed ALL remaining ingredients (except the cilantro & lime juice) in a large mixing bowl ... poured it over the chicken breasts, turned on the slow cooker to low, left, and played golf .. came home .. shredded the chicken, let it go another 2 hours, added the lime juice and cilantro ... opened a cold beer ... crumbled some tortilla chips (from a bag) ... and had a GREAT meal. Next time I'll garnish with avocado chunks. MAKE THIS SOUP ------ TONIGHT!!!!!!!

text:
Yum!  I have to admit that I tweaked this a bit to suit my family's tastes, but what a wonderful starting point! I seldom even look at recipes that are rated less than 4 (there are just so many great recipes from all you wonderful cooks - and never enough time to make them all!).  And I always read the reviews first, before I start cooking (it pays to do so).  My changes: diced mexican-style tomatoes; one jalapeno, chopped (we like it spicy); a can of black beans; one package of frozen corn, black beans, and peppers; about 1 1/2 tsps mexican oregano; and 1 tsp. each of chili powder, taco seasoning (from this site), and cumin.  I just laid the frozen chicken breasts in the rest of the mixture and took them out after about 5 hours on low to let them cool so I could shred them.  I took the advice of another reviewer and used my immersion blender to puree the soup just a bit (while the chicken was cooling), and at the very end, I added about a T. of lime juice.  I served this with the Homesteader Cornbread from this site, and a green salad of romaine, tomatoes, cucumbers, and avocado with the Spicy Cilantro Dressing, also from this site.  Thanks for a great dinner everyone!

text:
Such an easy and wonderful recipe! I did make a few adjustments. I used chicken broth instead of water. I also used spicy rotel instead of the mashed whole tomatos. I also doubled the garlic, cilantro, and added a few dashes of cayennne pepper. I used some minced fresh jalapeno and the juice from one lime. The lime juice makes a huge difference...trust me. I took the advice of another reviewer and added a can of drained black beans,and I am really glad I did. I put three whole chicken breasts in and shredded it about an hour before it was finished cooking. I also have to say the tortilla strips are 100% worth making....brush with a little garlic olive oil for an awesome flavor. I served with a topping of shredded cheese, sour cream, and diced advocado. Thank you so much for this recipe! So easy and so tasty! This is going to be a favorite soup in our house from now on!

text:
First there was silence as the spoons were lifted.....and then one by one my family (including me) uttered "Oh my gosh" and "This is incredible!" and then silence again as we savoured the next spoonful, followed by more compliments! I gave it 5 stars because it's an excellent recipe, and I'd give it 10 stars with the minor changes I made. First of all, I threw 5 medium-sized raw boneless skinless chicken breasts right into the crockpot. And then added the recipe's ingredients, including these changes: I subbed 1 can of diced tomatoes for the whole ones,  1/2 tsp garlic powder for the garlic cloves, and subbed a can of chicken broth for the water (for a total of 2 cans chicken broth), and decreased the salt to 1/2 tsp. I set the slow-cooker on High,  shredding the chicken after 3 hours, then added 1 can of black beans and 1 chopped red pepper, and then set it on Low for another 2 hours to really let the flavours meld. We added shredded cheddar and sour cream as toppings, along with the home-made tortilla strips  (baked for just 8 minutes. Watch carefully so they don't burn!) and cilantro. We found the spiciness to be just right.  But if you want it "hotter", I'd suggest using "medium" or "hot" enchilada sauce. Thanks, Elena, for an awesome, awesome recipe!

I didn't know one could copy a recipe from a cookbook onto this website or I would have done it years ago.  This recipe is straight out (verbatim) of my crock-pot cookbook and I've been making it for years.  My husband likes it so much that I usually double the recipe so that we can freeze some and eat off it forever.  I get requests for this soup often; it always gets eaten right up and gets rave reviews every time.  My favorite ingredient is actually the enchilada sauce, as it makes the soup just spicy enough for everyone's taste.

This recipe was super-easy and absolutely delicious!! I took the advice of other reviewers and threw in raw chicken breasts at the beginning into the slow cooker instead of cooking them in a skillet first. I let all of the ingredients cook throughout the day on low while I was at work and when I got home the chicken was done and ready to shred (so easy to do). I topped off the soup with sour cream, fresh diced avocados and tortilla strips. YUM!!

text:
My husbands family is all from Mexico and he grew up watching his Aunt's and Grandma make authentic Mexican food and had the pleasure of eating it.  He said that this was by far the best most authentic Chicken Tortilla Soup he has ever had!  I trippled the recipe (You need a very large crockpot or two to tripple it, doubling recipe you only need one large crockpot) so I could freeze the rest for dinner's throughout the month.   I used tortilla chips and crushed them to add on top of each serving.  To make it more authentic add shredded mexican style cheese, avocado and sour cream in each serving.  It looks beautiful and taste even better.  I also used chicken thighs, "put them in frozen" and at the end pealed off the fat.  Use two forks to shred the chicken off bone... it falls off the bone.  Put them back in the soup and its ready to serve. I did it the fast way (4 hours on high). NO NEED TO COOK CHICKEN BEFORE HAND, NO NEED TO MAKE YOUR OWN TORTILLA CHIPS.  It took me 10 minutes to prepare! Perfect for making for get togethers...

text:
I fell in love with this recipe after my first bite.  It's hard for me to find ingredients where I live so I was forced to make my own enchilada sauce (I used the 10 minute enchilada sauce from this website) as well as chicken broth from scratch.  This may have made the recipe superior to canned products but I cannot be certain.  I do know that it's wonderful!  I made mine a little hotter than called for but the recipe strongly held it's flavor without being overpowered by spice alone.  A little sour cream in the soup is a nice touch.  Also, if you feel daring, separate out some broth, tomato chunks, corn (everything but the chicken) and blend in a blender or with a hand wand.  The thicker texture is an improvement.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
With a couple of slight changes this recipe is exceptional! First change was instead of putting the chicken in the crock pot cooked, I put it in raw. After 3 1/2 hours on high it if fully cooked and practically fell apart by itself. Second, I drained the juice from the tomato can before adding them (A true chicken tortilla soup is not supposed to have heavy tomato flavoring). Thirdly, I added a little less than the full can of chopped green chile peppers (Just to make sure it wasn't too spicy). The last changes I made was that I served the soup with a side of fresh sliced avodaco, and shredded cheese along with the tortilla strips,  all for optional additions. This recipe reminds me of San Antonio, TX so much!!! I've made this recipe twice and it is an absolute favorite amongst my partner and I.

This is a keeper, but there is no need to use cooked chicken.  I used frozen breasts, cooked it for 9 hours, shredded the chicken and added it back in.  No need to top with tortillas, either -- just use corn chips.  This is a really great soup that is much easier than the ingredient list looks!

text:
This soup was delicious! Since I had 3 quite large bone-in chicken breasts, I decided to double the other ingredients; seasonings as well. Used no water; all chicken broth. Didn't have any frozen corn on hand, so I just added a can of Summer Crisp, along with a can each of pinto and black beans. I cooked up 2 cups of rice on the side, which we added to the bowls in desired amounts along with crushed tortilla chips, grated Mexican blend cheese, sliced avocado, a sprinkle of lime juice and for my hubby, a dollop of sour cream with more freshly minced cilantro. Cooked on low 6 hours; shredded chicken and returned to soup for about 2 hours longer. This is great soup, Elena... thank you so much for the recipe. I have quite a bit in the freezer (without the chips and extras, of course... can't wait to try this on my kids this coming week!)

text:
O M G this was the BEST tortilla soup ive ever had & my hubby declared this the best soup overall hes ever had! this was so easy to make. & it cost less than $ 5 to make.
i followed the recipe to a T except...
i added 1 lb of raw boneless chix thighs &
2 raw corn on the cobs, cut in half.
after 3 hrs, the chix was shredded & dumped back in.
honestly, all i had to do was buy the meat, unwrap it when i got home & plop it in the crockpot.
it would taken more time & energy to open a can of chicken &/or boil chicken & cut it.
i served this w/ avocado, monterey jack cheese, lime , cilantro & freshly fried tortilla strips. 
man, those strips were the cherry on top.
i will forever make this . & i think i found ONE reason to look forward to the fall/winter months...

country:

text:
One word...WOW!  I decided to make this for my family on ou rainy-Christmas day, 2008!  This was a fantabulous recipe for a crock pot!  I did some altering, of course!  I started with 6 boneless skinless chicken breasts, thrown in the pot first.  Followed by the large container of chicken stock.  Spice it up with about 3/4 of a large can of red enchilada sauce, cumin, chili-powder, poultry seasoning, bay leaves (2) salt, pepper and of course fresh garlic (3 cloves) and one whole onion.  I added 2 cans of sweet corn, dranied.  Then add one large can of cubed, mexican style tomatoes.  After cooking on high for 6-8 hours, assemble in a nice pasta  bowl.  First I slice white corn tortillas into 1 1/2 inch strips and fry in oil till light and crispy then lightly salt.  Put a small handful in thre bottom of a owl and top with shredded cheese.  Then ladle some soup into the bowl, making sure to include PLENTY of liquid.  Pull some cilantro leaves off the stem and add to top of bowl along with sliced avocado.  Then squeeze a lime wedge over top of avocado and leavethe wedge in bowl.  Top with a dallop of sour cream a few more tortilla strips and a sprinkle of cheese.  My 12 year old son, 8 year old daughter and I ate the entire pot throughout the day..and they BEGGED me to make more instantly!!!!  This is definitely the best recipe I have ever used for this dish, BY FAR, and  the easiest!!!  YUMMY, YUMMY, YUMMY - The family is impressed therefore....I THANK YOU!!!!  To all who are re

I've made this twice now. It's really easy and delicious. I use chicken thighs and throw them in raw. I also included a can of rinsed black beans. My kids complained it was too spicy last time so I used a can of diced tomatoes with onions and green chiles, instead of a whole can of green chiles. I also omitted the enchilada sauce and put in a can of tomato paste and a packet of taco seasoning. Cooked on low for 8 hours. Served it with rice to make it more like a stew. Yummy!

userID:
2076750
Display Name:
michael's brenda
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wish I could give this recipe way more than 5 stars. This soup is literally incredible. I have never tasted any soup as delicious as this one. I could seriously put it in a cup and drink it. The broth is so flavorful it could be eaten by itself. Here's how I make it my own: I do cook the chicken beforehand. I use 1 1/2 pounds (a pound is not enough) of boneless, skinless chicken tenderloins or breasts. I season them with mrs. dash, oregano, garlic powder, and onion salt and bake them in the oven with a little bit of water at 375 for 25 minutes. I use all mild ingredients just because I don't like things too spicy. Instead of taking the time to chop up the onions and peppers I throw in a jar of tostito's chunky salsa. It adds a lot of flavor and also makes more soup in the end. I add 2 packets of chicken bouillon to the water and then an extra packet to the actual soup just because. I also put in more corn and add some oregano. I just use a bag of tortilla chips for convenience and always add lots of cheddar cheese. If you want it to serve more you could add a packet of mahatma saffron yellow rice. This soup is so good that even if you're stuffed you have to get more. My fiancé absolutely loves it. He drank the broth like milk at the bottom of a cereal bowl. Next time I'm making two crockpots of it. It's goes great with "Annie's Fruit Salsa and Cinnamon Chips" from this website for dessert!

text:
This is a family favorite!!!  Here are some changes that I make:  For large crock pot, substitute 28 oz. can of crushed tomatoes and 14 oz. can of diced tomatoes w/zesty chiles, rather than 2 cups water.  Add a can of "Black beans with cumin and chili spices"; Double chili powder and add chipolte chili powder.  Cook for 6 hours on low then shred chicken. Cook 2 hours additionally. Top with cheese, sour cream, jalapenos and crushed tortilla chips. Excellent!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so fabulous!  I took the advice of a lot of other reviewers and made some substitutions:

1. Can of diced tomato with spicy red pepper rather than can of whole peeled tomatoes.

2. Jar of Hot Taco Sauce rather than enchilada (couldn't find it).

3. No water, just extra chicken broth.

4. Added a can of black beans and half a package of taco seasoning.

5. Used raw chicken thighs and they cooked with the soup and I shredded them before we ate it. 

6. Crushed our own store-bought taco's over top instead of making them.

This soup was SOOO good!  My husband kept going back for more and ate 3 bowls.  He said it was one of the best soups he had EVER tasted.  I will DEFINITELY make it again.

Tip:  If you make some of the substitutions I did, leave out the salt.  I added it, but it was a little too salty.

Two words here: terrific and quick. Made last night in a crock pot - only took about 10 minutes to put it together and let it go on high for about 5 hours. Used a turkey cutlet (a lot cheaper than boneless,skinless chicken breast)and put it in the pot in big chunks and raw. While it cooked the meat took on the flavor of the broth. Used no water - all chick broth. Had some with crushed tortilla chips as the only topping - really good. Later had some with a bit of sour cream, some avocado slices, and crushed tortilla chips for the topping - even better. Try it - you'll like it!

I doubled the recipe, but omitted the water (it brings nothing to the flavor party). An extra chicken breast added them raw let it go on high for about 4hrs then with a wooden spoon mushed/shredded the chicken. Added one can of black beans and frozen corn at the end. Served with sides for everyone to choose from of cooked rice, refrained beans (just put it in the bottom of the bowl and scoop the soup on top, cheese, hot sauce, diced onions, diced avacados, tomatoes, sour cream, tortilla chips and burrito shells to dip like bread. It is amazing! Froze some in ziplock bags to eats later. Open a ziplock bag put it in a cup fold edges over the lip of the cup. After a couple of scoops squeeze out as much air as possible zip it and let it cool on your counter then freeze.

This was AMAZING...with the mods I made of coarse! I didn't really change much...I used green enchilada sauce and a pinch of sugar in with the 26 oz can of whole peeled tomatoes, used fire roasted green chilis in a can. Added a can of rinsed black beans. Didn't add cilantro to the soup, but instead as a garnish. Also, I used 3 baked chicken thighs, I would have added boneless skinless chicken to the crockpot, but I didn't have any and I didn't want to add the skin and all to the pot and worry about fetching it later so this time I baked em and removed the fat, skin and bones. I also used 2 pkgs of chicken bullion in the pot with the water. I let this cook on high for 4 hours since I added cooked chicken. I would go longer next time with raw chicken. The way to serve this is over some rice to make it more hearty and filling, squeeze some fresh lime juice over the bowl and top with a spoon of sour cream, green onion, cilantro, cheese and tortilla strips...I used bagged tortillas. OMG SOOOOO AWESOME!!!!! Thanks!   I personally think that you should read over reviews and take into count the changes ppl made, it helps make it better, so I never make things as written I always make changes to our liking. Enjoy cooking, I certainly do!!

text:
This is a GREAT recipe.  Great because its so easy to prepare, and because it tastes fantastic.  With that said, after making this recipe a couple times, I tuned a bit to my tastes.  It is a tad watery, isn't spicy enough for me, and could be tad bolder IMO.  So, here's the changes I made.

I use 3 chicken breasts, or about 1 1/2 lbs worth.  Also, I add three fresh diced jalapenos to give it a little kick.  Double the enchilada sauce(my local grocery only carries mild) and use two cans of diced green chiles instead of one.  Instead of adding the two cups of water, I just dump in a second can of chicken broth.  Lastly, I throw in a packet of taco seasoning.  Now we're talking!

I made the recipe, as written, leaving it to slow-cook for for nearly 8 hours. It was OK, but seemed a bit sweet than I like. text:
AMAZING!!  We thought this was better than any restaurant tortilla soup we have ever tasted!  I basically followed the recipe, but I used 1lb frozen boneless chicken breasts and put them in the crock pot frozen.  I cooked it all for about 6 hours, then took the chicken out, shredded it, and put it back in for another 2 hours.  I also used 2 cans chicken broth and omitted the water.  I cooked 6 servings of brown rice seperately and then added it to the pot for about a half hour at the end.  It made the soup more hearty and perfect for a full meal.  Also, fresh lime juice added to each bowl along with a few strips of tortilla strips (I used Mission tortilla strips instead of making my own), and a dollop of sour cream and a pinch of mexican shredded cheese!  Perfect!!

Great flavor soup! I made some modifications as suggested by others - made my own enchilada sauce, used only chicken broth, added frozen chicken breast directly to the crockpot,  added one can of pinto beans (rinsed), doubled the cumi, garlic and chili powder and did not add the cilantro but used it to top the soup. Thank you for the recipe Elena! - it has been added to my favorites!

text:
This recipe is awesome. Before I decide to try a recipe out I always make sure that it has at least 4 stars and then check to see how many reviews there are. At the present time this one has 2,327 reviews and I now know why. I first made this about a month ago and again tonight. I put the slow cooker on low (6 to 61/2 hours). As others mentioned, I also added a can of black beans. Other then that I follow the recipe just as it’s written. Oh, I also use store bought tortilla chips instead of making them.  The smell through the house is sooooo good. This is a keeper and will be a regular on my list of recipes to serve for dinner. 08/07/11 update. When making this soup I now make my own tortilla strips and instead of putting them in the oven I put them in the microwave for one minute twenty three seconds. I also make these as a snack except I will add a little salt and grated parmesan cheese. Took me two trys to get it perfected but it was so worth it.

city:

country:

text:
First I thought this was a bit bland but after cooking all day and sitting in the fridge over night it was MUCH better! I used less water and added more cumin and chile powder, and also black beans, but did not have a bay leaf. This soup definately gets better each day it sits, as a lot of tomato things do. My intention was to re-create a tortilla soup I had in Mexico and I totally failed...not because it was not tasty it just wasn't the same. When I had my first bowl I was really dissapointed but I think it's b/c I was looking for a specific flavor and did not accomplish it, rather than it not being a good soup. I chose this recipe from reviews that claimed it tasted the most authentic, but unfortunately I do not think this was anywhere close to the taste I got in Mexico. Don't get me wrong this soup does taste great, just not what I was looking for. In Mexico they had avocados and chunks of queso fresco, so of course I had to buy these items. They was great but maybe next time I will skip the expensive cheese (or make my own) and stick to whatever cheese I always have in the fridge. Also do not skimp on making your own tortilla strips, this was one of the best parts and it's probably cheaper too than buying chips. I sprayed mine on both sides and stacked 4 at a time and cut thin with a pizza cutter and baked. Also added fresh cilantro on top (a must!) with a touch of sour cream.

I have made this many times and shared it. This soup is awesome and easy to make. Everyone loves it.   For all of you haters that whine about the ingredient list calling for canned broth and chilies...the important word is EASY. Some of us have full time jobs and like to be able to throw stuff together quickly. I'm sorry, I love cooking and eating, but I am not wasting my weekend slaving over the stove to make my own enchilada sauce and chicken broth.   While I am sure this recipe would be even better with fresh beans, broth, chilies and all that...it is fine the way it is! Rock on poster and much love to this easy to make and easy to modify recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this recipe about 6 months ago and I love it. I made only a few changes since I like to stay true to the original recipe and have made it the same way every time. I pressure cook a whole chicken for about 45 minutes.  I use the chicken broth from the cooked chicken.  I think pressure cooking a whole chicken gives you a tastier broth. While the chicken cooks I measure out all the other ingredients and chop the onion. I use 1 (15 0unce)can crushed tomatoes and I leave out the green chile peppers. I add the rinsed black beans as another cook recommended. I measure out about 4 cups of chicken broth to equal the water and broth amounts found in the recipe and place in a large pot. While these ingredients are simmering I debone and shread the cooked chicken and add one pound of the chicken to the soup. I let it simmer a little while longer and it is ready. I like the way the added black beans add color to the soup.

text:
My husband loves this soup at our favorite Mexican restaurant and looks for it at others.  I made this for him as a treat and he loved it.  In fact, he said it was better than at his favorite restaurant (but, he is a charmer!)and less spicy, which is more appealing to him.  I didn't have shredded chicken ready, so I put partially defrosted chicken breasts in the pot and shredded it towards the end.  Adding fresh cilantro, however, in the beginning is a waste as you lose the fresh, piquant flavor.  I recommend adding that towards the end.  Otherwise, I wouldn't change a thing!

FABULOUS! I loved this soup and it could not be easier. I threw everything in the crock pot in about 10 mins. and let it cook all day. I put the chicken breasts in whole, shredded them up about 30 mins. before it was done, and then dumped them back in the soup. I also added some frozen corn and a can of kidney beans. I wanted to use black beans, but didn't have any on hand. My husband is not a big soup fan, but he raved about this soup. It's thick and hearty enough to be considered a good meal. I will be cooking this one a lot this winter.

This was very hot and spicy, way too spicy for us.  However, if you like that, this is a great recipe for you!  I even omitted the can of green chile peppers and just used a can of diced tomatoes with green chilies, instead of a can of whole peeled tomatoes. First, I will say this is easy. I always take the 5 minutes to season the meat prior to cooking. In this case I season cut up ( bite size)boneless skinless chicken thighs with 1/2t.to 1t. each. Cumin, Garlic Powder, Oregano and chili powder. I took 15 more minutes to brown the meat in some oil. Onions and fresh peppers, and garlic can be browned in the last few minutes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe as a "base" to clean out some pantry items.  Great results for my first try at tortilla soup!  It made me think of Boston Market's tortilla soup, which I haven't had in years.  I used can corn instead of frozen.  I did not have canned tomatoes on hand, but subbed in three fresh, peeled tomatoes.  I "made" enchilada sauce out of a can of mild Rotel tomatoes, red pepper flakes, cumin, chili powder, garlic powder, and canola oil, which I blended down in a 2 cup measuring cup using an immersion blender.  I added the suggested can of black beans mentioned by other reviewers (another pantry item utilized!).  Also, I did not want to use 1/2 of a 32 ounce container of broth, so I used the whole container to boil my chicken breasts, pouring all of the liquid into the slow cooker and omitting the 2 cups water.  We served it with tortilla chips from Costco that we had on hand.  And, I didn't have a bay leaf or cilantro, but it still came out great.  It really helped me knock out a few extras I had laying around with tremendous results.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i think that this is a good slow cooker recipe but i did alter it a bit, taking some cues from a few reviews.  i wanted more heat so i diced both a jalapeno and serrano pepper.  I also used 2 cups chix broth and 1 cup water and added the juice from a whole lime.  after cooking for 5.5 hours on high i thought there was too much broth so i added a can of pinto beans with jalapeno peppers and cooked for another 1.5 hours.  

i get that there are no beans in tortilla soup and i also get that making a traditional soup in this quick-style manner is not authentic.  BUT this is a slow cooker recipe, geared for simple, delicious quick meals.  the beans seemed to be the key to bulking this recipe up a bit and it was delicious!

we baked a few white corn tortillas brushed lightly with olive oil and salt, serving two on the side. topped with a bit of plain yogurt, this will now be a go to meal in the future!  Thanks for this!

text:
This was a great cheater recipe.  But why waste money on chicken breasts? I used the leftover carcass from the Allrecipes "Roast Sticky Chicken-Rotisserie Style" which I had marinated overnight in the spices for that recipe.  I cooked the carcass alone for an hour so that all the meat fell off, and then proceeded with the recipe for the tortilla soup.  Like others, I used a bag of tortilla chips, a can of black beans, and a can of corn. I also added a can of garbanzo beans since I had a lot of soup.  I served with lime wedges, chopped cilantro, avocado and sour cream and everyone had fun dressing their bowls.

text:
I really enjoyed this and will make again soon.  I, too, cooked my chicken in the soup and used all chicken broth instead of water.  I used Hatch brand enchilada sauce and, also, Hatch chiles.  I didn't make my own tortilla strips, but, instead used the wonderful brand at my local market, Harbor Greens.  They are thin and crispy and I used the "chilepeno" flavor - perfect as a topping with my soup.  When I made this I didn't have corn on hand, but next time plan to add roasted corn.  Also, I'm going to try another reviewer's suggestion of cooking black beans in the soup instead of using canned.  Because I like my food spicy, I did increase, probably doubled, the cumin and chili powder and then added ground cayenne as well. :)  The only problem I had was that it was so good I didn't have enough left for the freezer.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mmmm.... yummm!  I made a little different based on what I had on hand.  I used 1 can tomatoe sauce and 2 diced fresh tomatoes in place of the whole canned tomatoes.  I also seeded and diced 2 fresh jalapenoes instead of canned chillies.  Skipped the chicken broth (to eliminate sodium) and just used 2 extra cups water.  I increased cumin to 1 tbs, added 1 cup dry black beans and 1 cup frozen corn.  Per 1 reviewer I added 2 sliced corn tortillas at the beginning to add some tortilla taste and to thicken.  I put the chicken in raw and shredded after 3 1/2 hrs, then let it cook for another 3 1/2 hours till the beans were done.  The enchillada sauce blended well and gave a great flavor.  Some reviewers said theirs turned out thin and watery, but mine was thick and hearty.  I think the tortillas helped and adding dry beans probably soaked up some extra juice.  I squeezed the juice of 1 lime into the pot before serving and garnished each bowl with fresh avocado and a bit of sour cream.  Definately make your own tortilla strips.  This was oh so good.  I can't wait to have leftovers for lunch.

userID:

Display Name:
Mtnlaurl

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I've made this about 5 times now and my family has begun to request it so figure I have enough experience with this soup to honestly review it.

One of the tastiest and easiest soups to make. No, you don't need a slow cooker but it does help to meld the flavors when you use one. Yes, you can begin with raw boneless, skinless breasts or use leftover chicken. Sometimes I begin with raw breasts in the slow cooker and then throw in leftover baked chicken towards the end. Depends on what I have on hand. The recipe is very flexible and forgiving.

It's the enchilada sauce that makes this recipe so don't forget it or it won't taste the same. I use diced tomatoes that include the green chili's and don't add additional chili's as we aren't into really spicy stuff. I include the cilantro but reserve the most cilantro to put fresh on top each bowl. I also add chopped avocado to my personal bowl. My son likes grated cheese on his. Sometime I include a spoon of sour cream in mine. The basic soup is fantastic and each bowl can be personalized with additions. OH, the LIME, must have a squirt of LIME in each bowl as that really brightens the flavor. 

As for the tortilla, just use your favorite tortilla chip. Much easier and tastes great. 

I made a double recipe of this last night. It's gone today as my gang not only ate it for dinner - they finished it for lunch.

text:
Wow.  Just wow.  This is such an amazing recipe.  The only things I did differently were:
- used boneless, skinless, chicken thighs cooked in the soup (I HIGHLY recommend this.  The dark  meat really works well in this soup.)
- Used cayenne pepper as opposed to chili powder
- omitted the 2 cups of water (not enough space in my slow cooker and I am glad there wasn't.)
- used a bit more garlic (I love the stuff).

The soup is so simple, yet rich in flavor.  This recipe is going to be a new cold weather staple in my house.

Yumm-o!  I made it as written and it was very good.  I will change it only slightly next time I make it.  First, I used mild enchilada sauce and mild green chilis just to see how it would turn out.  I will slowly ramp up the heat by picking either hot sauce or hot chilis next time.  Also, I love black beans in my tortilla soup so I will add some next time.  I may cut back a bit on the corn, maybe use half a bag.  It was pretty corn-y.  Also, I plan to use diced or pureed tomatoes next time rather than waste time crushing the whole ones.  I made my life easy by using a store bought rotisserie chicken picked over for the meat.  I topped with sour cream and used bagged tortilla chips instead of homemade, and it was delicious.

text:
This was fabulous! The flavors! I used 1 can of beans instead of corn, hot enchilada sauce, cooked 2 Tysons garlic/wine chicken breasts with soup and added one hot turkey sausage link (crumbled after cooked in soup), added an additional can of tomatoes with chiles, added a few jarred jalepeno slices, halved the salt as my additions included salted items, and used one chicken bouillon in place of broth and 2.5 cups of water. These changes were personal preferences (we like a kick!) and after reading some reviews - I would have not known where to begin without this great recipe!

text:
Excellent soup! I've made this a couple of times and it always turns out great. I don't pre-cook the chicken, I used boneless/skinnless breasts (2-3 depending on size) then I remove them & shred the meat right before serving. I have also added a can of black beans, rinsed & drained and that was good too. Don't use pre-packaged chips for the garnish! The tortillas are worth a bit of work--just make a few extras. My son & his friends at a lot of them while waiting for the soup to finish.  I sprayed the strips lightly with cooking spray then sprinkled them w/cumin & chili powder before baking. Perfect!

city:

None
text:
Have made this recipe a couple times. The first time exactly as written. I felt it was missing something. The second time I made these changes. I used fire-roasted diced tomatoes (great taste), used spicy enchilada sauce and left out the green chilis. I added chicken stock for the water and doubled the cumin. I added chicken breast to the top of the mixture and cooked on high. The last hour, I removed the chicken breasts and shredded them with forks and returned to the cooker. I also added 1/2 of a lime squeezed and 2 TBLS of MASA (corn flour) mixed w/ 1/2 cup water to thicken and to add the cornny taste it's missing. I serve w/ grated sharp cheese and tortilla chips.

text:
This soup was fantastic! All my husband could say was "This is SO good" over and over. I love how easy it was to prepare and it smelled very good all day. As another reviewer recommended, I put in frozen boneless/skinless chicken breasts and shredded them when they were cooked. Instead of using water and chicken broth, I only used chicken broth. Towards the end of the cooking time I tasted it and it had a little bit of a bitter taste. I know that this is not a "traditional" ingredient in  tortilla soup, but I didn't want the bitterness, so I added about a cup of chopped carrots and that took care of it and it was perfect. I still can't figure out why it had that taste to it, maybe it is supposed to? When I served it, I garnished with lime, fresh cilantro, chopped avocado, shredded cheddar and tortilla chips. I am going to recommend this recipe to everyone!! Thanks for sharing it :)

text:
I made this yesterday.  Didn't have frozen corn so I used fresh and used green enchilada sauce because that's what I had in the house. I also used 2 large frozen boneless chicken breasts. As soon as the chicken was "shreddable" I did and let it soak in the soup until we were ready to eat.  Didn't have tortilla's so I used french bread and topped the soup with sour cream. The soup had a sweet taste from the sweet corn. Not a bad thing but if you don't like a little sweetness, use regular frozen or canned corn.  Tried this recipe again with regular enchilada sauce,3 chicken breasts and added a can of red beans. Both versions were 5 stars but we preferred the green enchilda sauce.

text:
Very good recipe!  I gave it 4 stars cause I tweaked a little, but it is a 5 star recipe.  I used green chilie enchilada sauce instead of the regular enchilada sauce.  I also added black beans, but not the canned kind.  They tend to get mushy and nasty.  So I used the kind from a bag.  I put everthing in the crock pot the night before and added the beans.  As a way to "soak" overnight.  The beans were a good addition.  Came out good.  We topped with fresh cilantro and squeezed lime juice on top with sour cream, cheese and baked tortillas!  Wonderful!  It would have been even better if had fresh avacado.

text:
YUM! That's all I can say. This is a very easy, but very tasty slow cooker soup. You can make it as spicy as you want or as mild as you want. Add toppings or not. We use canned Rotel HOT tomatos in this as well as canned chiles...I omit the water and have always used canned corn...comes out just fine. My hubby likes to put this on top of tortilla chips, top it with sour cream, onions and cheese.  I only use low fat sour cream and a bit of cheese and onion. Very healthy... FIVE BIG STARS ON THIS ONE! :) BTW- It may be cheaper to buy a rotissiere chicken from the grocery store and shred it as opposed to buying a pound of chicken breasts. :)

text:
This got a thumbs up from both my husband and 14yo daughter.  They are both VERY picky eaters.  My husband doesn't care for soup or Mexican food, but he told me at least 3 times how good it was.  I also added a can of black beans and used all chicken broth as several others had suggested.  I added 5 (uncooked) boneless, skinless chicken thighs and about an hour before it was dinner time, took them out and shreaded them.  Then other changes I made are that I added about 1/3 cup of salsa and about 1/3 cup of FINELY crushed tortilla chips half way thru cook time.  Adding the crushed tortilla chips kinda made it thicken up a little bit (learned it on The Food Networks "How to Boil Water" show)  SUPER SUPER GOOD!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
GOOD RECIPE with some advice from other reviews plus some of my own: Frozen Chicken breasts shredded when cooked, 1 bottle beer (no extra water or chicken broth), 2 TBS chicken boulion, canned diced tomatos with mild green chilis, no extra chilis, 1 can black beans drained and rinsed. Tortilla strips were not worth the extra work, the store bought ones would have been easier and taste better. Froze extras and were even better the second time around after the flavors melded. DO NOT FORGET TO ADD THE FRESH LIME JUICE, it makes the dish! 
****UPDATE****
I now make this soup overnight and let it sit in the fridge all day and let the flavors meld and it is the BEST!

Muy bien! :-) My husband had never tried tortilla soup before and went back for seconds! I used a can of corn (juice and all) instead of frozen corn, and I added a can of Mexican Festival Rotel for added spice & flavor. I also used fully cooked, seasoned, shredded chicken (12 oz.) from the grocery store instead of cooking the chicken myself which saved a lot of prep time. Display Name:
Paige Everly

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4048074.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely amazing. I made it with very few adjustments. I used homemade chicken broth instead of canned and used twice the amount and only 1 cup of water. I also used homemade stewed tomatoes (which I chopped). I added some black beans, too (my family loves them). I threw the chicken in the pot whole and left it all day on low, pulled it out and shredded it when I got home, added it back in with some cilantro (I used a lot of cilantro - we really like it - about 1/4 of a cup). Gave it a good stir, got the bowls out and served it with a good squeeze of lime (a MUST! Do not skip. I know for Americans this sounds strange, but you will LOVE it.), and little shredded cheese on top (personal preference), a small dollop of sour cream for some of us. My family adds crunched tortilla chips, but I like it without them. This is really amazing soup and so easy to make.

userID:
5963665
Display Name:
Sandy D. Dubon
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1989613.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is another recipe to add to my binder.  I like how it's a slow cooker recipe however, since I had to doubled the ingredients to accommodate 16 servings, I prepared this on the stove (My large slow cooker wasn't big enough.)  The only thing I changed is that I didn't pre-cook the chicken...it really isn't necessary to do that whether you use the slow cooker or stove.  Just place the raw chicken in when you put everything else and when your ready to eat just shred the chicken and add it back into the pot. I didn't add the corn until I was ready to simmer the soup (added corn, brought the soup back to boil, then simmered for 40 minutes).  I used boneless skinless Chicken thighs.  This soup is a bit zippy but not terribly.  However, if you have zero tolerance to spiciness then you may want to adjust the recipe accordingly.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great soup.  I did make a few changes though.  I used raw chicken breasts which I think is crucial in getting the meat tender.  I wouldn't use pre-cooked.  I shredded the chicken after about 3 1/2 hours and then put the meat back in.  I also used only 1 cup of water, but an extra cup of chicken broth (low sodium).  Next time I'll probably only use the broth and no water.  I didn't have enchilada sauce on hand so I used a can of thick salsa (smooth, not chunky).  I also added some celery and diced red bell pepper.  Additionally, based on other reviews, I added a can of black beans.  When I served the soup I topped it with shredded Mexican blend cheese and avocado and warmed up some corn tortillas to eat with it.  Delicious!  My husband has been sick and said it was just what the doctor ordered :)

text:
During the worst winter the Midwest has had in many years, my thoughts were "Time goes so fast and it will be spring before we know it. But in the mean time make some soup!" I found this recipe and was everyone's hero. I tweaked it just a little....I had boneless chicken breast that I cut in bite-size pieces and seasoned and browned in a skillet. I added the chicken broth to the pan to catch all the browned bits and then poured in the crockpot.I didn't have the canned chilis so used a can of Rotel tomatoes. I added a can of drained rinsed black beans. Didn't have tortillas so used tortilla chips. Served w/ avocado,cilantro and cheese. Yummy!!!!

text:
This recipe looks like trouble with a lot of ingredients but don't let that fool you!  I threw in frozen chicken and I didn't have cilantro so omitted that and used two cans of chicken broth instead of water.  Then added everything else and left it to slow cook all day.  WOW, it was so delicious!  I also don't measure the spices but just add what I think I will like (stuck to the intended ingredients though) so I can't be sure if it was spicer than normal or less spicy but it was just right for me.  I froze half and will enjoy it on the colder days as a treat.(I also just used store bought tortilla chips and they were just fine, I was all about saving time!)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/280361.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a 1-qt. crockpot to slow cook the chicken (for 3 hours) then shredded it before transferring to the 5-qt. crockpot to make the soup. I added 5 oz. of frozen corn because I didn't have canned corn. I also used a 14.5 oz. can of diced tomatoes with chipotle chilies (Hunt's makes many specialty diced tomatoes these days!). I had a 32 oz. carton of chicken stock leftover from the holidays, so I used that instead of the chicken broth and water. I used all of the other ingredients as described in the recipe. I ended up adding another cup of  water just to bring down the spicy heat. I did make the homemade tortilla strips, which are BY FAR better than salty, store bought tortilla chips (like Tostitos). The homemade variety is thicker and heartier and makes for a better dipping tool. I served my soup with shredded coulby-jack cheese, olives and a dollop of greek non-fat yogurt (see my photo). Great basic recipe because it leaves a lot of room for adding/subbing ingredients.

text:
I'm giving this 5 stars because it not only tastes great but it so very easy to make. Just dump everything in the slow cooker and walk away! I'm a Texan living in Scotland where canned enchilada sauce is not available, so I use an enchilada mix packet. I just add that to the other spices and sprinkle it over everything. For the liquid, I combine tomato sauce (called passata in the UK) and the chicken broth. I like a thicker soup so I only put in enough liquid to just cover the ingredients. Great recipe! Thank you!

text:
I followed this recipe almost exactly and everyone LOVED it.  My only changes were that I did not make the tortilla strips (we just ate with tortilla chips) and I did not pre-cook my chicken breasts.  I had placed some in the fridge overnight to thaw, and they were still partially frozen in the morning.  I put them in, anyway.  2 hours on High and then 6 hours on low, and the breasts shredded very easily. The house smelled DELICIOUS! 
My 9 year old son is requesting I make this again on a daily basis.

text:
This recipe is excellent.  I use canned petite diced tomatoes and use black beans instead of corn for more fiber and less carbs.  I also use a bit more cumin, some minced garlic and some garlic salt.  I did as others suggested and just put raw boneless skinless chicken breasts into crock pot with other ingredients.  Removed and shredded about an hour before serving and returned to slow cooker.  Served with shredded sharp cheddar cheese and Golden Flake tortillas (The label says "Mazietos" and they are absolutely the best.  Since there are only 2 of us, 3 chicken breasts make plenty with enough leftovers for at least one more meal.  Yummy.

I made this last night and I am absolutely in love.  I order Chicken Tortilla soup at restaurants and I've always wanted to make my own and finally found this recipe.  Oh my goodness... it was perfection.  I did a couple things differently and they really paid off.  First, I cooked my chicken with a packet of Lawry's Chicken Taco seasoning and 3/4 cup of water in a pan, letting them simmer first.  Instead of 2 cups of water, I added a second can of chicken brother and a half cup of water.  I also added an extra TBL of Chili powder.  To thicken it and add a bit of creaminess, I put in a few spoons of sour cream.  :-)  Perfect!

userID:
6012086
Display Name:
Desi93
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
8
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG this tortilla soup is sooooooooo good! I've made this recipe a few times now. I follow the recipe pretty much exactly. The only changes I made was to the cooked chicken. First I did as other people said throw the chicken breasts in whole, then shred it a few hours into the cooking time which came out great. But this time, I took 2 chicken breasts, coated it with olive oil and seasoned it i mean verrry liberally with chili powder, garlic powder, cumin, salt and pepper and baked in the oven at 400 for 15 minutes. Meanwhile, I get the slow cooker ready with all the ingredients as directed. When the chicken is done, shred it and pour it in with all the extra spices and juices left over. This gives it fabulous flavor! I cooked it on high for 3 1/2 hours. It was so so good. The added flavor and drippings from baking the chicken is just divine and it just took 15 mins extra. Loved it!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Very good. 
It could have better to add chicken broth instead of 2c of water.  
Used frozen boneless skinless chicken thighs. After tearing up the meat, the stock tasted a bit gamey, so added 2 Tb rice wine, doubled crushed garlic, 1/4 ts grounded ginger. 
After tasting 2nd time, wanted more smokey flavour. So added 1/4 ts smoked chipotle chili powder.

text:
My husband and my daughter loved this soup.  I made a modification, which, I wish I didn't make. I added a 1/2 cup of rice as well as an additional cup of chicken stock.  The rice REALLY absorbed the broth.  They loved the thickness of the soup, while I prefer mine "brothy".  Overall, the soup had a good flavor and, as suggested by other posters, I used frozen chicken breast as well as a couple skinless chicken legs.  I like how chicken legs add flavor and the meat fell off the bone, making the bones very easy to remove.

Only gave this 4 b/c based on others advice I made some changes and the soup turned out great.  If hadn't I'm not sure I would have been happy.  I noticed the cx broth to h20 comparison and thought that would be too weak in flavor - so we just used chicken broth.  We used 'hot' enchilada sauce, and it turned out nice and not too spicy, actually not much kick.  We added fresh/raw chicken to the pot - I thought why crockpot cooked chicken for such a long time.  Anyway we like it a lot and will make this again.

userID:
5837350
Display Name:
Laura
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe today; I read through a lot of revews and modified it to suit me.   I used a rotisserie chicken from my local grocery store. I used a jar of medium salsa rather than plain tomatoes, and I added in 1/2 a cup or so of salsa verde to boot. I did NOT use enchilada sauce. I used all chicken broth, no water, for more flavor; 30 mins before the finish time, I stirred in a mixture of 3 tbsp. masa harina (masa flour) whisked into 1/2 cup water to thicken it slightly and give an additional layer of corn flavor. I also added in a can of drained and rinsed black beans. I doubled the amount of cumin and chili powder, and only used half a can of green chiles - it was hot enough with just that much, for my family. I served it with some bacon and cheddar cornbread muffins.   Great base recipe from which to build; thanks for sharing it.   Pic of my dish and recipe here (copy and paste URL, I guess they don't allow live links in reviews) -     http://culinaryspirits.wordpress.com/2010/11/20/crockpot-chicken-tortilla-soup-with-bacon-cheddar-cornbread-muffins/

text:
I made this recipe with modifications based on other reviewers and my friend (who is an excellent cook) thought it was great and spicy enough for people who like spice without being "killer hot" for people who can't take too much heat.  I used 2lbs chicken, (from frozen breast strips) 1 can of "hot" red enchilada sauce, half a 15oz can of green enchilada sauce, 1-15oz can of black beans, 4 cloves of garlic, 27oz container of chicken stock, 1/2 cup of water and one heaping teaspoon each of cumin and chili powder.  Kept everything else the same and it was great!

text:
I made a couple of changes to the original recipe but it turned out fantastic.  I used 3 or 4 frozen chicken breasts to save some time and hassle.  I subbed 2 cups of low sodium chicken stock instead of the water to give it more flavor.  I also added a can of black beans (drained and rinsed to make it more visually appealing). This was absolutely wonderful.  It made a huge batch and there was a lot left over for just the two of us but it was perfect for a super busy week.   Also, I cut up some leftover corn tortillas, sprayed them with cooking spray, sprinkled with salt, and popped them in the toaster oven for a few minutes while I reheated leftovers.  Store bought chips would have been fine but I liked the fact that the strips were warm. Don't forget to garnish with sour cream, cilantro, and a squeeze of lime!

text:
This was a wonderful chicken tortilla soup enjoyed by the whole family.  I stayed pretty true to the recipe.  I didn't weight my cooked chicken, but I'm sure it was somewhat more than a pound and I pulled it into bite-size chunks rather than shredding.  The can of tomatoes I used was a 14.5 oz can of diced tomatoes with jalapenos.   I used a 14.5 oz can of chicken broth with roasted garlic and eliminated the minced garlic due to that.  I used 2 15 oz. cans of whole kernal corn, drained, because I was out of frozen corn.  For the tortillas I used commerial restaurant-style tortilla chips.  Each of us put a scoop of rice in the bottom of our bowls, topped that with the soup, added a fistful of Mexican-style cheese, added diced raw onion and chopped cilantro.  This is the best -- no need to look further for the best chicken tortilla soup.  It was so easy to throw together and let the crockpot do the rest of the work.

text:
My girlfriend has IBS symptoms but is trying to also have a low-carb diet to lose weight (I know, opposing goals) so after enjoying the original I also made this with a few changes and it was wonderful.  In an attempts to add as many vegetables as possible, I chopped green, yellow and red peppers and added them to the mix and you can also PUREE a can or two of the Southern Style seasoned Beans that Glory Foods offers, which adds body and protein without TOO much fat.  I also chopped some zucchini squash and used the method others mentioned of putting frozen chicken in the soup and then taking it out and chopping or shredding it later after it cooks.    I love corn, but it's not part of Phase 1 of the South Beach Diet, so it was out, but the other additions combined to make a delicious and filling soup that thankfully didn't cause my lady's stomach to hurt.

Pretty  good if I must say so myself.  I made my own enchilada sauce using a couple Tbs. of oil, about 1-1/2 Tbs of flour, 2-3 Tbs of chili powder (two different kinds), 1 Tbs cumin.  Stir over heat, add 1 small can of tomato paste, 1 can of chicken broth/stock/boullion (whatever) maybe two (I don't remember), simmer approx. 15 min.    I also used 1 can of black beans, 1 can of corn, 1 can of diced tomato's in olive oil, garlic & oregano. I threw in the about 8 frozen chicken tenders, all chicken broth, no water, more cilantro, 3 cloves pressed garlic, 1 teas. chili powder, 1 teas. cumin, and no salt & pepper.     I topped it w/mozzarella cheese & diced avocado w/little cilantro, and it was to die for!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/311200.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good soup, but slightly lacking in depth of flavor.  I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs since they have more flavor and are more tender than breasts (put into crock-pot raw; no need to pre-cook).  I added all the ingredients listed, cooked on high for 5 hours, pulled chicken thighs out at 4 hours and shredded with a fork (they basically fell apart they were so tender), threw chicken back in, then tasted.  Soup did not have enough punch or flavor for me, so I added another 1/2 t. of both the cumin and chili powder, then added a few dashes of Penzey's 4S Seasoned Salt and the juice of half of a lime.  The broth is thin, but that is typically how tortilla soup is.  Note:  I originally added one medium chopped onion, as recipe stated, but ended up pulling a lot of onion back out, as that's all I could smell when it was cooking, and it looked to onion-heavy.  Also, the onion was not soft for me until after 5 hours of cooking.  Crunchy onions are not something I enjoy in soup, so I cooked it for longer than the recommended 3-4 hours on high, waiting for the onions to soften.  Overall good, with the added spices, etc. I listed here.

I am having some friends over for a holiday dinner in a few weeks so I was making a "dry run" this afternoon with  this recipe and a batch of Hearty Chicken Tortilla Soup. It looked to me like these two recipes had the most stars so I figured I would try them both and see which one is the best. I followed both recipes EXACTLY except I added a can of drained  and rinsed black beans to each bath. When I served it (in bowl #1 and bowl # 2 so the family vote on the best one) I put some shredded cheese, sour cream and sliced tortilla chips (store bought) on top. The vote is in 3 out of 4 liked this recipe the best. It is a little bit spicier. I cooked it on the stove, not the crock pot. Boiled some chicken breast in a third pot. Cooked for about 40 minutes. I am thrilled, it was very very yummy!  I know my friends will love it too.

text:
This is outstanding! I didn't have time to slow cook, so I cut up my chicken breasts into small chunks and added them to a large stock pot with all the other ingredients, except for the cilantro, which I added about 15 mins. before I served it. I used Rotel tomatoes instead of the tomatoes and green chiles since that is what I had on hand. I simmered it for about 2 hours on my stove. To save time I served it with tortilla chips. My family thinks it is the best soup I have ever made (and I agree)! Thanks for sharing this Elena.

text:
This was DELICIOUS! I took tips from other reviewers:  TIP #1: Use 3 frozen chicken breasts, shred when 1 hour left.  TIP #2: Dice up 5 tortillas and add to the beginning for flavor and to thicken the soup.  TIP #3: Add 1 can of black beans and 1 can of kidney beans.  TIP #4: Omit the water, just use 3 cups Chicken Broth. This will definitely be a staple recipe at my house :) Made lots so prepare to freeze some!

Wonderful!  Cooking chicken in the crock is about the best way to go and makes it super easy to shred, something I would normally despise doing.  (My chicken was also frozen so I stuck it in with some of the liquid stuff and let it cook all night first.)  I didn't use the green chilies cause I don't particularly care for them and I think that would have been too hot.  I think also about half the tortillas were enough.  I did start out baking the tortillas but they got soft after being in the soup anyway, so I used the rest as is.  Super easy.  I would say I think I'd like the chicken pieces bigger and would probably just rip it into pieces next time.

I think this is a little bland without some additional changes.   Use Rotel instead of plain cans of tomatoes. This is a good base.  I needed more broth and salsa, I had lots of chicken but not much sauce.  I doubled the recipe and used 1 cup of corn and 1 can of white kidney beans.  Next time I'll add 2 cans at least of kidney beans and double the salsa and broth.  Also, it has no spice, so if you like spice you'll need to kick it up.  I think I'll add zuchinni next time too.  It's needs more vegetables to me. I threw everything in the slow cooker on high for 3 hours and low for 1 or more.  The chicken of course was perfectly tender.  Really nice, I just think it could be much more.

text:
So good!!!  It was easy also!  I followed the recipe almost exactly. Here are my variations:*I doubled the recipe to make sure I had leftovers. *I added uncooked chicken breasts to the bottom of the pot. Then poured the rest of the ingredients on top. *I used more chicken broth and used less water than called for. 
*I also added a can of drained black beans half way thru the cooking time. *I then took the chicken out an hour before done time and shredded it and put it back in the crock pot. I can't say it enough! Easy, easy, easy! You won't be sorry if you try this recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this recipe all the time and everyone that I have ever served it to loves it and asks for the recipe. I do make the following changes: I don't add any water, instead I use chicken broth, for a total of four cups chicken broth. I also add one can of rinsed black beans. I also add frozen chicken breasts at the beginning and then remove from the pot and shred before returning the chicken back to the soup. I also don't make the tortilla strips, we just serve it with crushed tortilla chips on top along with shredded cheese and sour cream. This is my staple for nights when I don't have time to cook. I just throw everything into the crock pot in the morning and cook on low for 8 hours. If I don't get it started until the afternoon, then I just cook on high for 3 1/2 hours. YUMMY! Oh yeah, I just skip the bay leaf as well and don't ever seem to miss it. This recipe is so easy that I often have my 10 year old daughter start it for me.

This is an excellent, awesome, super easy recipe!! If I could give it more than 5 stars I would.    I used 4 or 5 boneless skinless frozen chicken thighs. This is a keeper recipe.

text:
This is really, really good!  To make it even easier, I just throw the chicken in the crock pot uncooked, remove an hour before serving to shred, and toss it back in.  I also added a can of black beans, which was a great addition.  
I made this to take to our weekly soup supper and accidentally bought "hot" enchilada sauce.  I was worried it was going to be super-spicy, but it seemed to lose a lot of zing while cooking, so it turned out with just the right amount of spice - everyone loved it!  
Make your own tortilla strips - it's well worth it and store-bought chips just don't cut it after having the real thing!  Great recipe!

Used a can of Rotel instead of whole tomatoes, used all chicken broth instead of water, added black beans, added raw chicken breasts from the beginning, shredding once tender.  My firefighter husband says this is firehouse worthy (quite a feat).  Will definitely make this again!

text:
OMG, this was terrific!  I haven't had tortilla soup in years, and I was happy to stumble upon this recipe.  I tore up a rotisserie chicken, then threw everything in the crock pot on low for 7 hours.  I tasted it and I thought it was a little weak, so I added 3 envelopes of no sodium chicken boullion and a little sea salt.  Next time I'll use all chicken broth and no water.  I garnished each bowl with the toasted tortillas, a generous dollup of light sour cream, cubed avocado and plenty of chopped fresh cilantro.  It was out of this world, and I will be making it often!  Thanks for the terrific recipe, Elena!

Great soup!! I didnt have any enchalada sauce, instead I had a bottle of medium taco sauce and a jar of salsa. Added  can of black beans and used frozen chicken that I later removed and shredded just prior to serving. Love it, will be making on a regular basis. UPDATE: Have made this recipe a few time now. Turns out you can use just about any combination of tomato products that you want and it still turns out great. I've used two cans Rotell, pureed can of diced tomatoes and another can Rotell, Salsa, taco sauce, or enchalada sauce as written and its all great!

text:
After reading all of the reviews, I was excited about this recipe. Unfortunately, I messed it up all on my own. I followed all of the original directions to the tee (aside from taking a que from reviewers and using corn tortilla chips rather than making my own)... then sampled the soup about 4 hours into cooking. It tasted like it might need a little more salt - so I added about 1 tablespoon more. BIG MISTAKE. Don't do that. If you add sharp cheddar cheese and store bought chips, that is all the salt you need. Otherwise, it was good. I also added sour cream, which I will leave out next time. It dulls the spices - which is what makes this recipe good. I probably won't make this again real soon, but it will be a good soup to make again on a cold weekend night.

text:
This soup was great. Flavors were right on. Not too spicy, but had just enough heat to give it that authentic taste. You can certainly add more heat to suit your own wants and needs.

I, like a lot of others, can't stand when somebody gives an outstanding review of a recipe, only to read a little further, and realize that they basically changed the entire thing, making it something that it was never intended to be in the first place. That being said, and in full disclosure, I make the following statement: I made 3 changes. 1. I added black beans. 2. I also added white beans. And 3... I put two frozen chicken breasts into the slow cooker at the start, and let them rock. There. I said it. I PUT TWO FROZEN CHICKEN BREASTS IN AT THE START, AND JUST LEFT THEM IN THERE TO COOK! Wow. You have no idea how good that feels to get that off my chest. other than that, followed the recipe to a T. To the letter. No changes. No if's, and's, nor but's.

You know what? In my mind, the base of vegetables, liquid and seasonings is pretty close to perfect. And after all, isn't that what makes cooking fun? Start with a solid base and go crazy from there. Like throwing frozen hunks of chicken in at the beginning.

text:
This recipe is so easy and the outcome was perfect. My family of 4 teenagers (very picky), my husband and I loved it. I made very few changes. I used 3 medium to large frozen chicken breast. i  threw them in along with all the other ingredients. Instead of water and chicken broth i just used a 32oz container of chicken broth (no water). I cooked it on low in the crock pot for 5 hours. Then I came home and took the chicken breast out and used 2 forks and shredded it. It was so tender and I did not have to wait for them to cool to shred them. I put the chicken back in the crock pot and added a can of black beans and let it continue to cook on low for another 3 hours. I was a little worried that I did not shred the chicken at around three hours ( other reviews shredded chicken at around 3 hours) and I thought that I may be cooking it too long, but because I have 4 teenagers that are super busy, I had no choice since I was not home during the day. So in all, the soup cooked on low for 8 hours in my crock pot, and it was super delicious! We had tortilla chips and i also made tortilla strips with corn tortillas. I cut them into strips and sprayed Pam on them and baked them at 400 for about 8 min. Either one tasted great with the soup.  Because of other reviews, I set out sour cream, Cheddar cheese, avocado, cilantro and fresh lime to add to the soup if anyone wanted. This is a recipe I will

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was just as good as the reviews state, which frankly suprised me from the simple ingredients. I stayed pretty true to the recipe, but did add one fun enhancement: I bought a package of chicken thighs to use for the shredded chicken. Instead of cooking and shredding them ahead of time, I trimmed the skin and fat off them and set that aside, and just cooked the thighs in the soup, removing and shredding the meat near the end. But the really fun part was that I chopped the chicken skin/fat into bits, and then rendered it in a pan. Once the skin bits started to get brown, I removed them to a plate, and then used the chicken schmaltz in the pan to fry the tortillas in. Afterwards, I saved the remaining schmaltz for another use, and then put the skin bits back into the pan to finish frying them. Fry them until they are a dark golden brown and very crisp. You can sprinkle them on top of the soup, with the tortillas, or on top of salad instead of bacon bits, etc.

Excellent recipe! I used all broth instead of water, green enchilada sauce and used 1 can regular tomatoes and 1 can Rotel, tomatoes with peppers. I also took about a cup and a half of broth and put it in a blender with about 20 tortilla chips and blended until smooth then added to soup. This acted as a thickener and gave the soup a nice body & subtle corn background flavor. This will definitely become part of our staple "go to" meals.

userID:
13775202
Display Name:
jenn
isPro:

11
favoritesCount:
91
recipesCount:

0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super soup but this is the low down.  Omit the water.  Since tomatoes come packed in water and the canned chichi's enchilada sauce is thin, it doesn't need more water.  Instead I increased broth 1/2c.  The other thing is that i only needed to cook on low for 3.5hrs - i checked to make sure each breast was cooked through, so if anyone has complained chicken is dry then it is overcooked.  BEFORE you shred AND IF you have kids that don't like 'pieces' of veggies in soup, i highly recommend an immersion blender.  You obviously would add corn (microwaved instead of cooked in soup) at the very end, and you would also shred chicken AFTER you blend (pull out breasts before blend then add shredded after).  I prefer to add chips rather than bother with tortillas in the oven.  Part of the beauty of slow cooking is to eliminate extra fuss, imho.  Enjoy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Flat out awesome.  This is of the heartier variety than the glorified chicken broth that some call Tortilla soup, and it couldn't get any easier.  I have not had soup at a restaurant that I would prefer over this one.  I'm all for tweaks, but this one doesn't need to be messed with.  Just make it as written and you won't be sorry.  Now, if you want to make it even a bit easier, you can A) use precooked shredded chicken like you can get at Costco by the rotisserie chickens, or B) just use frozen chicken breasts, take them out about half way+ through, shred with 2 forks, and toss it all back in.  I use about 1 1/2 pounds of chicken.  We like the home made tortilla strips, but use store bought chips because I'm lazy.  The shredded Monterey Jack or Pepper Jack cheese (not cheddar) and sliced avocado to add when serving is an absolute must.  YUM!  An across the board favorite with everyone in the family.

text:
This is a winner, hands down!  It is SO delicious! My dear husband, who is NOT a cook, assembled this (we doubled the recipe which filled the pot to the top) into the slow cooker for me on his day off for a party I was hosting that night.  We reviewed the recipe the night before, I chopped and bagged onion & garlic, and measured out spices.  All he had to do was open cans and dump everything in.  Based on reviews, he added only one bag of corn and one drained can of black beans, adding chicken breasts whole - they were so easy to shred just before serving.  For ease, we used store bought tortilla chips and served along w/a grated Mexican cheese mix.  I also served a minestrone, prepared the night before, from this site.   Both soups were a hit, but this one especially so!  Ladies came back for seconds and two requested some to take home to their husbands.  We were left w/one scant serving.  Needless to say, hubby was so proud of his accomplishment that he now enjoys assembling slow cooker recipes on his day off.  He even does his own chopping AND the last recipe he chose himself.  Thank you Elena!  This is in my recipe box definitely we will be making it again!

text:
I am IN LOVE with this soup!! Followed this recipe almost to a tee. I omitted 1/2 tsp of salt, added 2 cups of drained black beans that had been cooked from a previous dinner, and added 2 extra cloves of garlic. I ended up using 3 raw chicken breasts and cooked the whole deal in a cast iron dutch oven on my stove for 6-8 hrs at around 2-low temp. Shredded the chicken about 3-4 hrs in. My whole house smelled amazing! I followed the directions for the tortilla strips exactly and they turned out great! When it was serving time, I placed a few strips in the middle of the bowl with a dollop of sour cream in the center, cilantro for garnish, a couple slices of avocado and a squeeze of fresh lime juice. Absolutely scrumptious!! I wanted to eat the whole pot! Thank you, thank you! I will make this over and over again!! :)

text:
This is a good recipe to start with and can be tweaked to your liking.  I followed others' tips and added beans (I used white beans) and just threw in frozen chicken tenderloins instead of pre-cooking.  A jar of salsa is a great sub for the canned tomatoes.  I also stirred in a can of refried beans at the end, which really thickened it up and kicked it up to 5-stars.

text:
Good recipe. Live in Southern California and have spent tons of time in Mexico and I thought this had a very authentic taste, especially considering how easy it was. I made some changes based on what I had a available and our taste. I used a hot enchilada sauce and also added some hot sauce. We like spicy and this had some serious kick! I skipped the water and added more broth. I made this on the stove top. I added raw chicken breast to my broth and let it simmer on really low for a while, pulled it out and shredded it and then added it back in. We topped it with a little queso fresco, lime, cilantro, avocado and greek yogurt (in lieu of sour cream).

Just had this soup tonight for dinner and it was just what we needed. We just finished a juice detox this week so we were looking for something light and healthy to start eating again. We followed the recipe as is, but of course, we like things spicy, so we substituted the canned green chili peppers for three medium jalapenos and one serrano chili (finely chopped). It gave it just the right SPICE =) Tip: for crispy wavy tortilla strips, be sure to slice them thin.

OMG I LOVE this soup! And everyone who's tried it loves it. I've given the recipe to several people and they love it. I use chicken broth instead of the water, add a can or two of black beans. I cook the chicken in the water w/ some vegs for flavor. I also go ahead and add the lime juice at the end of cooking cuz I freeze it in individual bags to take to work for lunches. Not going to drag a lime w/ me. I don't do it in the crock pot, just cuz I make it on weekends to freeze, but would have no problem doing that. This is my FAVORITE soup.

text:
I like mine spicy so I doubled the chili powder, and I added an extra garlic clove.  Instead of canned chilies, I diced a fresh jalapeno.  I could have added one more jalapeno honestly.  The recipe calls for 1 tsp of salt, but it probably needs 2.  Make sure you squeeze lime juice when serving; it makes the world of difference.  I would also suggest topping it off with real Mexican cheese like queso blanco, which is similar to Monterrey jack.
