text:
I made the following adjustments:  

2 large cans imported Italian tomatoes with sauce (more flavorful) instead of green chiles
4-5 chiles in adobo sauce (added some of the sauce as well)
1 box chicken stock (no water)
Doubled the cumin & chile powder 
~ 7-8 cloves garlic pressed
4 chicken breasts.

I brown the onions in olive oil in a cast iron skillet first (add garlic for last minute) before adding to slow cooker.  This adds a smoky flavor.  We like lots of tomatoes so the 2 cans might may be overkill for some.  My adjustments pretty much double the recipe.  Like others, I add the chicken breasts thawed but raw and let it cook 6-7 hours, shredding chicken after 3-4 hours.  I also mash the fomatoes before adding them.  Yummers.  We eat it for days.
 
This recipe gets rave reviews from family/friends.  We are native Texans/ transplanted North Carolinians so I have to do my own Mexican.  This is a first-rate soup.  You will spoil your family where they don't want restaurant tortilla soup!

I love this recipe. I decrease the water (to about a cup) and add an additional can of enchilada sauce. I also add 3 cans of chopped green chiles instead of one. city:

country:
None
text:
Turned out even better than I thought it would!  I love chicken tortilla soup in restaurants but have never attempted it at home.  I tweaked a few things based off reviews here and what I had in the house:  1.) Like others said, no need to cook the chicken first.  I threw in 2 large chicken breasts, partially thawed then shredded them up after they were cooked in the soup. 2.)  Added 1 can of broth plus the 2 cups of water...then got nervous it would taste too watery, so I threw in a chicken bouillon cube for some extra flavor 3.)  Had a ton of jalapenos and tomatoes from my garden so I used them instead of canned tomatoes and green chiles and 4.) not a fan of corn so I subbed a can of black beans and added some chopped celery for extra veggies.  I also used store bought tortilla strips (found by the croutons) instead of making my own.  I'm surprised seeing anyone call this recipe bland!  The result was a very flavorful restaurant-quality soup that even my husband (who loves everything as spicy as possible) really enjoyed.

I give this recipe five stars for the idea and concept.... anyone that cooks knows their preferences and how much work they want to put into it and can make adjustments from there.. since we are using a slow cooker, I used raw chicken.. I am married to a Mexican and he prefers fresh so we just used a chicken we raised... also used tomatoes cilantro garlic onion and chilis from our garden... just chopped them up and let it cook all day... made my own enchilada sause with chili ancho... and the tortilla strips are amazing when you make them from hand made tortillas... added black beans that i had washed and sorted.... they cook in plenty of time to not have to use canned... and used fresh corn as well... just shaved it off the cob... it is more work to eat fresh, but ohhhhh so rewarding.... the taste was absolutely amazing... we just served it with jazmine rice.... smelled great and the kids and husband loved it! not to mention my brother in law who is from Guatemala... so all in all ... very good!

country:
None
text:
Good mix of flavors, but I have to agree with the other criticisms of this recipe.  Definitely use dried chiles to make the "enchilada sauce"...
No need for a slow cook, the flavors will blend well by simmering for an hour or so on the stove...
Lastly slow cooking already cooked chicken meat results in a stringy, chewy mess.
Would make again with this ratio of ingredients (and fresh red chile sauce) but saute the onions, garlic, and spices first, then add all but the chicken, cilantro, tortillas and corn to simmer for a while before adding the remaining ingredients to heat through.

text:
This was absolutely delicious! I did make a few very minor changes but this would still be amazing if made as is.. 1. I added 1 can of rinsed red kidney beans. 2. I did not add any salt to compensate for all of the sodium in the canned goods. 3. I used tortilla chips I already had. 4. I put 2 raw chicken breasts in, cooked on low for 4 hours, took them out and chopped them and then threw them back in. So, the flavor of this was incredible. It is most definitely a keeper and I WILL be making it again. The whole family loved it. Oh, and don't forget the avocado, cheese, and sour cream or plain Greek yogurt (healthier and just as yummy..) when serving! WOW, totally kicks the flavor into high gear! I added some diced avocado, a sprinkling of sh. cheddar and a T plain Greek yogurt to the top once in the bowl - divine!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is absolutely one of my kids favorite meals! I've made it about 4xs now and when I say this is for dinner, everyone is very happy!

Now, for ease, I've made a couple changes, but nothing drastic. I use 1+ lb frozen, boneless, skinless chicken thighs (I just put them in the crockpot FROZEN). For the onion I use 1/4 c dried onion (because my daughter hates the texture of onions and she doesn't notice these). 32 oz chicken broth (one of those cartons). At this point, all the rest the same except I do not add the corn or cilantro yet. I cook it on high for 1-2 hours (until the chicken is fully thawed and stating to cook) then low for the rest of the day (probably low all day would be fine too.) 1-2 hours before eating I take out the chicken and shred it, add it back and add the corn and 1 can drained beans. Black and canolini so far. (Cannolini are the favorite.)

Serve in a bowl. Top with a handful of Fritos, some shredded cheese, a blop of sour cream. Omg...sooooo good!

This was surprisingly simple and very flavorful.  I am keeping this as a crockpot fave.  Some reviewers complained about it being too soupy and not having enough substance. text:
Loved this receipe, have to admit I'm not big on canned food to make meals but, this served such a good purpose, it allowed me to rotate and use some of our older cans.   I added a bit of Queso cheese, used both diced can of tomatoes and sliced stewed tomatoes.  I increased the servings, added some brown rice, black beans, bag of corn, fresh cilantro, basil.

I like my soups hearty and I read a few reviews that stated the recipe was a bit watery (not for me).  I added a total of 3 lbs of chicken, 1 large breast was cut extremely small which helped to thicken the soup.  Just used store bought tortilla chips due to time contraints, but I'm confident it would taste a bit better if you take the extra 10 min to make some.  Will make again!

text:
This is such a great tasting and simple recipe!  I  shredded left over roasted chicken (you could easily use a grocery store rotisserie chicken).  Because of time, I didn't slow-cook the soup.  Instead I heated all the ingredients to a boil, then simmered on low for 1-1.5 hours on the stove.  I didnt have whole canned tomatoes, so used canned diced (love it!).  The enchillada sauce I used was "medium" which added a nice heat.  Next time however I'll try "mild" so our toddler can enjoy the soup.  I served each bowl with a squeeze of lime, tortilla chips, shredded cheese and a dollop of sour cream.  It tasted complete, but next time i will add cubed avocado too.  Also, next time I will add the salt at the end.  The particular canned enchilada sauce i used pushed the sodium level up a little high for my tastes.

text:
This has become my all time favorite go-to soup.  I can prep it in 15 minutes and it is so good.  My alterations are as follows.  Keep in mind that we enjoy a heartier (and spicier) soup that isn't quite as brothy.  I use hot enchilada sauce and also add a can of hot Rotel.  I drain everything and eliminate the water and the bay leaf.  I put 3 very large chicken breasts in the crockpot frozen along with the ingredients through the pepper.  In my opinion, the soup needs more cumin, chili powder, salt and pepper.  After it's cooked on high for about 4 hours, I shred the chicken and add a can of black beans (drained), the corn and cilantro.  I let it cook a little while longer on low.  I have given out this recipe more than any other one ever!!  It's so good.

text:
Wonderful recipe! Definitely a keeper! Very easy to make. I started with raw chicken diced up and put in the crockpot with the rest of the ingredients. To give it more flavor I used 2 cups more chicken broth where it calls for water (cut back on salt though if yours contains salt). I also used frozen fire-roasted corn from Trader Joe's and it worked out great! Like another user suggested, definitely good with avocado slices and grated cheese on the top, lime juice and extra cilantro on top for garnish (don't skimp on the cilantro - I used an entire bunch-- gives it a more authentic mexican flavor).

None
text:
I definitely scoured the other reviews to add in a few items that came up quite often. Cooked brown rice. Dollop of fat-free greek yogurt (FAGE) instead of the sour cream works beautifully. Added avocado chunks/slices. Cotija cheese from the local mercado. Tons of cumin. If you can find freshly made mole poblano paste, I'd add some to taste. Also, the canned black beans — should have drained it, but was in a hurry. Tons of garlic. Shredded a rotisserie chicken from Costco (for $4.99) and put the bones/carcass in the slow cooker. Didn't add the chicken til right before serving. Lots of bay leaves. Grabbed a pack of frozen roasted corn from Trader Joe's. The 4oz can of green chile peppers was made up of jalapenos. Totally swapped out the water and chicken broth with organic chicken stock in a box from Costco.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent soup. Can't stop reheating for meals, it's been my dinner for 4 nights. My "mistake" was using a 28 oz can of whole peeled tomatoes because it's what I had on hand. I was prepared to add more spices but didn't need more. I used a hand blender to smooth out chunks of tomato (my preference). I added 2 TBSP of pre-shredded Mexican cheese to my bowl before adding hot soup, and then put my tortilla shreds on top. Highly recommend cheese for added yumminess. Thanks for great recipe!
** Oops- Forgot to add I cooked the chicken breasts from raw in the slow cooker soup for 6 hours. Then shredded and added back for another 30 minutes. I see no point in cooking chicken prior to soup prep.
Update- A big hit at the Super Bowl Party last night. Wanted to say that I now always use a 28 oz can of tomatoes and a 14 oz can of enchilada sauce. Remove the chicken breasts and use a hand blender to make a smooth soup. Then add back shredded chicken. I serve the soup with a tray of garnishes, which include Mexican shredded cheese, green onions, tortilla crisps, and extra raw tomato.

text:
We absolutely love this recipe!! I made a few changes just to make it easier. I don't use a can of diced tomatoes and a can of diced chilies. I use 1 can of Rotel tomatoes. Also, I usually toss the chicken in still frozen and come back about halfway through after it's cooked, shred it and let it cook a little longer. And I don't bake my own tortilla strips... we just use tortilla chips. When it's done, I usually sprinkle some cheese on top add some avocado and dig in! We have this frequently since it's so easy and so good.

text:
I followed MexicoKaren's advice and made the enchilada sauce, which was a huge improvement over the canned one. Still, I had to do a lot of doctoring up. It was watery, and lacked depth of flavor. I tripled up on the spices (cumin and chili powder), added two chicken bouillon cubes, 1T fresh chopped oregano, and a cornstarch slurry to thicken it. Only THEN did it taste good. I'll try it again using 3 skinless bone-in fresh chicken breasts and 1 quart chicken broth to boost the flavors.  The frozen chicken and frozen corn could have contributed to the wateriness, and diluted the flavors, not to mention drying out the chicken.

This is exactly like the tortilla soup we often have in Cabo San Lucas, Mexico except it has more "stuff" in it.  They are kinda chintzy at the local dive that we frequent.  The only changes I made, by accident, were to add a 14 oz. can of enchilada sauce, forgot the garlic and put in 32 oz. of chicken broth for the water and broth originally called for.  I did not add the fresh cilantro until serving time.  I added 1 packet of True Lime per large serving bowl, 1 chopped avocado and used crushed store-bought tortillas to save time.  It was outstanding!

text:
After all the positive reviews I decided to try this recipe.  It always makes me laugh when reading the reviews and people post that the recipe was bland and had no flavor.  Well cooking is all about taste and adding seasoning until it hits your palette.   After cooking for eight hours it was missing a flavor so I added a corona beer and BAM that did the trick.    Everything else was kept the same.  I did use raw chicken breasts and they were fully cooked and tender after simmering all day.   Thanks for posting this recipe.

Display Name:
jen

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Looking for perfection? I think I found it with a few changes. I used a large/26 oz can of tomatoes with the juice, a 32 oz box of low sod chx broth instead of the water + broth, bumped up the cumin and chili powder to 1 1/2 t each, used a whole 16 oz bag of corn, added a couple teaspoons of worcesterchire, a 1/2 t of Tastefully Simple Mexican seasoning, added an undrained can of low sodium kidney beans and didn't add the cilantro while cooking as my husband doesn't care for it. The rest I used as listed. I brought it to a boil in my dutch oven and then simmered on low for an hour or so. I topped all the bowls with a generous squeeze of lime, cilantro for mine and just crumbled up a few black corn tortilla chips on top. Seriously, really great and good for you, too! Highly recommend it whether you do it as is or with a few changes. Yummo!

text:
I love this recipe - I make it all the time. I actually cook my chicken (whole) in the crockpot, take the meat off, and keep it in the freezer for anytime I need cooked chicken. Be sure to make your own tortillas for the top...take a flour tortilla and fry in oil in skillet until golden and puffed. Cut into strips with a pizza cutter....so much better than corn chips or  tortilla chips on  top - really makes it super yummy....also, add a dollop of sour cream. YUM!

Display Name:
Acadiana Doll

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an easy recipe and it came out really delicious once I changed it up a bit to fit my family's taste. I threw everything in the crock pot, including 2 large whole frozen chicken breasts, and let it cook all day. I omitted about 1/4 cup of the broth since some water would come out of the chicken as it defrosted & cooked. I shreded the chicken & threw it back in to absorb the flavors of the soup about 30-45 minutes before serving. I didn't have a fresh onion on hand so I used about 3 tablespoons of dehydrated onion flake and it worked fine. I added a 10 oz (I think) can of Original Rotel and 1 packet of Mahatma Spanish Rice mix (with the seasonings) to the soup. It gave the dish a little more flavor and texture. Also, instead of mashing whole tomatoes I used diced tomatoes. My family and friends loved it, so it's now in my regular monthly rotation for the colder months.

text:
I LOVE tortilla soup. If it is on the menu, I am ordering it. With that said, I have had some average chicken tortilla soup and some amazing chicken tortilla soup. This homemade recipe is great! Plus .... with 2011 just starting, I know I am trying to watch my sodium and calorie intake. Making your own soup allows for this.  So try this recipe, you will not be dissapointed. SUGGESTIONS: I like my soup spicey. I am a Latina who only knows spice. I bought the "hot" enchilada sauce which added a kick! Plus ... for added heartiness, I added black beans. The soup was delicious and filling. Think fiber, fiber, fiber. Enjoy!

text:
I thought this soup was wonderful. I made it exactly as the recipe stated with only one minor change... I used 3 cups of water and two chicken boullion cubes. Other than that, I kept it the same. It is very liquidy without much substance, but I think it is supposed to be that way... more room for tortilla chips! This is how I prefer my tortilla soup in any case. Lots of broth, lots of chips, and lots of cheese! THis is one of the few things that I cook that I prefer over a restaurant. Some have complained about the soup, but it must just not be to their liking... I cook ALOT and there is nothing wrong with this recipe at all! IT comes out great and flavorful. If I could give it more stars, I would.

country:

text:
So good! I've been fighting with the tortilla soup recipes on this site trying to find one that was just right and this is THE closest to what I want, with a couple easy tweaks. I always use chicken broth in place of water, and I made homemade enchilada sauce, a lil more than 10oz. I doubled the garlic and all seasonings and added one low sodium chicken bouillon cube. To me, Mexican food isn't right without oregano so I added 1.5 tsp. I used about half the chicken, but the full amount would be good if you like your soup very chunky. I keep hominy on the side to add to the soup bowls too. Thanks for the tasty recipe!

text:
I made modifications to duplicate the Tortilla Soup I was craved and devoured while I was pregnant! Such as...cream of chicken soup and broth-no water (to thicken a bit), and instead of enchilada sauce taco seasoning! My favorite tortilla soup had (substance ;) large chunks of veggies: potatoes, carrots, onions, celery and black beans...not just corn!It was very hearty and filling. This recipe is my base for re-creating my favorite soup ever so I recommend being creative! Use your imagination if something doesn't look or taste the way you hoped/ think it should!This is something I have learned after trial and error and overcoming fear of the kitchen...As the cook we get to taste before we serve, right?

Loved this recipe!  I took the suggestion of others and simply put my uncooked chicken in the slow cooker at the beginning. Topped with shredded cheese, a spoonful of sour cream, and cubed avocado - Yummy!

This was the first soup that I have ever made and it was AWESOME!!! I put 4 frozen chicken breasts in my crockpot on high for 3 hours, then removed and shredded and cooked for another 2 hours on low. (I threw in a can of black beans at this point)  I used diced tomatoes instead of whole ones and a carton of chicken stock and 1 1/2 cups of water. This soup was incredible, will def make again!

None
text:
I made this for a small dinner party last night. The guest of honor doesn't eat gluten or dairy, so planning the meal was a bit of a challenge. Everyone loved the soup and asked for the recipe.  I used leftover chipotle fried chicken from the deli section of my grocery store; shredding the chicken was the only time-consuming step of the recipe.  It simmered nicely all day and made the house smell wonderful.  I also created a salad bar, which included a taco station.  People could add salad bar items to the soup if they liked; these included habenero shredded cheese, black beans, chopped green onions, chopped tomatoes, and sour cream.  I'll make this soup again and again.

text:
Excellent soup I didn't use a crock pot, I cooked it on the stove slowly all day.  Also I used homeade enchlada sauce from this site which was very good.  3-4 ancho peppers seeded boiled in 3-4 cups of water with onions, garlic and salt for about 30 minutes then put all of it in a blender including water with a small can of tomato sauce blended; added directly to soup.   Also this soup goes very well with the southwestern eggrolls from this site.  Wonderful meal.

I literally crave this every few weeks! I agree with several other viewers' suggestions-- black beans are a must, use chicken broth instead of water, and frozen chicken breast works JUST FINE! We did try the homemade baked tortilla strips vs./ store-bought, and it's definitely worth the extra 5 min to make the homemade. Lastly, don't skimp on the fresh cilantro and sour cream. Works equally well for both a cozy winter brunch, and a summer evening light supper. YUM!

text:
Very good recipe! I modified a bit for a low sodium option. I started by put frozen chicken tenderloins on the bottom of the crock pot. The tomatoes were diced canned (no salt), no broth, 2 cups water with no salt chicken bullion, only had a half package of frozen corn & a can of (no-salt) chili beans. Chopped up some fresh spinach, put on bottom of bowl, poured soup over making sure to get one chicken tenderloin for each bowl. Garnish with a dab of sour cream, reduced fat shredded cheddar cheese & crushed reduced fat tortilla chips.

Loved this soup! Everyone including the hubby who is the pickiest eater in the family had seconds. Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I think this is by far the best tortilla soup than any restaurant. The aroma while it cooks smells so good. The changes I made to the recipe are to just add 2 frozen chicken breasts and take them out 1/2 hr. before serving and shred. I used Las Palmas Red Enchilada Sauce, S&W Italian Style tomatoes, added triple the garlic, added 2 cans of chicken broth and omit the water, about 1 cup of black beans (soaked overnight), about 4 bay leaves, and few dashes of cayenne pepper. The heat was just perfect. Garnishes: tomatoes, green onions, cilantro, jalepeno, lime, sour cream, mexican style cheese.  I missed the review to omit the salt to lower the sodium content, which I will do next time. There's so many garnishes, the salt is really not needed. I baked the tortilla strips with cooking spray, garlic powder and cumin. The next day, however, we just ate the soup with warmed corn tortillas. The soup is very filling so get extra helpings in small batches! We thought that the tortilla strips weren't really needed and just an extra garnish. Warm tortillas work just great. There was so much leftover, I even served some over a bed of lettuce for lunch and another meal over warmed tortillas like a tostada. Definitely will be eating off it for a week.

text:
I use a recipe similar to this, but I use the slow cooker only to stew the whole chicken while at work.  I remove the meat & use the stock (plus additional over the counter if needed).  I add all the same ingredients, but leave out the enchilada sauce and, cumin & chili powder add 2 pkgs of taco seasoning.  I also add 1 can of rinsed black beans &/or kidney beans, and a couple of handfulls of crushed Mega Thin tortillia chips.  The crushed tortillia chips absorbe liquid, dissolve and thicken the soup.  Also, the whole chicken & stock stock is worth the extra work involved.

text:
I thought this was excellent, DH felt it only worth 3 stars, so I gave it 4. A few minor changes I made: Used frozen chicken breasts that I shredded an hour before serving, unsalted canned corn, fat/salt free chicken broth, and added black beans. I left out the 1 tsp of salt--not needed with the enchi sauce, imo. The dispute between this soup came from the enchi sauce. DH felt it either needed to be left out (and replaced with broth) or greatly reduced to make the soup more authentic. He also felt it needed a squirt of lime juice. I had chips on hand that turned out to be a little stale, but worked great with the soup. I also served with sour cream and shredded cheddar.

text:
This soup was a hit with my family of 8!  I did cook the chicken and shredded it up before adding to the crockpot, but I think I will just throw in the breasts as suggested in a previous comment and shred it up before serving next time.  I used the hot mexican chili powder instead of regular, and also set out a bottle of Tapatio hot sauce (as suggested in a previous review) for those of us who wanted to spice it up a bit.  I toasted the corn tortilla strips with garlic salt, cumin, and hot mexican chili seasoning. Everyone really liked the added flavor the strips added to the soup.   Definitely keep an eye on the tortillas.  I made 4 batches and some seemed to cook faster than others (I accidentally burned one batch).  The only other thing I would add is if you have a large family like mine, double the recipe so you can have left-overs!  We ate ours up!

text:
This is a great recipe if kinda pressed for time and love to use your slow cooker like I do. Followed the recipe except for a few changes. I used a pre cooked roaster chicken(costco)cut up, 1-7 oz.can chopped gr.chilies, 3-3/4 c. water with 1T. chicken bouillon, 2-1/2 t. cumin, 1 T. chili powder, 1-14oz. can corn, (drain, rinse) 1-15 oz. can diced tomatoes, 2-cans black beans (drain, rinse). Small hand full chopped cilantro. Omitted the salt used bouillon instead. Remember to taste and adjust spices including the salt content before serving. Add chopped cilantro shortly before serving. Serve on the side, grated cheddar cheese, lime wedges, sour cream, chopped fresh cilantro, crushed tortilla chips. And there you have it. Enjoy!

None
text:
Don't use store-bought tortilla chips!  It really is very easy to just bake corn tortillas as in the recipe and the taste difference is incredible.  I used baked tortillas for dinner, then for lunch the next day I was in a hurry and packed tortilla chips.  Big difference.  Don't be lazy if you have time!  Also, this recipe was a little spicy for me, but I'm sensitive.  So if you're sensitive, you may want to make it a bit less spicy.  I could still handle it though; it was so good I couldn't stop slurping it down!!

userID:
1408537
Display Name:
JILLZYC

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an excellent soup.  We served it to company for dinner and got raves all around.  I used all broth and no water, bumped up the seasoning quite a bit, and added a can of rinsed, drained black beans and some uncooked brown rice to make it a more filling, complete meal (which required the addition of more broth and therefore even more seasoning toward the end of the cooking time, as the rice absorbed a lot of the liquid).  I also threw in the chicken breasts straight from the freezer at the same time I tossed everything else in the crock pot, and shredded the chicken an hour or so before serving.  I let it go in the slow cooker about 8 - 10 hours on low.  Just prior to serving I added the juice of an entire lime to the whole pot, which made a HUGE difference in the taste -  I definitely recommend not skipping the lime juice.  We garnished with sour cream, avocado, and tortilla strips made as directed in the recipe. It made excellent leftovers for lunch the next day, and I made the last of the leftover soup into a hearty, creamy dip for tortilla chips the day after that.  It was a huge hit all around - thanks for a great, versatile recipe, Elena!

text:
I LOVE this recipe and will make it again and again and again.  I did two things SLIGHTLY different.  I had two Anaheim pepper to use up so I decided to make this soup.    I roasted my peppers over an open flame (my gas grill) and then put them in a paper bag for 5-10 minutes. I then peeled the skin, chopped them, and added them to the soup.  Also, I added two split chicken breasts and then shredded them about 3-4 hours later.  I garnished with some avacado (lots for me 'cause I love them!) and some Kroger Quesadilla cheese.  WE also just used up some thin tortilla chips we had leftover, instead of making our own tortilla chips.  This will be a regular rotation for our fall/winter meals and an occasional meal in the summer!

text:
You have to try this! Using frozen chicken breasts worked beautifully. I shredded them about 1/2 hr before serving. I followed the recipe exactly, only doubled it for my family's size. Only other addition was black beans. It was a huge hit with everyone. Since it was Saturday & I had the extra time, I made the homemade tortilla chips. I used flour tortillas as that's all I had on hand and spritzed them with lime juice and sea salt before baking. The chips, light sour cream & shredded cheese were great toppers to the soup. This truly was delicious & the house smelled so good all day while it was cooking. "Souper" easy & "souper" good.

text:
Loved This one!!  I took leftover Chicken from the "Roast Sticky Chicken-Rotisserie Style" recipe... And just chopped it up to use for this recipe...Wowza was it good!!    I reduced Salt to 1/4 Teaspoon and made up the difference in Black Pepper...Also to make it extend further, after the first servings of this soup have been eaten, I add some brown rice (about 1/2 cup uncooked) to the soup and let it cook for awhile longer till the rice is incorporated.  Or to save that step, you can take precooked rice, put it in a bowl and ladle the soup over it if you like...but being from New Mexico, I rarely do this unless I'm really tight on the budget, and trying to stretch my soup as far as I can.    Just letting you know that it does work...but Brown Rice tastes better than white for this purpose.    Enjoy this wonderful recipe..It's Yummy on a Chilly Evening!   PS..I leave out the corn for this recipe.

text:
This recipe was simple and very good.  I baked 4 chicken breasts in the slow cooker on a spiral of foil and drained the liquid and fat.  This brought the weight down to just about a perfect pound.

I used two cans of chicken broth and no water.  I used a teaspoon od dried cilantro and then served with fresh cilantro instead of adding to the crock pot.

Next time I make this I will use a larger oval crock pot.  I made this in the 4 Quart size and it was a bit fuller than the pot should have been so I cooked it extra hours.

text:
This kind of bombed in our house. I have no idea whether our chilli powder is just sxceptionally spicy or what, but even after using only 1/2 a ts of the the chilli it was a lot spicier than expected...and we love spicy. I've had this soup before at a Mexican restaurant and remember disliking it because I felt like I had just spent my money on a bowl of broth...and the same problem exists here. I know I would be ruining the authenticity of he recipe...but I feel like it needs some substance. Maybe a few carrots, chopped green beans, and a can of black beans? And I used uncooked chicken cut into chunks, and am very glad I did. Cooked, shredded chicken in the slow cooker? Wouldn't it just completely dissolve into chicken mush? 
And I know everyone said that they went out and bought the chips...but that ended up being our favorite part. I hate tortilla chips, but these were great: crispy, not greasy at all. And of course, I couldn't stop myself from dolloping plain yogurt on top( like I do with everything) but it really tempered the spice. Overall, I liked it more than my family...just like most things I make;)

text:
This was really good.  I'm new to cooking and I was so excited that this tasted so good for lunch for me, my fiance and his sister.  I followed advice of other reviewers and put frozen chicken breasts instead of regular or precooked and I omitted a cup of water.  I just took them out before serving and it was incredibly easy to shred them. (something I've never done before) I put it all together and cooked it over night.  I woke up just to turn off the crock pot, then let it sit there for a couple of hours until lunch time.  I turned it back on to heat back up, while I prepared the tortilla, then shredded the chicken.  
I served it with a side salad and self-serve bowls of avocado, grape tomatoes cut in half, grated mexican blend cheese, sour cream, the suggested baked corn tortillas, tabasco sauce and medium salsa.  It was fun and like tacos or something, everyone could doctor it to their tastes if they prefer it hot or like a lot of cheese, etc.  It really was yummy and easy.  
Not that cheap for me, because I didn't have all those spices and ingredients already, but now I have them for future recipes!  
I definitely recommend it.

text:
I love this recipe!  I've made it several times and it always turnes out great.  My family has been know to comment about a dish they didn't care for all the much as saying "Its no chicken tortilla soup".  I add the beans which has helped my family to realize they do like beans after all and replace the water with chicken stock.  Putting the frozen chicken in, in the morning works perfectly.  The only issue is that with so much really good stuff in this soup it becomes more of a stew.  You can add more liquid either water or stock if your slowcooker still has room or just add some more liquid when you eat the left overs just make sure you also add some of the spices or it will make the soup more mild.

I just got a slow cooker and this was the first recipe I tried with it; I have to say it was very yummy! However, after halving the recipe (it's just my roomate and I) I made some changes since I didn't have all the ingredients on hand- Like other reviews suggested I threw in the chicken still frozen and shredded it about an hour before serving, I used 2 fresh tomatoes rather than canned, 1/3 Cup of Spicy Salsa to replace the enchilada sauce, instead of chicken broth I used tomato soup, added a 1/4 teaspoon of cayenne pepper, added 1/2 Cup of black beans and topped it off with sliced avacado,and served it with cornbread...mmmm yummy!

Absolutely amazing! One of the best recipes my wife and I have ever made in 13 years! We have tried several recipes like this, and have found this one to be our favorite. We did not use the enchillada sauce though; instead we used 10 oz. of garlic lime salsa from walmart. We put the tomatos, salsa, onion and green chile peppers in the blender to give the soup a thinner consistency. We also made some white rice to throw in the individual bowls of soup. Probably the best soup I have ever had. Make this - you won't regret it!

This recipe was a hit in our family! Many copies were requested. The only changes I made were that I followed the advice to put in raw chicken (mine was even partially frozen) and cook it on low for about 4 hours. I then took it out and shredded the chicken which made the chicken very tender and fall right apart. Also, I added hot sauce (as a good Southern girl should!) which gave it a good kick. I also used all chicken broth in place of the water. Try it with Mexican cornbread! MMM!!!!!!!!

text:
I've made this recipe twice now. The second time, I simmered it on the stove instead of in a slow cooker. The flavor was much better cooked on the stove in my opinion. The tomato cooks down and gets less acidic and the spices blend and mellow more with stovetop cooking I think. I used the ingredients as directed except I added a can of black beans and extra chicken broth. My husband didn't like the slow cooker version, but did like it cooked on the stove. The tortilla stips really make the dish, their flavor is awesome, don't skip them!

I am well aware that this recipe doesn't need yet another rave review, but I am going to give it one anyway! The soup is simply incredible and extremly easy to make! One of the top three soups I have ever tasted -- let alone made myself!! I kept pretty close to the original recipe, with the exception of: adding chipotle in adobo sauce and jalepenos instead of green chili peppers (because I didn't have any), using homemade enchilada sauce, and using only chicken broth (no water). What I love about it the most is that it isn't just spicy, it is wonderfully flavorful too. Thanks for a great recipe, Elena!

My husband and I both thought it was too watery so I would probably add some black beans, omit the water and substitue another can of chicken broth.  Tastes great when garnished with a dollop of sour cream, generous amount of shredded cheese and some crushed tortilla chips.

I have made this several times, first time added raw chicken breast simply let it cook in the soup, came out moist and tender. The next time I had some left-over Rotisserie chicken and Turkey breast in the freezer and I added it. Both ways is very good. I use a little under a box of chicken stock and no water, doubled the spices and added a tsp of Chipolte Chili pepper. Also added a can of rinsed and drained black beans. Serve with shredded Cheddar cheese and fried home made tortilla chips. Perfect!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My picky Mexican husband LOVED this soup.  It really doesn't require a slow cooker.  I made it on the stove top following the exact same recipe except that I cooked 2 raw bonless, skinless breasts in the soup.  I brought the soup up to a boil then turned the heat down to low and covered the soup until the chicken breasts were cooked through (About 1 hour).  I removed the breasts to shred the meat, placed the meat back into the soup and we were ready for dinner.  SO EASY and so yummy.  We topped ours with totilla chips, cheese and diced avacado.  It's a meal in a bowl that we will make again and again.

userID:
1511201
Display Name:
Zelda
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really enjoyed this recipe. A lot of users complained about it being too spicy but it wasn't spicy enough for me. Probably because I used a can of mild green fire roasted peppers as it was all I could find in that size of can. However that worked out great because everyone could make it just as spicy as they desired by sprinkling in some Tapatio (hot sauce). I used two whole chicken breasts still on the bone but minus skin and cooked them right in the soup from the beginning. The chicken came out very tender and fell right off the bone. Simply take it out, shred it and plop it back in the soup. I wanted something a bit more hearty so I made some instant white rice separately and let people add in as much as they wanted. I also used store bought tortilla chips and just crushed them between my hands into my bowl. I served this with crema Mexicana and it added great dimension and flavor to the soup. And for anyone who made their soup too spicy this would really help out. I sprinkled in some shredded oaxaca cheese which was also good but a tad too mild so I’ll probably use Jack next time. I will definitely make this again. Oh and I used all chicken broth and no water. Left overs were great!

text:
It may not be quick, but it is the BEST!  The only thing I do differently is to boil a whole chicken, and instead of using a canned broth, which usually is fairly tasteless and salty, and  I use the broth from boiling the chicken.  I don't care for enchilada sauce in chicken tortilla soup, so I leave that out.   A plus of boiling a chicken is having a lot of good shredded chicken to add to the soup. It's perfect and exactly like they make it at my favorite Mexican restaurants.  I live in Texas and there are a lot of good Mexican restaurants here. Lol!

text:
This was an excellent crockpot recipe that I tweaked a bit based on other recipes I have tried.  I used 1.5lbs of chicken, a 10 oz can of rotel tomatoes with green chiles, a 32 oz can of enchilada sauce due to the added 0.5 pound of meat and black beans, a 32 oz can of chicken stock instead of adding water and reduced the salt by half due to the added salt in the chicken stock, and a can of black beans.  I also put some avocado on top when serving, which added a nice creaminess to the soup.  I will definitely be making this on a regular basis!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-12-09T13:04:10.387

15228676
Display Name:
Astrohip
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3703991.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good soup. Just the right thickness, great flavor. My changes: used all broth instead of water, added one can (drain/rinse) black beans, one chopped jalapeno. Also upped the chicken to 1.5 lbs, and used whole breasts. About two hours before serving, take out the breasts, let cool a couple minutes, then shred with a fork, dump back in. They will literally fall apart. I also added chopped green onions as a topper, in addition to cheese, lime juice, tortilla strips and avocado.

Get a nice fresh bread at the store, slice thick, toast, and serve with the soup. Makes for a nice juice soaker-upper.

BTW, this may taste too hot during cooking if you sample, but when it's served, with all the toppings, it comes out perfect, just the right spiciness.

text:
Warning - I am rating my version of this recipe... I put the chicken in raw as others suggested. Left out the chiles. Used minced onion. All chicken broth instead of water. Was out of corn so I added a can of black beans. Took the chicken out to shred after 4 hours on high. Tomatoes were still too chunky so I used my immersion blender to smooth it out (which yes, puréed the beans, too). Added the shredded chicken back in, along with 1 cup uncooked quinoa and a can of pinto beans. Cooked on high for another 20minutes or so, then stirred in a couple of tbsp of whipped cream cheese (trying to calm the heat down for my hubby). With the exception of the cream cheese, this was a protein packed, clean eating yummy supper. I "ruined" that with corn bread on the side, but the whole family enjoyed it. My daughter wanted thirds!!

This soup is delicious, I did make a few changes though. I used diced tomatoes, I'm not one for re inventing the wheel. I shop at Aldi and they don't sell canned green chilies but they do have diced tomatoes with chilies so I used those. As far as the chicken goes, I put frozen breasts right in the crock pot and dumped all the other ingredients over them. When the soup was done I pulled the cooked chicken out, shredded it the dumped it back in. My family loved it!

text:
I made this pretty much exactly as called for in the recipe.  I didn't have chicken broth, so used a couple of bouillon cubes and that worked out fine. The tortilla strips were OK, but it would be just as easy to use store bought tortilla chips on top.  I served it with sour cream and avocado slices on the side so guest could top as they liked.  Now, here's a surprise... with the cost of avocados, I didn't want to risk wrapping up the leftovers in plastic wrap as they usually still turn brown.  So, I simply added them to the soup leftovers.  I just had a bowl today, 2 days in the fridge and the avocados in the soup are still nice and green!  This soup is seriously good, ever so easy and just as good as restaurant quality.

text:
I followed the recipe mostly as written, I did not use tortillas ... I went and bought Tostitos scoops and crushed them up.  The recipe did not say red or green enchilada sauce so I used red, also added some chicken stock cubes to my 2 cups of water and a can of drained black beans (based on prior reviews).  The one thing I did was to put the spices in a container the night before, chopped up the onion and stored it, and the liquid type stuff including the green chili peps into a container the night before ... along with the shredded chicken ... it was so easy to open those 4 containers and put them into the crock right before I went off to work !!! the cumin adds such a great smell and taste ... well worth the try and will definitely makes again.

I live in New Mexico, and have always sought out the best tortilla soup at just about every restaurant  in Albuquerque,   This recipe ranks with some of my favorite restaurant's version of tortilla soup here. 14835037
Display Name:
Adri

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe should be called "Cure your Cough Chicken Tortilla!" I feel like it could have used a little more salt, but I don't know if that's just because I'm sick and my taste buds are out of whack. I did make some changes. I read some of the reviews, and decided to go without adding water, and instead just put a little more enchilada sauce. I also got 2 12 oz bags of a frozen blend at the store that had corn, black beans, poblano peppers, and onions, so it made life a lot easier, as far as the onion was concerned, and I got to add beans, which was a plan anyway. I also added 2 cups of brown rice, and I felt like it thickened it up the perfect amount. I'm a wimp when it comes to spicy, and I thought it might be a little too spicy with the peppers in the corn blend, and the chillies, but it actually wasn't spicy at all. Next time I'll probably add more chillies or get hotter enchilada sauce. I also just threw the chicken in the crock pot raw, shredded it about 15 mins before it was done, then tossed it back on to soak up the sauce. I loved this recipe though. It was so good, and not too much prep work at all, which was nice.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-12-28T08:41:51.047
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
17138046
Display Name:
Candy Munkres
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3040360.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is awesome!!!

Ok have to celebrate. Last night I cooked dinner and at the request of my hubby I tried Chicken tortilla Soup.
This all started from the need to have to cook the thawed chicken breasts that were not used as intended.
So starting at 3:00pm put the breasts in the slow cooker on high with some water and jar of salsa, then to the store to get the ingredients of the recipe below.
Now if anyone knows me and my husband you will know there are quite a few things we are picky about. So the recipe was slightly altered to meet the picky substitutions and necessity of ingredients on hand. 
1. Had to double the recipe as we had more chicken we had to cook.
2, Only one can of enchilada sauce so Added 10oz of Chunky mild salsa. 
3. Garlic wasn't really measured so heaping teaspoons for each clove needed.
4. And probably the most important - the frozen corn was replaced with corn cut off of four fresh ears of sweet corn. (No need to cook before putting in soup)

What we had was INCREDIBLE!! 
Of course topped it with shredded monterrey jack cheese and broken tortilla strips.
CAVEAT - There isn't enough juice, as this is a really really hearty soup. So I ended up adding more chicken broth and water, so had to add more seasoning.
However if you start with a rotisserie chicken you can cook this in your slow cooker real easy. We will definitely be cooking this one again!!

text:
I love this soup! My family loves this soup! I use chicken, tomatoes and chicken broth that I have canned in quart jars, so I double the recipe and freeze half for later. I also like to add a 15 oz. can (two if doubling) of black beans. Don't skip the fresh cilantro! It makes a big difference in the flavor. I turns out almost like a stew rather than soup. We just crumble a couple tortilla chips on top of the soup rather than bake the tortillas and cut them up. Although I am sure it would be delish, I have never added cheese, avocado or lime. Just stir a little dollop of sour cream in. Yummy!

Side note: The rest of my family would not agree, but I actually prefer a bit less chicken than called for. If making this to suit my taste, I would probably use only half the amount of chicken.

text:
This was ridiculously good! And so easy! It took me seven minutes to throw all the stuff together. I took others' suggestions and just put the raw chicken straight into the slow cooker. No need to waste time cooking it ahead of time. I also just dumped the tomatoes in... Didn't mush them up or anything. I actually used skin on, bone in chicken breast halves (about two... So it was more like 1.5 pounds of chicken and it turned out great). When the whole thing was done I took the chicken out, removed the skin and bone, shredded the meat, and threw it back in. I think the skin added some much needed fatty richness to the soup and the bone added some more flavor. To save time I just topped the soup with crushed white corn tortilla chips. And shredded cheddar and extra cilantro! Definitely add avocado if you've got it! This one is a keeper! Tastes like a restaurant soup!

This is a easy soup recipe with great favors. Anytime my husband says, "this is really good", I give 5 stars. city:

text:
This soup was delicious!  I took the advice of other review-writers, and cooked two large whole boneless chicken breasts in the crock pot to save time.  I removed them about 30 min. prior to serving the soup, shredded the chicken, and returned the shredded chicken to the mixture to simmer for the last 30 minutes or so.  I like a heartier broth, so I replaced the 2 cups of water with 2 additional cups of chicken broth.  I didn't have fresh cilantro, so I used dried cilantro.  It was good, but I'm sure the soup would be even better with fresh, if available.  The crispy tortilla strips that topped off each bowl definitely added flavor.  I didn't need to leave them in the oven as long as specified- watch these closely so they don't burn!  My mother ate our leftover soup during a visit, and asked for the recipe to make it herself.  I will definitely make this again!

text:
First time making homemade soup, and this was a good choice.  I used a rotisserie chicken to save time.  It smelled so delicious slow cooking all evening!  I would suggest keeping a close eye on the tortilla strips baking in the oven, mine were done long before the 10-15 minutes listed on the recipe.....and they added a nice crunchy garnish to the soup.  I also took the suggestion from another reviewer, and added a squirt of lime and some shredded cheese (I have used reduced fat sharp cheddar, and 4 cheese Mexican, and loved each bowl) on top before serving.  This soup was worth the wait, will make again in the future!

text:
My family enjoyed this and I will make again.  I thought 10 oz of corn was too much and I will decrease by half the next time I make it.  I used 1/2 of a small can of tomato paste instead of the tomatoes (my clan hates tomato pieces in anything) and I thought this gave the soup nice body--less watery than as written?  This soup is easily kicked up with whatever spices you like, and cheddar, lime tortilla chips, lime juice, cilantro and sour cream for garnish.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/57525.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super easy crock-pot meal.  I used Frozen boneless breasts from Costco and a can of Rotel, rather than the whole tomatoes and the green chilies.  Just dice up the chicken when you get home. I leave out the Cilantro as that is a love-it-or-hate-it herb...and I HATE it.  I found the broth a little thin the first time I made it, so I tossed in a handfull of crushed tortilla chips the second time.  These break down and the Masa helps to give the broth a little more body for a great mouth-feel.  Couldn't be simpler to toss it all in the crock before work and come home to a hot and tasty meal minutes after walking in the door.  Makes the house smell heavenly and inviting after a long day and leaves plenty for the three of us to take for lunch leftovers. This will go in the regular rotation.

text:
I had no idea I would love this soup so much! I really don't eat much soup, but I had a leftover rotisserie chicken  I wanted to use up and it was a cold day (perfect for a slow cooker  meal) . I omitted the corn (which I'm sure would be delicious) and I actually omitted the tortillas  (due to laziness) and it was still wonderful. I ate this for every meal for three days. I can't wait to make it again. I served the soup with diced avocado , extra cilantro , and cheese. Great recipe! Thank you!

Not quite sure why I didn't much care for this recipe,but I'll try. I followed the recipe true, with the only change in chicken broth. Instead of using 2 cups of water I used chicken broth in addition to the chicken broth  it asked for. I think it was a little too watery. I like my soup on the thicker side,but ok. I'm not sure I'll try this recipe again.

userID:
2603534
Display Name:
Take2Bake
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/49466.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe more as a basic outline substituting the closest resembling ingredients with what I had on hand. Like everyone else, I added two raw chicken breasts. I had a bad experience once with enchilada sauce so I used 8 ounces of Wolfgang Puck's arribiatta marinara sauce. I used one can of black beans drained, not rinsed and one can of corn not drained. I use one can of diced tomatoes instead of whole peeled and one green bell pepper, instead of green chilies. I added about 3 tablespoons maybe 4 of chicken paste about 4 cups of water (didn't measure) and one can of tomato paste. It was not watery at all. The rest of the spices I use were the same except I had no cilantro, I added 3 small bay leaves, I don't usually use black pepper so I didn't & I forgot to put in garlic. I am a huge garlic fan and always like a pungent garlic flavor so I always save fresh garlic until the last five or 10 minutes. This time I was so excited to taste it, I forgot to put the garlic in. I just shredded the chicken and enjoyed myself with some sour cream, shredded cheddar cheese and crumbled restaurant-style tortilla chips. I still enjoyed the flavor.  My five-year-old enjoyed it as well. So glad to have another easy winter staple.

One of my favorite recipes. As with other reviewers, I throw in a frozen chicken breast in the morning and shred it later. Using tortilla chips is a bit easier, but I much prefer making strips from the corn tortillas. They really add to the flavor and texture of the soup, much more so than the chips. I also like to add a little shredded cheese as a garnish.

city:

country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe ALMOST exactly; only things I did different were to use fresh opposed to canned whenever possible, made my own chicken stock using raw chicken, water, and chicken flavored Better Than Bullion, and made my own enchilada sauce using the ten minute enchilada sauce recipe from site. For the stock, I cut about 1-1/2 pounds of raw chicken breast, then cooked with the water and BTB. It came out ten times better than it would by just opening and dumping cans of stuff into a crock pot. It could easily be made on the stove but I think slow cooking it marries the flavors better. If you don't like things too spicy, use about half the amount of chili peppers (and if you're using fresh, wear gloves before chopping!!!). Absolutely delicious.

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2014-01-26T13:14:37.603
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
10347942
Display Name:
Crys Kaufman
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
52
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5554116.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great,"what do I have in my pantry?" recipe.  Didn't have chicken or broth but had a 3.5+lb pork shoulder in  my freezer. I seared the pork in garlic salt and chili powder, added heavy dashes of seasoned salt, sea salt and smoked paprika to about 3 cups of water and tossed it in the crock pot. Seared up 3 slices of thick cut bacon and covered the top of the pork with it and added the rest of the drippings to the pot.  Cooked on low over night, switching to warm around 4 a.m.  Shredded the meat with tongs in the morning. Found some bell pepper/onion mix in my freezer that I sauteed with garlic and cumin then added to the pot.  Used canned Mexican corn, seasoned black beans, red enchilada sauce (though considered adding green).  Used 2 cans of Ro*tel and added two dried chipotle peppers to the pot.  I did time and a half the recipe since there was so much meat.  Garnish with cilantro, avocado, sharp cheddar and lime juice.  I bought tostadas and Salsa Verde Doritos for garnish, too!  

I disagree with other reviews that said this was too spicy or too watery.  But again, i changed the recipe quite a bit.  I do agree, however, with a reviewer who said it doesn't need to be a crock pot recipe. You can EASILY do this on the stove top in 30 minutes.  Buy a roasted chicken and shred it up, toss everything else in a stock pot and bring to a boil.  The flavors come together nicely once the soup has sat over night as well. Makes great leftovers!

text:
Prepared this for the family last night. I followed the suggestions from many reviewers and tossed uncooked chicken into the crockpot. About midway through the day, I took the meat out and shredded it, returning it to the pot for the rest of the day. 

Everybody went back for seconds. That was all I needed know. Yep, this one is a winner!

I'm sure, as some of the more critical reviewers point out, it could be improved by changing out certain ingredients, but for those of us who don't have enough time to make enchilada sauce from scratch or prepare fresh tomatoes, recipes like this are a such a welcome gift!

text:
I think this is missing some essential umami depth, but I couldn't quite find the right add to make me feel I got "it." (I tried a bit of tomato paste, which helped.) It's still delicious, though. I doubled the recipe, used about 1.5 quarts of chicken stock instead of water, I sauteed the onions first and then added about 6 good sized cloves of garlic to the saute and them added to the pot. I used uncooked chicken breasts that I pulled out to shred about about 2.5 hours (and then added back in for 2.5 more hours). I also served over Cilantro Lime Rice from this site, which was delish, along with monterey jack cheese, avocado slices, generous squeeze of lime per bowl, extra cilantro, and sour cream. I'd definitely make again but I'd try to figure out the missing ingredient for the depth I was looking for. Maybe chipoltes in adobo...

text:
This soup is wonderful!  It is a staple in our house now, thanks!  I almost have it memorized, so now I can make it without checking back AND when I am at the store I automatically know if I need anything to make it.  
I usually don't add any water, just all broth.  My husband is hispanic, so he needs his beans, lol!  That said I typically cook up some beans the night before and add about 1 cup to the soup.  I typically add diced tomatoes just cause I have them around the house.  I always throw the chicken in frozen, it shreds beautifully when done cooking.  Other than that I keep it pretty much the same.  I sometimes use corn, or depending on the mood I throw whatever veggies I have on hand.  I made it with frozen peas once and I was concerned that it would be gross but it came out just great.  I don't think there is any way to mess this one up.  Simple and worth it every time.

text:
I don't usually leave reviews but this was so amazing I had to share. First of all, this was SOOOO GOOD I can't believe I made it. I usually suck at cooking. This soup was better than anything I have had at any restaurant. Here are a few pointers I wanted to share: you should definitely taste the broth as you start to mix things up, don't follow this recipe to a T or it will be bland. I used semi-thawed chicken breasts and took em out and shredded them and then added them back in 30 mins before the slow cooker turned off. I had to add more Enchilada Sauce and spices cuz it was bland originally, next time I would probably only use 1 cup of water and not two. Chop up your onions super small, you don't want to eat big chunks in your soup. I topped the soup off with Green Onions,Avocado, Cilantro, Sour Creme, Cheese and Thick cut tortilla chops from the store. So amazing!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
With a few modifications this is an excellent recipe, but given the amount of tweaking that I had to do (based on previous reviewers suggestions) I can only give this recipe 4 stars. Changes I made: Started with raw boneless chicken breasts, after two hours on high they were done and ready to be shredded, I added the chicken back into the slow cooker with a can of corn (frozen is nasty) and a can of black beans. Doubled the cumin and chili powder and used all chicken broth, no water. The cooking times on this are way too long. Like I said, after 2 hours on High, a raw chicken breast was done and ready to shred, not sure how long it would have taken on Low. I also didn't add the cilantro to the slow cooker, I garnished the soup with it, I really like fresh cilantro, as opposed to cooked to death cilantro. And, since I'm doing the low carb thing, I served this on a bad of cabbage, and didn't make the tortilla strips. This recipe is super easy, I will definitely be using it again.

This soup was awesome!  I doubled recipe for a school luncheon but tweaked only slightly due to other reviews. Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this on Monday with a few changes and it came out EXCELLENT! I did not brown the chicken first - that is a waste of time and will make little difference in flavor. Instead, I threw it into the bottom of the crock pot raw. I used a fresh, finely diced tomato in place of the peeled, mashed tomato. I did not have enchilada sauce on hand so I used a small can of tomato paste, a guajillo (dried, stemmed, seeded), and additional (maybe about 2x the amount) cumin, chili powder, and black pepper. I also added cayenne pepper, dried cilantro, red and yellow bell pepper, and celery. I cooked it on low for 8 hours and shredded the chicken with forks after about 7 hours, but you can also cook it on high for 4 hours. I served it up with fresh sliced avocados, "Mexican" blend cheese, sour cream and salsa. (Don't forget the fresh margaritas!) This came out so awesome, we each had two servings that night and ate left overs the next day. It is now Wednesday and it will be gone by lunch for sure!

I thought this recipe was delicious! Especially since it's a crock-pot recipe! I made it one day as a diet thing (to eat some soup before each meal to eliminate calories) and I've thoroughly enjoyed it--which is not common for me with tortilla soup. I usually feel like they have too much chili powder, but this one is not like that. The only thing that I think is a little less-than-great is the canned tomatoes. I want to try to find some jarred peeled tomatoes next time because I feel like canned tomatoes taste a little like aluminum (but that's just a personal preference thing). Also, for the chicken, I used about 5-6 chicken tenders and boiled them in salted water, then shredded them myself.

Display Name:
mel_dubb

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
AMAZING...with a few mods
First, i used a 28 oz can of enchie sauce, i used mild and with the other spices in there it still had a kick.
(using more enchie sauce might work for the people who complained it was too watery, mine was not watery at all)
Second- I only used half of a medium onion
Fourth- i prob used 2-2.5 lb of chicken to make it nice and hearty
Third- another thing that prevented mine from becoming too watery is i added the water last, i only used two cups of water and added one chicken bouillon cube, essentially omitting the water from the broth, yet still giving it the broth flavor
I cooked my chicken first, mainly bc i was pressed for time and wasnt sure if i could get this done in the alloted time.  Threw all the ingredients in and turned it on high.  Prob had it cooking for about 4-5 hours.  I cubed up some avacado, shredded some cotija cheese(a mexican cheese), squirted fresh lime juice, and used the crispy corn tostadas instead of baking my own and YUMMMMMM!!!
In the end, a really healthy(if youre not on a low sodium diet) and protein packed meal!! This will definitely be in the regular mix of meals.  Super easy to make and packed with flavor(i am a very picky eater, so take my word this is a great recipe)
Notes: I would prob omit the salt next time since there is so much salt in broth and enchie sauce and the whole tomatoes.  I prob wouldnt spend the money for one bay leaf, not sure how much that would change the taste.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is now one of our favorites!  I followed some of the suggestions in previous reviews to make this simpler and a bit healthier.  
*I toss boneless chicken breasts in and shred at the end right before serving.  
*Add a can of low sodium black beans (rinsed). 
*Substitute a can of low sodium diced tomatoes for whole peeled.
*Use 1 tsp. of dried cilantro instead of 1 T.
*Eliminate the 1 tsp. salt altogether.
*Add 1 reduced sodium chicken bouillon cube or 1 tsp granules to the 2 cups water.
*Serve with Baked Tostitos and a little shredded sharp cheddar.

text:
My family of five LOVES this recipe!  I did make a few small changes to make it quicker.  I toss diced raw chicken in the crockpot rather than pre-cooked shredded.  It saves time, and works great!  I also thicken it slightly with corn starch (2-3 Tbs mixed with about a cup of cold water) - Last but not least, we crush corn chips into the soup rather than making our own strips.  Wonderful recipe... thank you!

I used the suggestions of others and put in 3 frozen chicken breasts that I shredded after they cooked.  I used 15 oz rotel diced tomatoes with green chilis instead of the whole tomatoes, and also added black beans (drained and rinsed).  Added about 1/2 packet of taco seasoning as well. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wanted something to eat with my Margarita and I didn't want to wait 4-6 hours so I did this in the pressure cooker.  Added the ingredients and one, frozen chicken breast half.  I brought it up to pressure then maintained it for 15 minutes.  I shredded the chicken and returned it to the pot and *VOILA* Chicken Tortilla Soup in 30 minutes.  I put tortillas in the bowl, added the soup and garnished it with a lime wedge, avocado, and shredded cheese.  Been awhile since I had Sopa de Tortilla back in Mexico, don't know how authentic this is BUT it was quick, easy and best of all tasty!  Will add this recipe to the "Soup" section in my recipe book for sure!!

text:
I changed more in preparation than I did ingredients in this recipe.  I did as others suggested and left my chicken breast whole and I also added it frozen.  I added all ingredients except the corn to the crockpot overnight.  All I needed to do in the morning was remove the chicken to shred it.  It was so tender and falling apart that it was almost self shredding!  And the flavor was amazing!  I added the corn and some chili beans and let it cook on low heat for another couple of hours.  One of the best things I have ever made and so easy!

text:
This recipe is awesome. I'm sure the sodium content is on overload but with a few changes this recipe can be super healthy and tasty. I peeled two whole tomatoes and chopped them instead of adding the can of whole peeled tomatoes. Then I boiled my chicken in water( just enough to cover the chicken) until it was tender and shredable. The water used to boil the chicken of course was now broth so there was no need to add a can of broth. I omitted 3/4 cup of water and added some mrs. Dash herb seasoning. There were no left overs!

text:
I followed the recipe word for word, and the soup was very bland and watery tasting.  I used a canned enchilada sauce, and those are sometimes hit or miss for me - some taste good, and others don't.  So my choice in the sauce may have negatively impacted the soup.

Looking at other reviews, I added half a package of taco seasoning and half of a lemon.  Without those small changes, the soup would have been depressing, but I would make it again with the taco seasoning and lime.  Very tasty.  The posted recipe still needs some work in my opinion.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a big hit with my family.... I did however double the recipe.. The serving size say 8, however, we use bigger bowls (like chili or rice bowls) and my family of 5 likes to eat... I also like to have some leftover.  Doubling the recipe ensured that my entire family had a nice bowl of soup and there was enough left over for seconds and even some for lunch the next day.  I did not cook my chicken before adding to soup.  I simiply added everything together and cooked it in a big pot right on the stove since I had doubled it.  I did shred the chicken after 3 1/2 hours...  I did add cooked brown rice after shredding the chicken as one person suggested.  Once the soup was served in bowls, I added chunks of avocado, some shredded cheese and a squeeze of fresh lime to each bowl.  Lime is a must!!  Adds great flavor.   I tried to make the tortilla strips, but they burned the first time in the oven, make sure to keep an eye on them, 15 minutes is way too long... I then tried them in the microwave for 4 minutes on half power.. Some of them still managed to burn but those that didn't were very tasty... I ended up using regular tortilla chips in the soup and everyone loved them just the same!  My 12 year old daughter wants me to tell you the soup was phenomenal!  Again a big hit!  Will most definitely make again.

We swapped pinto beans for the corn, because my husband doesn't care for corn, and used bagged tortilla chips. Also just chopped the chicken into small spoon-sized pieces and let it cook in the slow cooker - did it on high for 4 hours rather than low for 8, and it turned out WONDERFULLY.

text:
I made this recipe as part of the hidden treasures blog by mis7up.  I have had this recipe in my box since July 2009.  My 9 year old and I really liked this soup.  My husband on the other hand said it was to “tomatoe.”  That may have been my fault because I used a quart of tomatos that I canned instead of the 15oz can the recipe calls for.  I was also unable to add as much water as the recipe called for because my crock pot isn’t that big which probably contributed to the overly tomato taste.  I used frozen chicken breasts instead of cooked shredded and then pulled them out and shredded them before I was ready to serve which worked great.  I would make this again with a pint size jar of tomatos.

this soup was fantastic!! i altered it slightly, only because i didn't have the exact ingredients. i couldn't find enchilada sauce, so i used mild taco sauce instead. i also used a combination of onion powder and minced onion spices to replace a fresh onion. i pureed the tomatoes and chilies on accident, but it actually came out better that way. go easy on the tortilla strips, they soak up most of the soup. i will definitely use this recipe again and again. delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup was great - I only added a few things to kick up the spice. I also added cayenne pepper (to taste, depending on how spicy you like it), a pinch more chili powder, red pepper flakes and a drizzle of hot sauce. When I served the soup, I squeezed a lime over each serving, and topped with a pinch of Cheddar Jack cheese (which melted right in). I also added a can of black beans for some protein, and since the corn was frozen, I didn't add water and used 2 cans of chicken broth instead (I figured there would be some water when the corn defrosted). 

All in all, a great soup and my husband says is a "repeater."

text:
Very, very flavorful.  I loved it!  It is a spicy dish, so you must like that.  The tortilla strips were a nice addition.  I would also add a dollop of sour cream to "tame" the spice a bit- or if serving to children.  Makes a nice main course if you serve a big bowl of corn chips and Guac. on the table.  I used Old El Paso enchilada sauce med. and a Vadalia for the onion.

text:
Very good BASE for a good soup...with a few changes. 
Like other reviewers, use 2 cans broth instead of water. I also used red enchilada sauce, because we like things HOT! Used about 1 T of chili powder and double the cumin...even with these changes it was still a little bland and had to add more chili powder to taste. Also added 2 extra cloves garlic. DEFINITELY cook the chicken in the slow cooker with the rest, and serve topped with shredded Mexican Cheese Blend =)

Display Name:
Susan C

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/357814.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this soup - make it all of the time.  It is so easy - mostly just opening cans. It is great for a pot luck.  Some changes:  like someone else suggested, don't bother cooking chicken in advance.  Just throw it in the crock pot.  1/2 hour or so before eating, shred up the chicken and throw back in.  Instead of whole tomatoes, I use fire roasted diced tomatoes.  Also, leave the cilantro out and serve as a garnish when eating.  Otherwise, it turns brown and isn't fresh.  I serve this with basmati rice, shredded cheese, lime wedges and sour cream.  For a twist, throw in some black beans.  If you want to make it with a kick, use hot enchilada sauce and diced jalapenos.  If you make it mild, you can always spice up your bowl with a spoonful of habanero salsa.  Love this recipe!

text:
A new family favorite...we have had this every other week for about 2 months now.  We leave out the cilantro and bay leaf just because we don't have those on hand and it turned out great without it.  We also add 1 Tablespoon of chili powder rather then one teaspoon.  Make sure your chicken is shredded prior to starting the soup, it really makes a big difference in the end result..believe me, that batch didn't turn out very well. :)

text:
YUMMY!! I loved this soup more than I thought I was going to. I did change it up based on what I had in the house. I used Las Palmas Green enchilada sauce, I didn't have a can of green chilis so I ended up using 2 cans of rotel instead of the can of tomatoes and chilis. We wanted it spicy so we used about 3 oz of diced jalepenos from a can which added a nice kick to it. I didn't have cumin or bay leaf but it still had a lot of flavor!! I also just put 1 1/2 raw chicken breasts in the crockpot and it cooked the meat and also made it fall apart tender. Thank you!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup was sooooo good!  I made a few modifications to the recipe though.  I used shredded chicken leftover from a whole chicken I had made the night before, so I made this on my stovetop instead of the slower cooker.  Used 4 cups of water for more broth (in place of water and broth the recipe calls for), added 4 chicken bullion cubes, a can of diced tomatoes instead of the whole tomatoes, and a can of black beans.  I brought the soup to a boil and then let it simmer for two hours, and didn't put the corn and beans in until the last half hour of cooking time.  I also used store bought tortilla chips crunched up over the top instead of making the strips myself.  I also served flour tortillas on the side.  I will definitely make this again!!  We looked forward to the left overs the next night because it was that delicious!

Absolutely amazing! text:
I have never made a home made soup before, and this was perfect. I just got a very nice slow-cooker and wanted to make a healthy tortilla soup. I followed the recipe step by step (which I normally use it as a guideline and add more/change, etc.) except I used chicken boullion (one square) because the chicken stock flavor didn't really come through. Make sure you break up the tomatoes really well, and they will break up more as time goes by. I used a small onion and 1/4 cup parsley. Thanks for this recipe!

text:
LOVE this recipe! I have very little time in the morning, so I make ahead the night before, with a few minor changes: xtra chicken breast, already cooked and shredded. Diced tomato instead of whole peeled. No salt (there's plenty in the enchilada sauce & the chicken broth). No bay leaf. Take it out of the fridge & throw the crock pot on low in the AM on the way out the door, and this is excellent when we get home! The kids like to crush up tortilla chips & sprinkle on top. A new family favorite - thank you!

This was AWESOME!  Bonus that it was so stinking easy.  I was really leery about using the enchilada sauce but it was so good.  Very close to restaurant in AZ I used to eat at.  Added little chunks of cheese and avacado to the bottom of the bowl then added soup...the cheese got all melty and gooey.  Yum-o! I used 2 skinless chicken thighs and one frozen chicken breast (added last minute because I didn't think the 2 thighs would be enough).  I pulled the bones out and just broke apart meat with a fork.  It was the perfect amount. I also added 1 can of rinsed black beans and 1 small can of niblets corn about half way through....LAWDY LAWDY so good!

text:
I really liked this recipe alot, but I did change a few things: for one, I used a bit more chicken (probably closer to 2lbs) and coated it in taco seasoning mix and then seared in my dutch oven. This made it more like a stew than soup. I then added 3 cups of chicken broth (no water), didn't use the enchilada sauce and I also used crushed tomatoes vs. whole peeled. Next time, I am definitely going to add black beans, 2 cans, and puree one of them w/ the crushed tomatoes.  I did this for another soup recipe and it just adds a ton of flavor and makes the consitency a little thicker.  Great recipe though! Very easy and delish!

I found this recipe months ago and have made it many times now.  It has become a family favorite. I have also served this at a few parties I have had and it was a big hit.  Like some other reviewers suggested, I used crushed tomatoes instead of the whole and I add a can of black beans.  I also used a large container of chicken stock and 3 cups of water.  This is the easiest thing to make.  Also, you don't have to cook it in a slow cooker.  I have also just cooked it in a large pot on the stove for an hour.  Turns out great.

country:
None
text:
Love this recipe, so easy. I know the ingredients list looks daunting, but remember that you are dealing with a slow cooker recipe. Just dump everything in and go.  My suggestions: I omitted the extra 2 cups of water. Would have been much too broth-y had I left the water in. I used drained canned corn in lieu of frozen. Also, a whole onion was way too much. I did a half an onion and it was still too much. I doubled the cilantro because I love that flavor. Also I used medium heat enchilada sauce and it gave it just the right amount of kick.   The recipe made more than enough for my fiance and I to have two bowls of it and enough leftovers for two days, so I'd say they are right on the money with the yield.  We will be keeping this one in our recipe rotation for sure.

text:
This soup was wonderful. I added black and white beans, extra corn, an extra can of enchilada sauce, no water (all broth), and used frozen thighs. This is a super easy dinner to throw together in the morning. To save more time, combine it all at night, stick it in the fridge, and bring it out the next morning before you head out for the day. I really liked the idea of throwing cheese on the tortillas before adding them too. This was a huge hit in my household and we will DEFINITELY make it again. Thanks so much for sharing this with all of us! So yummy!!!
