photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7059540.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have a usual taco soup recipe but it's more of a meal and we wanted some tortilla soup that was light and brothy. This was definitely that and we really enjoyed it. The only changes I made was omitting the cilantro and adding some extra cumin, chili powder, and tossing in some garlic and onion powder. I also used only chicken broth instead of water. Oh, and I threw in raw chicken breasts and just let them cook, shredding them with about 30 minutes left. There's really no need to pre-cook the chicken. My only recommendation to make this better would be to use an extra chicken breast because it's a lot of broth without a lot of chicken. A little more chicken would make it perfect. It was very much like restaurant tortilla soup so if that's what you're looking for this is a good recipe to follow.

text:
This soup, WITH the garnishments was pretty good.  The soup all by itself would just be "ok" I think.  We garnished it with shredded mexican cheese, sour cream and lime juice.  And I was surprised at what a difference the lime juice makes!  It adds just the right touch.  We also baked the corn tortillas brushed with oil and seasoned with salt and pepper and they were great!  My kids loved eating the little crunchy strips!  Even though this wasn't the best soup I've ever had, it was good and I will probably be making it again.  Almost forgot~ I made a few small changes...used all chicken broth instead of chicken broth and water and I doubled the chili powder.  Also put in a slightly larger can of green chilies than what it called for.

text:
This is the BEST tortilla soup I have ever had!!!  As other reviewers have mentioned, I too use frozen chicken breasts, I start off on high for the first 2 to 3 hours, remove the chicken to shred, then return shredded chicken to the pot and turn down to low for several hours.  I always make a double batch, as this soup goes quickly at our house!  I top the soup with packaged tortilla strips purchased at a local food service and shredded cheddar...YUMMO!!!

I made this soup for a team potluck at work and it was the first thing to get eaten. Everyone loved it! Just like most of the other reviews I only used chicken broth (no water) and i added corn, black beans and rice. It made it so much better and more filling. I threw everything in the crock pot this morning and it turned out wonderful :) SO easy to make and perfect for those of us who like to be done with dinner early in the day so that they can focus on other things. I did make the tortilla strips from corn tortillas as the recipe says to do and I really believe this added a little something extra. However, I am sure chips would work fine too. If you make your own, you could add whatever seasoning you like before placing them in the oven just for extra flavor. I just added salt + pepper. I do believe this soup needs MORE salt than called for in the recipe. Maybe an extra teaspoon? Overall, this dish was a hit with our family. Thank you!

Big hit.

Love it!  Love it!  Love it!  My husband, who likes nothing with shredded chicken, loved this soup.  I only tweaked this recipe a bit for our taste.  I didn't use any water. Probably one of my favorite soups.

text:
My crockpot was engaged this morning so I made this in a big pot. I used the last of my pre-cooked chicken I had in my freezer, organic diced tomatoes (that was all I had on hand), homemade enchilada sauce made with organic tomato juice/sauce, I eliminated the water, used two cans organic chicken broth and tripled the spices. Because I'm trying to watch my carb intake and bump up my veggie intake, instead of corn I added three chopped zucchini, half a head of cabbage and two large organic red peppers. So far, this soup is awesome. I'll update my review once it's had time to simmer and combine flavors. With any recipe, it's really all about the quality of ingredients that you use. I think using organic ingredients and more spices, this made my soup really sing.

text:
I  thought this would thicken up some how but it was just really brothy.  I liked the flavor but it needed some binding, I thought.  I made Mexican Rice II and then put that in the bowl and put some of the soup over.  That was very good.  I also added a can of drained and rinsed black beans.  Since I used rice I didn't use the tortilla chips.  Adding a dollop of fat-free sour cream hit the spot.  With these changes, it's a great recipe and very easy to throw together with the frozen chicken tenders.  Beware, it makes a TON, but from the other reviews I see that it is freezable.  In the freezer the leftovers will go, into individual ziplocks for later meals.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe to start off with. I am a beginner soup maker so I was a bit nervous but read others reviews and took their tips. The chicken shredded quite easily after about 3 hours on low in the slow cooker. I used chicken stock instead of water and broth. I also added black beans to help this be a more hearty soup. Its simple to make the tortilla strips yourself and worth the effort as they keep their crispness longer than any bag tortilla chip would once it's in the soup. We also served with optional monterey jack cheese blend. Easy to adjust how "spicey" this can be with measurements. Got good reviews at church today and Serving this to my kids tomorrow for dinner. My husband was quite happy with this as well. I would recommend keeping extra chicken stock on hand should more cook off than expected.

text:
This gets 5 stars for both taste and ease! When my husband came home and saw that Mexican was on the menu he said, 'oh, I ate at Chiptole like 3 hours ago.' So he wasn't really in the mood for it again... or very hungry, for that matter. Anyway, the man went back for a heaping second helping! Both of us commented on how amazing it was! I took the advice of many previous reviewers. I threw 3 large frozen chicken breasts in the crock pot and replaced the water with more broth. I also added some sweet white corn. I shredded the chicken about 30 mins before serving and plopped it right back in. I had bowls of cheese, chopped avacado, and tortilla chips for everyone to add on their own. This was SOOO good! I'm so glad there are leftovers for tonite. My only change I would make next time would be to double the cilantro.

None
text:
Absolutely fantastic. I served this at an impromptu dinner gathering and it got rave reviews. As other reviewers suggested, I started with frozen whole chicken breasts and took them out and shredded them before serving - which I believe kept the meat from drying out. I also used frozen fire-roasted corn (which they sell at Trader Joe's) which really gave it an added authentic punch. A squeeze of fresh lime was also very helpful. I put out a host of possible toppings from which guests could chose - lime wedges, diced avocado, fresh cilantro, sour cream, blue and yellow tortilla chips, diced green onion. It was a lot of fun!

text:
So good!  I put frozen breasts in the crockpot, pull them out right before serving, shred them with two forks, then dump them back in the crockpot. I use a can of diced tomatoes instead of whole because my life is easier when soup doesn't have ingredients that are bigger than mouths of children. Plus, I find it silly to buy whole tomatoes and crush them when chopped tomatoes are available for the same price. I don't bake tortillas and just used tortilla chips instead. Tastes great and saves a bunch of extra work.

text:
This was amazing!!!!  The picture doesn't do it justice! I discovered this recipe about 5 years ago and it has become a regular for us.  My family LOVES it!  They have 3 or 4 bowls.  Definitely use the crock pot.  I cook it on high for 4 hours ....  and I even add frozen chicken breasts at the beginning and it turns out fab.!   Just a note:  use GOOD quality enchilada sauce!   I also add olives (cause my family is nuts about olives) and a jalapeno to spice it up a bit.  We like spicey!  We also fry the tortilla strips (rather than bake them) for the topping (yellow corn tortillas).   When it is time to dish up, we also added a few more toppings to our bowl: mexican blend shredded cheese, diced avacado, the fried tortilla strips, and a splash of lime juice.  YUMO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!   FYI - is freezes beautifully ...... comes back to life, no problem!

When my mother was carrying me in her womb, Mexican food was always her treat & now I'm heavily addicted to Mexican food & I must say that this is easy, authentic and VERY delicious! Excellent soup...very easy and my fairly picky family loved it! I used the roasted chicken, but would try it with chicken breasts cooked right along with the soup next time. My family doesn't like corn, so I used a can of small white beans. The tortilla strips are so much better than bag tortilla chips...tossed them with a pinch of salt before baking. Make extra, because everyone picks at them before they go on the soup! I topped mine with sliced avocado and served with grilled cheese on a snowy day. Perfect!

text:
Awesome soup!  My husband loved it too!  I didn't have all of the ingredients on hand so I substituted a few things;  I used frozen lean ground beef  and broke it up about half way through cooking; instead of the enchilada sauce I used a jar of mild salsa and about a cup of strained tomatoes, roasted chipotle peppers in place of the chile's and I put in about a teaspoon of lemon juice.  I used other people's advice and used multigrain nachos.  I served it with a dollop of sour cream and Tex Mex grated cheese.  The mild salsa with the chipotle peppers gave it a sweet/hot flavour.  My husband had 2 bowls and then took it for lunch the next day!

text:
I was a little disappointed in this recipe.  It's okay as a base or starting point, but if you don't dress it up I think it's kind of bland.  I added 1/2 tsp more of cumin and chili powder and another tsp of salt and it was still flat.  I added the juice of 1 lime wedge, shredded colby and monterey jack cheese, and jalepeno cheddar tortilla strips to each bowl.  With the extras it was excellent.  Be advised if you make this recipe you better dress it up with something before you serve it.  And the recipe made as-is is not spicy at all, so if you like some heat you better add something for that also.

text:
This was the very first recipe I tried from this site. My mother requests it all the time. When I took a batch to work for a Black Friday potluck, my boss and two other coworders HUGGED me! (This experience also convinced me that I need a slow cooker with a locking lid, but that's another story.) My modifications: more broth instead of water, golden hominy, black beans and southwestern corn instead of frozen corn, no chicken (vegetarian), 1 tsp of cayenne for added flavor, and a dash of lime juice just before serving. I also dump a truly ridiculous amount of shredded cheese in my own bowlful.

text:
This was a wonderful base recipe from which I made more of a southwest style soup. I took advice from other  reviews and added black beans. (worth it!) I also added rice. (eh, so so). And Zuchini (mmmm buttery & spicy). A rotissere chicken from local mart shredded. (easy and good.) Be careful if you make the homemade strips. (They go from golden to oh #@*% quick). I used mexican style stewed canned tomato (easy/effective).  I garnished w/ fresh pico (hail the food processor) sour cream, fresh lime wedges, and avacado chunks. This recipe is a definate keeper either to use to the T or adapt your own querky spin off.

text:
We loved this at my house. Even my 2 and 5-year-old kids ate it! I put 2 uncooked chicken breasts in the slow cooker instead of cooked chicken and shredded it an hour before serving. For the liquid portion of the recipe I used all chicken broth except for 1 cup of water. I also rinsed a can of black beans and added them with the other ingredients. My tortilla strips didn't turn out well (maybe I didn't put enough oil on them) so I just used tortilla chips and that was easier and extremely tasty. Finally, we ate the soup with diced avocado, sharp cheddar cheese, and sour cream. I can't wait to eat leftovers!

text:
This was good.  I made it in my stock pot on the stove because I didn't start it until the afternoon.  It still came out fine, just simmered for a few hours.  I altered a few things just because of what I had on hand: I did not pre-cook the chicken, I took 2 large breasts, cut them into bit sized pieces and added them as called for (I would do the same in the crock pot too); I chopped up some banana peppers instead of the chopped chilis.  We'll keep this and I'll continue to make some changes here and there, all in all a good recipe.

text:
This soup was amazing!  It was a hit with my husband and kids too!  I did what other people said and to make it easy I just threw in 3 uncooked boneless, skinless chicken breasts.  When the soup was done I picked the breasts out with a fork, cut them into pieces and threw them back in.  I used 3 cans of chicken broth and no water.  I used a can of diced tomatoes instead of whole tomatoes.  I bought the pre-made tortilla strips from the store (Santa Fe Style) and otherwise everything else was the same.  I garnished with avocado, sour cream, grated chedder cheese and the tortilla strips.  Excellent and easy to do!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Incredibly easy to make. I was running really late and decided to make this quick recipe. Cleaning was easy because our pot was scraped-clean and my picky-eater (my husband) had 3 servings, and my two year old cleaned her own plate, twice! I used canned corn and packaged pre-cooked chicken and was amazed by the quality, the richness, and flavors. If you don't like thing to be too spicy, you can use less enchilada sauce (or buy a milder one), as well as use bell peppers versus spicy peppers, and don't use as much chili powder. It will definitely be one of our most used recipes.

text:
This was very easy to make but the heat and spices we so overwhelming I had to dilute it to make it edible.  My husband loves spicy food but this was over the top.  I followed the recipe exactly as stated so I don't know what went wrong.  I even made my own chicken stock for the base.  The only thing that saved it was adding some salt, more cilantro and lime juice to cut back on the heat.  Way too spicy for me and my daughter for sure.  I will not make this again.

text:
This soup was just what we were looking for on a cold winter day. I saw no reason to cook the chicken first so I took it out at the end and shredded it and put it back in. I think next time I will add more chicken and less water so it is a little thicker. I liked the idea od using enchilada sauce. Very flavorful. I did need to add a touch more salt to bring out the flavor. Could'nt have been easier. I will put the tortilla chips in the bowl first instead of on top. I think that will give it more tortilla flavor and a better texture. Will definitely make again.

text:
Ive been making this recipe for a couple of years now.  I've tweaked it a little and wanted to share.  Instead of using a bag of corn, I use one can of corn, one can of of a light bean and one can of a dark bean (usually black or dark kidney)  It is so versatile.  I add the chicken raw or even frozen and it breaks apart later in the day.  I only use bouillon and water and no salt.

text:
Amazing!! I doubled the recipe and there still wasn't any left.  Followed others suggestions and did not use any water, just chicken broth.  For a doubled recipe, I used 1 1/2 quarts total because we like our soup chunky.  I also added 1 large can of black beans (drained).   I made it with boneless chicken breasts and boneless thighs.  You can definitely put them in whole and shred them once they are fully cooked. This is a definite keeper.

Amazing!  I changed it just a bit.  I left the chicken raw and just diced it up finely.  They were so moist when the soup was done.  I used 2 boxes of broth instead of using water and broth.  I added green beans along with the corn for some extra veggies, and substituted a can of lightly drained diced tomatoes for the crushed tomatoes.  And finally, what made it perfect was adding a cup of cooked wild rice about 30 minutes before serving!  This soup was amazing! It's not very spicy, so don't be scared!

text:
I made this a few nights ago and it was delicious!!! I did use a 19oz can of enchilada sauce instead of 10oz, about 1.7 lbs of chicken, & the 2 cups of water I kept as is. I followed advice of another and used some corn starch at the end to thicken the soup. I made at least twice as many of the tortilla chips as we really loves these is the soup. put some chips & cheese in the bottom of a bowl, ladled the soup on top and put sour cream, more chips & lots more cheese for garnish & flavor. If you plan to use cheese & sour cream don't add too much corn starch since these will thicken the soup as well. An absolutely amazing soup, thanks!!!

text:

Then threw in a cup of raw brown rice and cooked another 2 hours.Omitted the corn and cilantro and we don't care for them and i thought it turned out excellent. Topped with tortilla chips and shredded cheese. Great left over too! Not too spicey. Kind of like a great new chicken soup!

text:
My family really enjoyed this soup. Great for a chilly Fall dinner.  I used uncooked boneless chicken thighs instead of breasts, a 15 oz. can of enchilada sauce, hot green chile peppers which added alot of heat, chicken broth(no H2O)and black beans. I also added a can of fire roasted tomatoes instead of whole tomatoes, for extra flavor. I served this with avocado, sour cream(a MUST to cool the heat from the peppers) and bagged tortilla chips which were perfect (and easy!) I would take other readers suggestions and add the corn closer to the end of cooking so it would retain its flavor. This is definitely a Keeper!!!

text:
This soup was phenomenal!  I used chicken broth and a little water (I didn't have quite enough broth to use all broth) and added some black beans too!  Like other reviewers, I put the chicken right in the crock pot instead of cooking beforehand and that worked great!  It didn't cook for long enough because of a power outage and still turned out wonderfully!  Edit: I've made this soup lots since my first review.  Since then, my husband and I have cut down the amount of meat we eat.  Usually I use less chicken and add a can of black beans to beef up the protein.  We love it that way!  We usually make some brown rice and serve this over rice!

text:
This recipe was excellent. When I first make a recipe, I follow the recipe exactly like it states,then when I make it again I make a few changes. The only  changes I made, I added 1 package of sazon by goya some adobo by goya, a can of rotels  (hot)diced tomatoes with chile , and a small 4 oz can of fire roasted green chile. You can find these items in the spanish aisle in your grocery store or any latin store. Next I prepared everything put it in the crock pot the night before, so that the uncooked chicken would marinate in the ingrediants. I also did what another person recommended and added black beans. When the soup was ready I garnished it  with fresh squeezed lime or lemon, sour cream, mild cheddar cheese, avacado slices and I bought a bag of tortilla chips by El Ranchero. Everyone enjoyed the recipe the original way I made it and the way I added ingrediants. Just your preferance

text:
I found this to be the best tortilla soup I have ever eaten!  Its easy and when it got to the table I used store bought tortilla strips for garnish and it was just as good as if you prepared them in the oven yourself.  You can't go wrong with this recipe and one more thing, I boiled chicken thighs the day before, skinned them and reserved the liquid, skimming off the fat the next morning before I put it into the pot.  I find this cut of chicken much more tasty than the breast, a lot more flavorful.  Ole!

text:
By far, the BEST chicken tortilla soup I have EVER had!!!  We ate it for dinner for 4 days, and loved it every time!!  I cooked it on the stove top, as it was a last-minute dinner decision, and it was still super easy.  I used frozen chicken breast tenders, slightly defrosted in the microwave, and they were falling apart in the soup in less than 15 minutes.  Added a can of black beans, and topped with sour cream, cheddar, and store-bought tortilla chips-- I will be making this weekly!  Thanks so much, Elena!!

text:
I bought my chicken from the deli at the grocery store. They shredded it for me right there.  Adding all the ingredients was no problem, just took a while.  I didn't see that a can of chicken broth was required, but luckily had an extra can on hand.  I followed the recipe exactly, not leaving anything out or adding extra (except for the baked tortilla strips).  I probably could have bought already mashed or sliced tomatoes instead of whole, but they were no problem to mash.  The soup turned out pretty good.  If I were to do it over again, I might add a spicy green chile mix, instead of mild, and maybe more chicken broth.  I ate it with whole wheat tortillas.  This is definitely a good crock recipe:)

text:
Great recipe; however, I did make some changes according to some reviews.  Good foundation though..better than any restaurant tortilla soup i've had.  I actually added 1/2 tablespoon of cumin; chili powder and salt.  I added approximately 4-5 tablespoons of chopped cilantro (i'm Hispanic so I love my spices)...I added 1 cup brown rice; 1/2 squash/zucchini; can of black beans.  I also topped with 2% shredded mexican cheese and diced avocado with squeeze of lime.  yum!!!  Both my husband and I Loved it!  We also had baked tortilla chips either on top or on the side.  We mixed all ingredients and brought to a boil and then we simmered for 30-45 minutes.  Perfect if you didn't get to do in the morning prior to leaving to work.  Thank you!

text:
This was delicious! But I'm only giving it 4 stars because of all the adjustments I made. I followed one suggestion and used frozen chicken breasts. That step made this incredibly easy recipe even easier! I omitted the water and used 2 cans of low sodium chicken broth. I added 1 can each of black, red, and pinto beans (drained and rinsed) to make it a heartier soup.  I also followed another suggestion and added finely crushed tortilla chips halfway through to make it thicker. The measurements for the spices I kept the same because the whole family likes spicy food. This soup also freezes really well. Thanks!

text:
So delicious!  I didn't use the crockpot, instead just did it on the stovetop and it was ready in less than an hour.  I sauted the onions and garlic in some olive oil and then cut up 3 boneless skinless chicken breasts into bite sized pieces and fried them until no longer pink and tossed everything into a stockpot to heat through. I also added some pinto beans and then served the soup over some rice (as suggested by another reviewer) and garnished with more cilantro and sour cream and added a bit of lime juice.  Great with the "hint of lime" tortilla chips!  Kids loved it too!

I have made this soup twice now and love it!  It's very healthy and super simple to make.  The best part about it is that I use frozen chicken breasts (we buy the large bags from Costco and always have them in the freezer). Display Name:
Erin

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We loved this soup!  I followed the recipe with these exceptions: instead of using water, I just added more chicken broth.  So I used 1 carton of broth (32 oz.) instead of 1 can of broth and 2 cups of water. Also, I only had a 28 oz. can of whole peeled tomatoes, so I just threw in the whole thing.  AND I had accidentally opened a can of crushed tomatoes at first, so I also threw in about half of that (14 oz.).  (I thought it was a LITTLE too thin before the crushed tomatoes and I think they did the trick.)  Also added 2 cans of black beans. I did make the corn tortilla strips - YUM!  Worth the trouble, IMO.  And really, they were so easy to make!  Here's the secret - use a pizza cutter to cut the strips - I cut the tortilla in half first, and then just zipped through cutting the strips - the pizza cutter made it EASY, EASY, EASY!!!  (Also, I lightly salted the strips before baking with Kosher salt.) I did cook brown rice as some suggested and added a scoop of cooked rice to each bowl, pouring the soup over the rice. Finally, I served it with the following toppings: sour cream, sliced avocado, shredded cheese, and of course the tortilla strips.  I will definately make this again!

text:
I made a couple of changes which I felt saved this soup (hence the 4 stars instead of 5): 1) DO NOT add water.  I used another can of chicken broth - can't imagine how bland this would have been with water; 2) at the end I added the juice of 1 lime (next time I might use 2).  These two things gave it a lot more flavor. I also used 7oz of green chiles just because that was the size I had on hand.  Next time, I will add some jalapenos or something to make it just a bit more spicy. It was very good after these changes.

I really loved this soup.  It was really easy, especially since I followed some of the other reviews and put a couple of frozen chicken breasts in with the other ingredients.  How much easier can it get?  The only change I made was to put an entire quart of chicken broth and omitted the water.  I think it would probably be fine the way the recipe was written too... We topped with sour cream, avocado, mexican shredded cheese and store bought tortilla chips....really yummy and makes great leftovers!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/352823.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best tortilla soup recipe I have tried and I've tried MANY looking for that perfect blend of ingredients. I think the Enchilada sauce really makes it work.  I followed the recipe with the exception of adding some thickener toward the last hour of cooking.  I found it too thin in consistency.  I mixed some regular flour and corn meal together and added water.  Cooked this in the microwave just long enough to get the mixture to a wet but pasty consistency.  It mellowed the taste of the soup and thickened it nicely.  I followed the advice of others and cooked the chicken breasts in the soup and shredded it. The flavors really melded into the chicken breasts very well and the chicken was easy to shred.  This I will definitely make again!!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This soup is  FABULOUS.  Being from Canada,  I had never even heard of this soup.  After I tried it on one of my US travels I was hooked and set out to find a recipe that lived up to the good hotel version.     I have tried others on this site but this one is the best by far.  The enchilada sauce makes it, as well as the canned green chilies. (Do not substitute- I tried a packet of taco mix once instead of enchilada sauce, and it was terrible- right into the bin.)I use chicken stock in a box, and don't forget tortilla chips and shredded nacho cheese to finish - it gives it the needed "body". A sour cream dollop on top, then sprinkle with some fresh cilantro (I love that stuff).   Best use of a slow cooker I have found....yummm.

This is probably the best recipe I've tried in several years of recipes from this site. I really can't say enough wonderful things about it....it tastes amazing, and even more amazing the next day. It's easy to put together, most of it comes out of cans. The recipe calls for slow cooker, but I've also made it stove-top when in a hurry, and it's honestly just as good. The only thing I do differently is I use prepared tortilla chips and crumble them on top of soup, along with a sprinkling of cheese. My kids, my hubby and my friends all love this soup (me, too!).

I have altered it slightly by using a costco precooked chicken, carrots, celery, black beans and two cans of chicken broth (no water). I look in the pantry to see what kind of tomatoes I have on hand and use 1/2 tsp of cummin (because of the little ones) and skip the chilli pepper. It has a mild enough spice and I put hot sauce on the table for anyone needing more kick. I have served it to guests and it has always been a winner. THANK YOU!

city:

country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  First of all you do NOT need a slow cooker for this.  It is kind of a heat and serve deal.  I used the 32 oz can of chicken broth and 2 cans of rotel.  You dont need extra salsa and because i didnt use water there was no need to cook in the slow cooker or boil for long periods of time to "reduce" the broth.  Didnt have fresh cilantro cuz the store was out, so I used dried instead.  Also added black beans in addition to the corn.  End result was very tasty, filling and quite spicy (due to the hot rotel).  I like spicy though.  I topped with sour cream and cheese which helped to simmer down the heat.  Skipped the onion since I was feeling lazy and didnt feel like the soup truly needed it.  Enjoy!

We loved this recipe! I was dying to have Chicken Tortilla Soup (something like Max & Erma's) without a lot of work and this turned out to be perfect! So delicious!  I used about 1.5 lb. of chicken (just my pref). I did not cook it first to save a step and the chicken was fall apart tender. text:
I was pleasantly surprised how easy this recipe was yet super delicious!  I followed several suggestions from other reviewers.  Definitely use 3 chicken breasts (yes, throw them in frozen with everything else and shred them right before serving...falls apart with no problem).  I used a 28 oz can of diced tomatoes with green chilies included; therefore, eliminating the 4 oz can of green chilies.  Also, I eliminated the water and used a 32 oz box of reduced sodium chicken broth.  I really liked the black beans suggestion as well.  Topped with sour cream, tortilla strips (local grocery might already sell these), and shredded cheese (Mexican blend) makes this soup a yummy dinner!

text:
This by far the best soup I've ever had. This recipe is a great base to add you own taste to. I how ever don't use the slow cooker I have made my own stock with a small chicken with the usual carrots, celery, and onions and I've also took a shortcut and used one of those great already roasted chickens and canned broth. Is just as great either way. I like to add carrots, blackbeans and I always top each bowl with avacado chunks with fresh lime juice and ofcourse the tortilla strips. I make mine by cutting corn tortilla into strips and fry them in a sauce pan in an inch or so of canola oil and salt them as I lay them on paper towel to drain. My family loves these. I'm sure baking them saves calories I'll have to try it sometime. Thanks for the great recipe.

This was really good. I didn't do this in the slow cooker, and don't see why you have to...I cooked the chicken ahead and in this way made my own broth, so that saved some money there and tasted better too (also had extra broth for another recipe). I used more of my homemade broth and cut the water to one cup.
I used the vegetable oil spray on the tortilla strips and they came out great.
Only regrets - forgot to buy avocado/lime and that's such a delicious garnish to have one this. Additionally, I added red pepper to spice it up more and made it a little too spicy.

text:
Really good soup and so easy! Some modifications I made:
1. Used only chicken broth, no water. Added a cup extra.
2. Doubled the chili powder. 
3. Omitted the onions, substituted with onion powder
4. Put the chicken breasts in frozen and cut them up later after they were cooked.
5. Used corn tortilla chips (broken up) instead of actually baking tortillas.

Definitely good stuff. I think next time I'll add some more vegetables, maybe zucchini and carrots.

I make this every fall, as soon as the weather turns chilly. I love to put this in the cooker before I leave, to then come home to the savory smell of this soup cooking. So cozy! text:
This recipe is delicious, but the best part is how quick and easy the preparation is (5-10 minutes!). I took the advice of several other reviewers and did not cook the chicken prior to putting it in the slow cooker, and it was beautifully cooked, tender and moist, when I got home from work. I also added a can of black beans to make it a little heartier. Otherwise, followed the recipe to the letter. Some of the best tortilla soup I've ever had. I served it with avocado slices, sour cream, cheddar, and cilantro sprinkled on top, and chips on the side for scooping it out of the bowl. It was a big hit with my family. This is a perfect recipe for a busy mom (or dad)!

text:
I love this recipe. So Quick, So Easy. Good for a chilly day outside during the work week. I also made my own changes to suit my families taste. 

I included 1 big can of Crushed tomatoes, a can and a half of chicken stock and Jalapenos right from the beginning. I cook the chicken right in the soup (like others suggested) and take it out an hour or so before we're ready to eat to shred it. After shredding I throw the chicken back in and mix it well. This time I also decided to add in some Bell Peppers when I put the chicken back in to add some crunch and tang. I top it with Cheddar cheese, Sour Cream and Crushed up tortilla Chips. 

So Good. My Family Loves it!

This is a fantastic recipe- simple, inexpensive, and healthy! It's a lot easier and less time-consuming!

city:

country:

text:
I made this last night and it was very easy.  I used the recipe spices as stated but replaced a couple ing. with suggestions.  I used cubed (not shredded) raw chicken breasts (raw not frozen), canned sweet corn (not frozen), 100% fat free less sodium chicken broth, did not add water, and mexican mild rotel (instead of green peppers and crushed tomatoes).  There was more than enough liquid from the broth and sauce to make a soup that I'm glad I eliminated the water. I also made and topped with the homemade tortilla strips but used whole wheat tortillas and Pam spray olive oil - they took a little longer to cook then stated (added 10 minutes) but I wanted them very crispy.  I cooked all the ing. together for 3 hours on high and it was plenty done.  We added a scoop of steamed brown rice to each bowl for more substinence, as we were eating this as an entree.  Also topped it off with low fat cheese and lite sour cream.  My changes were to make the recipe as healthy as possible  while not losing the flavor.  It turned out amazing and will now be a staple in our house. One bowl filled me up!  The leftovers were great the next day.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-05-19T11:18:01.3
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1979510
Display Name:
Michelle
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
21
favoritesCount:
79
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE good meals that are easy to make, and this one tops the list. I've adapted this one to suit my personal taste and it's just tasty, warming, and comforting. I throw in frozen, whole chicken breasts, make sure they're completely covered with the liquid, and when the soup is done I take a minute to shred the chicken with two forks - SO EASY. I leave out the chiles and cilantro (I'm a wimp when it comes to spice) and I substitute tomato sauce or paste for the whole tomatoes, depending on how thick I want it - paste will make it thicker while sauce will keep it soupy. I also add lime juice, a can of chili beans (with the sauce), and a can of drained and rinsed black beans. I use all chicken broth instead of broth and water. Like other users, we've found that just using tortilla chips is an easy way to go - and the lime flavored tortilla chips are extra tasty. I top it with sour cream and shredded Mexican cheese blend. This is my go-to meal when I can't think of what else to make, and is good with beef, too!

This recipe is GREAT!! I'd never made this soup before and tried it and am sooo pleased!! This is the best slow cooker soup recipe ever. text:
I grew up in Texas and Santa Fe, and this recipe had the heat and flavor I look for in tortilla soup. I used all broth instead of the water, a little less corn, added black beans, used spicy Hatch enchilada sauce (you could make your own pretty easily, though), a can of spicy diced tomatoes and doubled the chili powder and cumin. Topped with some sour cream, diced avacado and cilantro, it was very satisfying. The chicken shreds easily w/ 2 forks at the end of cooking time. Use boneless thighs for extra flavor.

text:
1. Use a few (I used 4 small) frozen chicken breasts. Before serving, pull out the chicken breast and pull the meat apart to shred. Put the chicken back in and it's ready to eat. 2. use chicken broth instead of water (more flavor) 3. add lime juice 4. add a can of black beans 5. I didn't go through the trouble of making the tortilla strips. 6. I didn't have chopped green chile peppers and it was still good. This recipe is super good and you don't really have to follow it to the T to have an awesome soup. Thanks!!

text:
To be completely honest, the soup tasted and looked like veggie soup with chicken in it when I got home after cooking for 8 hours. I was so dissapointed. So I went to the store, bought some light cream, black beans and tortilla chips and add them to the soup to cook for another hour or so. I only added about 1/2 cup of the cream and maybe 1/4 bag of crushed chips- which gave the soup that "tortilla style" consistancy that we're all looking for. Ended up being delicious..I would highly recommend trying it that way. Garnished with fresh avocado and low fat Cheddar...was a huge hit. I will def make it again that way.

text:
This soup is incredible. I did not add any water, all broth. I also added frozen chicken breast, and shredded it after 4 hours on high. I did not use green chili's, and by accident i read red pepper, instead of chili powder, but only added 1/2-3/4 of a tsp. You must make the homemade strips. They are the essence of the soup, and absorb the flavor when dipped, without getting soggy.( It is not called chicken tostito's corn chip soup!) I did make about extra tortillas in the oven, and added cheese to about half. My husband and I both thought it was perfect! Just added shredded cheese for a little thickening. My husband and I loved it !!!!!

Display Name:
WSBLEND

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1095333.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
very good....I left out the corn...used one box (I think it's like 4 cups) of chicken broth and NO water.  I used one of those precooked chickens you get in the grocery store deli section....just picked the meat off the bones.  I have a special way I like to make toritlla strips.....get a stack of about 7-8 small corn tortillas....starting on one edge, slice them into very thin (no bigger than 1/4 inch wide) strips....then fry them in hot oil in batches till just brown (watch them closely b/c they can go from light brown to BURNT TO A CRISP very quickly)...drain on paper towels.  They are extra crunchy and good to just nibble on too.

text:
My earlier review of this recipe was that it was so easy, I made in my living room because my kitchen was being renovated.  I wish to add a couple of other suggestions.  1) I added frozen boneless skinless chicken tenders rather than cooked chicken. 2) I added a jar of salsa con queso and about a 1/4 cup of half and half to give it added richness and thickness. 3) THIS SOUP FREEZES EXTREMELY WELL!!!  I just reheated it on low in my crockpot all over again.  It tastes even better the second time around.  The whole time I'm at work eating this I'm saying "darn, I should have brought more in."  So I'm going to have it for dinner.  Once again, thanks for the absolute best soup EVER!!!

We thought this recipe was lacking in flavor. It did have a lot of heat to it from the chili powder. We added extra cilantro, 2 teaspoons of dried oregano, a can of black beans, cheddar cheese, and sour cream. After the additions, it was more to our liking. Seems like a recipe you can accommodate to your own tastes. Next time I would substitute chicken broth in place of the water; the soup tasted too watered down to us.

text:
This turned out pretty well but I don't think I cared for it as much as tons of other reviewers.  I recommend cutting down on the amount of onion.  Half an onion would be plenty.  I pureed my tomotoes so it would be more appealing to the kids.  I added black beans but I think pinto would be a nice addition as well.  I replaced the water with chicken broth for more flavor.  I took the advice of others and cooked the whole boneless chicken breasts in the liquids till the end.  I then cut it up into small pieces.  It didn't seem meaty enough so next time I will cut the meat into larger chunks.  It just seemed too brothy at the end so I added a little cornstarch mixed with water to thicken it up a bit.  That definitely helped but something still seemed to be lacking.  My husband and one of my sons enjoyed it but my other 2 didn't care for it.

text:
Perfect!  I threw in 4 frozen chicken breast halves with all the ingredients and removed to shred and replaced to continue cooking.  The breast were so tender they just fell apart and gave th soup a great texture.  I used an extra can of broth instead of the water, used canned corn instead of frozen and just put it in when I replaced the shredded chicken.  I used a medium enchilada sauce so I left out the cumin and chili powder.  Husband doesn't like spicy food so I just added a little zip to mine own bowl.  I used Tostitos tortillas chips instead of makin my own strips and it was yummy.  Also added some sour cream, fresh cilantro and some sharp cheddar cheese.  Froze the left over and it made another meal.  This is a monthly at our house now!!!!

text:
This was the best soup EVER.  This soup was to be made for a church function.  My boys got sick so we stayed home.  We enjoyed the whole crock pot of it.  
I followed the recipe pretty much as it showed. I boiled the chicken first and then shredded the chicken and used 5 pieces of chicken to make more.  I also used more frozen corn and a slightly larger can of enchilada sauce.  The chili pepper was a hotter chili pepper.  The recipe was delicious.  As the previous post said, I think I will use more chicken stock instead of water.  But, it was fine the way it was so if I don't have extra chicken stock I wll make it the exact same way next time.  I used corn tortillas and it was great.  I cooked the corn tortillas at 350 for like 9  minutes.  
This is definetely a recipe to try out on a cold night.  Enjoy it like we did

I would definitely make this soup again!  I made a few alterations to the recipe, as other reviewers suggested.  First, I added a can of black beans (rinsed).  Then, instead of using water, I used a 12 oz. can of enchilada sauce and about 3/4 of a can of chicken broth.  The soup wasn't too "soupy" and tasted great.  Buying a can of diced tomatoes with the peppers already in them was a nice time saver.  This was so easy and ended up tasting so good!

text:
This is awesome. I ditched the bay leaf and half of the cumin and it still had a good flavor... and it's super easy to make! I used frozen chicken and it shredded right up with a fork after a few hours. If you make the tortilla strips, be sure not to use cooking spray... I did that on my second batch and it tasted putrid, but the veggie oil works great. Also you only need to put the tortilla strips in there for like 8 minutes, 15 would probably be a little too crispy! I think it adds something to the presentation and is better than plain old corn chips. I'll definitely make this many times again - yum!

I followed the advice given by others and poached raw chicken breasts in chicken broth (rather than water), a 12 oz can of tomatoes, 1/2 can of hot enchilada sauce and 2 cans of the green chilies. I added shredded cheese to each bowl before serving and made my own tortilla strips. It ended being a really good hearty meal that everyone enjoyed.

text:
This soup is in regular rotation at our house....it's easy, healthy and everyone loves it. The only real change I make is to add the juice of 2 key limes (limones), and the final result is very similar to the sopa de tortilla that I ate frequently while living in Mexico. 

While the soup is easily a meal all by itself, I often accompany it with store bought taquitos, and combined, it's an easy after work meal that lasts our family of 4 for 2 nights.

Delicious!!!

This was a great tortilla soup and pretty quick prep time.

I did replace the water with chicken broth, placed frozen chicken breasts directly in the slow cooker with the other ingredients and then pulled it out and shredded it and put it back in and used tortilla chips instead of making my own.

I also started later in the day and so cooked on high for about 4 hours instead of on low for 8.

A couple of friends and I ate almost all of it that night.  Really good soup, especially if it's cold and rainy outside.

text:
I made a Chick. Tort. Soup another time and it went poorly, I was apprehensive about this but time was short & the day was HECTIC and hubby WANTED soup!  SO, I started this recipe at noon & it was done (at high) at 4, I just shredded the chicken breasts (I used three) up right before serving, topping with restaurant style corn chips, crushed, and mexican-style cheese.  My husband smelled it, said (as always), "this better be good!" and then wolfed down two heaping bowls full!  He told me that night that this was EXCELLENT soup, like he would expect from a restaurant!!  Super meal, low-fat and SO good!  Thank you!  (Makes loads of soup, too!  Get ready to freeze some & use some for left-overs for lunch, tomorrow!)  My 2 yr.old loved it, 4 yr. old didn't, 7 yr.old ate all & no complaints, and 11 year old LOVED it!  I did, too.  I'm keeping this one!

text:
This was a super easy soup to make.  I love how you can just put everything into the crock pot and go.  I made a few adjustments: added creamed corn instead of frozen, added black beans, and topped it with cheese, sour cream, and green onions.  I also boiled the chicken in cayenne, cumin, and coriander.  I used the water the chicken was boiled in, in place of the two cups of water.  Make sure to really toast the tortillas or else they are too chewy.  I will definitely be making this again, thanks.

text:
I adore this recipe!  My husband says it is "restaurant quality."  Unless you are going to serve all the soup at once, you can cut down on the tortillas you cook up.  I figure one tortilla per bowl of soup.  Then I just make more as we eat the leftovers.  I make a couple minor changes on the posted recipe when I make it.  They are: I only use 1/4 a can of chiles, I use 1 can of corn instead of frozen corn, and I use petitie diced tomatos in stead of mashing whole tomatoes.

text:
I LOVED THIS SOUP
I HAVE HAD 3rds tonight
Some changes I made
-I didnt have time for the slow cooker so I simmered it for about 45 minutes
(i put everything in a pot to simmer while the chix poached & then I had to shred)
-I poached the chicken in broth before I shredded it
-I added 1 1/2 cups of celery
         1 cup carrots
         2 cups zuchinni 
that made it more stew like them soup like but it was a great way to get some extra veggies in and to use them up before they went bad. 
-crunched up store bought tortilla chips for the top instead of corn tortillas
-omitted the corn because I forgot to buy it
A local restaurant makes the exact soup on their menue with all the veggies I am sure of it.
next time a bit more broth to make it a bit more soupy and some avocado on top as well
MAKE THIS SOUP TODAY!

None
text:
This soup is awesome!  I did not cook the chicken breasts before adding them to the pot and they cooked thoroughly and shredded easily. I used diced tomatoes w/ green chilies in place of the whole tomatoes because that's what I had on hand. I cut back on the onions and used a little less than half of the chili powder and omitted the green chilies entirely (because of the kids)  To compensate, I  used 4 cloves of minced garlic and a bit more cumin.  It still had a little kick but everyone enjoyed it.  This one's a keeper!

text:
Loved this soup. So easy to make. Will be on our regular dinner menu.  Prep shredded chicken in slow cooker before making recipe. Place raw chicken, taco seasoning and quart of  chicken stock in slow cooker and set on 4 hour high setting. Once cooked, shred chicken in slow cooker and add tortilla soup ingredients and cook for additional 8-10 hours on low. One pot dinner. Delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this recipe - tastes similar to Saltgrass Steak House's Chicken Tortilla Soup.  Only a few adjustments:
* Used raw skinless boneless chicken breasts - cooked on high to a temp of 170 degrees before shredding the chicken and lowering the heat.
* Used Ro-Tel diced tomatoes and mild green chiles instead of the whole peeled tomatoes.
* Used a 32 oz carton of reduced sodium chicken broth in addition to the 2 c water.
* Added 1 c converted long grain white rice (cook on high) 30-60 minutes before serving.

Made this as written and it is fantastic. It's super forgiving too, if you like more tomatoes, add them.  We like black beans, so we throw those in there too. I also like to throw in some Basmati rice also. You just have to top this soup with some shredded cheese and sour cream, it just makes it creamy and takes it over the top. It's just so good. The kids all like it and so does the husband and he is picky about all his Mexican food. It's a winner and in my permanent rotation.

text:
Made this recipe at 6am this morning:  Nevermind using cooked chicken.  It’s going in the crockpot anyway.  Put your boneless chicken breasts in the crockpot uncooked, pull the chicken 30 minutes before the time is up and put it back in and stir.  Also if you’re not a fan of spicy, omit the cumin and replace it with maple smokehouse seasoning.  The soup was super delicious.  And by the way, you can buy tortilla strips if you don’t have time to make your own.

text:
Very good recipe. I was happy with end results. My husband, who never really compliments anyone's cooking, said it was really good. That is saying something!

It Only took 15 mins to throw everything in crock pot. I left my chicken breast whole and just cooked it in crock with everything else. I shredded at the end. I topped mine with Lime juice, sour cream, and monterey jack cheese. I cooked mine on low 6 hrs and it was perfectly done. The Chicken was easy to shred.

The Corn Tortilla Strips burned the first time I made them according to directions. I suggest testing one in your oven to see how it does before ruining a whole batch. Mine browned and got crispy in about half the time...7 mins.

text:
I made this recipe and it turned out great, but I made a couple of great enhancements.  I had fresh boneless/skinless chicken breasts so I boiled them in water with salt, pepper, garlic and onion powder to kill two birds with one stone. Cooked shredded chicken with homemade chicken broth. Used the broth from the fresh chicken in the recipe instead of store bought. I also added green onions, green and red peppers to give it more flavor. Btw - I did this over the stove. Just bring everything to a boil and let simmer for 20 minutes. Everything is already cooked...no need to wait 3-4 hours for this goodness!  Garnished with shredded colby and cheddar cheese, sour cream and lime juice. Devine!!!

text:
This was such a hit with my family. We loved it. It was so simple to make, that part I loved.  The things I changed were adding the shredded chicken at the end, just to warm through. It seems to me when you add already cooked chicken to the slow cooker at the beginning, it gets so overdone and dried out. This way the chicken is still moist. I also added a 14.5 oz  can of Rotel tomatoes. We topped the soup with chopped avocado, tortilla chips, cilantro, sliced radishes and cheddar cheese. I'll definitely make this again. YUMMMM!
Thank you so much for sharing the recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, so I didn't plan too well.   I did this on a Sunday when I had some time.  I had a pound and a half of boneless, skinless chick thighs that I browned (not cooked through) and added them to the cooking liquids instead of the pre-shedded chicken.  I also used a half can each of mild and spicy enchilada sauce because that is what I had leftover in the freezer.

Set the Crock-Pot on low for 3hrs, took the thighs out, fork shredded them and put it back in the pot for another hour on low.   I also cut up some corn tortillas and fried them to top off the soup.  A dollop sour cream, sprinkling of cheese, some diced avocados and a squirt of lime.....oh man!!!   My picky husband LOVED it!  Said it's the best winter time you he's ever had.

Definitely going into the "make again" file!

Display Name:
Allison Jefferson

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4184473.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loved this recipe.  I made a few changes based on the reviews that I read.  I had some fresh tomatoes that I needed to use so I chopped those up and added them along with frozen chicken thighs, some black beans, two chicken Maggi boullion rectangles, 4 cups of water, and the rest of the ingredient list (sans the frozen corn because I didn't have any). I cooked it on high in the crockpot for 2 hours then removed the chicken to cool a bit so I could shred it.  I then used my emulsifier and blended the soup right in the crockpot.  I was worried that it was looking too thin but when I put the shredded chicken back in it was excellent!  I added white beans and the liquid from their jar and one cut up red pepper. 
It cooked another hour.  It was amazing!  It was served with shredded cheddar cheese, green onion, fresh lime juice (a must!), and cilantro.  We added a bit more salt and pepper per person based on preference.  I will definitely make this again!

Loved the amazing flavors in this soup!  I was a huge hit at a party I brought it to.  I listened to some of the other reviewers and put semi-defrosted chicken breasts in and cooked on high for 3-4 hours.  After 3.5 hours when I went to shred the chicken, it wasn’t quite done so i pulled the breasts out and poached them for about 15 minutes in some of the soup in a separate pan until they were cooked through. I followed the recipe otherwise.

text:
I've made several different versions of chicken tortilla soup and this was the best one by a long shot. I think it has to do with using the enchilada sauce. I used the red sauce, not green. Definitely tasted like something from a restaurant...maybe better!
A few modifications:
I used 3 large chicken breasts and just shredded at the end. I didn't have frozen corn so I added a can of drained corn at the end as well. I didn't use cilantro and bought tortilla chips and just broke them into pieces for topping. Also used shredded cheese, sour cream and avocado as topping options.
Delicious! Everyone raved about it.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy to do in Instant Pot!  Awesome recipe! I’ve made it before in my slow cooker and I loved it. Now I have an Instant Pot pressure cooker, so I put everything in at the same time (chicken breasts whole, uncooked). When the pot came to pressure, set time for 10 minutes, natural release. I then remove the breasts and shred them with my hand mixer in less than a minute, return to IP, and dinner is ready in about 30 minutes.

text:
I used 946mL of no salt added chicken  broth instead of  just water ad the broth, diced tomatoes instead of whole tomatoes, green pepper, and an extra clove of garlice because I like the flavour it adds. I also added a bit more chicke than the recipe calls for, approximately 700g. I added some more corn and didn't add any extra salt, but more pepper. It turned out amazingly flavourful and hearty, there was a really good broth to solids ratio. As well, I made quesadillas with the corn tortillas, just with cheese and some green onion and dipped them in as a side instead of having them on top, and it was to die for. I would definitely make this again.

text:
It's delicious. I've made this twice, first time using Ortega. This time, I used a can of Hatch chilies marked mild. I had NO idea these would be blasting hot - I'd not tried them before. I had to toss the whole batch, sadly.  So...if you don't like blasting heat in your soup - beware. I'll definitely make this again, but I learned my lesson to not try something new unless I know what it will be. **Have also made this using a can of Hormel no-beans chili once since I didn't have a can of enchilada sauce on hand. Also good.

text:
I loved this soup! It was super easy to make! I pretty much followed the direction. But I also added a can of drained black beans, added a 28 oz can of whole peeled tomatoes & 10 oz can of green chilies instead of smaller size cans. I like chunker soups. I also put in a pound of frozen chicken breast and let them cook with the soup and shredded when we were ready to eat. I think you could even do a 1.5 pds of chicken for a thicker soup. This recipe is very versatile, you can do many changes based on your liking and taste preference.. Great base recipe! This is one of the best recipes I've found in a while. Thanks!

userID:
14138254
Display Name:
Kboy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
5
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is really good and really easy to make. I usually make base of the soup the night before and keep it in the fridge overnight to let the flavors marry a bit. You can throw in the chicken in the morning, it isn't necessary to shred the chicken beforehand. You can even throw in frozen chicken breasts. I used the Verde enchilada sauce instead of the regular sauce.  My mother doesn't like onions,so I substituted onion powder and minced onion. I also used garlic powder instead of fresh garlic, and left the parsley out. I added black beans as well. I cooked it on low for about 6 hours, and had my mom stir it a few times during the day. I took the chicken out of the pot, it was extremely tender and very easy to shred with a fork and a knife. I dumped the chicken back in, stirred it up and served it with sides of cheddar cheese, tortilla chips, and sour cream as optional toppings,as well as hot sauce for those that prefer a little heat. The soup is great for chilly days, and only gets better after a day or two in the fridge.
Review:

4

userID:
22545157
Display Name:
Mallycatstrike
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Four stars for the base ingredients. A great recipe to play off of. I am one of the most impatient and hangry people of all time, and was craving a good tortilla soup recipe. I made this meal in about 30-40 mins. I used all the can ingredients, 3 big pressed garlic pieces, the corn, plus one more can of chicken broth and a can of black beans. I combined all the ingredients into a large pot and set them on high. I added rotisserie chicken (shredded), 3/4ths of an onion, and a batch of chopped cilantro. I then added garlic powder, chili powder, cumin, cayenne, pepper, extra salt (to taste), and a big spoon of sour cream (for thickness). I DID NOT add water. I stirred everything together while my two corn tortillas baked (400 degrees, lightly rubbed with vegetable oil on both sides) and once they were done, turned off the heat. I put the soup in a bowl, added shredded mozzarella cheese, and the tortillas. Incredibly good and will last for a few days!

My only complaint is I had a LOT of fluid. So much so we ate and we're able to add chicken to the rest and make a 2nd batch the next day. I'll cut back on that next time. I'll definitely make it again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is wonderful! I have a couple of tips. #1 if you don't have shredded, cooked chicken, you can brown a couple of large chicken breasts in olive oil, and throw them in. A few hours later, fish them out and shred using 2 forks, and return to the pot. #2 A cup of cooked black beans is a good addition! #3 As others have said you don't need to add enchilada sauce, which is just more tomato and spices. Just up the garlic and maybe add a poblano or other fresh pepper, to taste. This is a flexible recipe, or delicious as written, and has become one of my go-to dinners!

Display Name:
nkpug

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3699716.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is delicious!!!  Everyone loves it!  I make it plant strong by replacing the chicken with pinto, red, kidney or cannellini beans and the chicken broth with vegetable.  I also like to replace the water with more broth.  I use whatever frozen veggies I happen to have -  we actually love using a broccoli/cauliflower/carrot mix in addition to the corn.  I've even used green enchilada sauce in a pinch and it was still delicious.  For those who do not like spicy food use mild enchilada sauce, mild green chilis or eliminate altogether, and skip the chili powder.  It's still very flavorful.  Top with a little lime juice and chopped avocado - WOW!!

None
text:
Love this recipe! Easy, tasty, and loved by everyone that tries it. I always double the recipe to freeze container for later.  I wouldn't change a thing with the recipe provided.  My only recommendation is to use split chicken breast with the skin on and not boneless, skinless chicken breast.  I usually boil the chicken beforehand and use this water for the soup.  The small amount of fat from the skin and meat adds more flavor to the soup.  I would highly recommend this recipe for all soup lovers!

text:
This is a VERY good chicken tortilla soup recipe and will be added to my typical rotation.  I did not cook the chicken ahead of time.  Instead, I cut up the chicken into smaller pieces to have the flavor cook through, and shredded the chicken about an hour before serving.  Great with a bit of lime, sour cream, and cheese on top.

Also, the amount of cilantro is no issue for those who think it tastes like soap.  Highly recommend with a corn and black bean salad with chipotle ranch dressing.

text:
I had made my own chicken stock by simmering the chicken bones, celery, cilantro stems and onion for about 40 minutes and then added salt. I added more of the spices to the soup, 2 teaspoons of Worcestershire sauce and a can of black beans. Due to lack of time, instead of using the Crock-Pot, I just sauteed the onion and garlic, added the rest of the ingredients and let it all simmer on the stove for about 20-30 minutes.

text:
This is my go to Chicken Soup recipe, especially when me or someone in my family is sick with a cold or allergies. It has a way of helping you breathe, as well as tasting so good. I do change a few things though. I like less of the tomato taste, so I add very little crushed tomatoes. If any at all. I do however add 1 can of rotel, and 3 small cans of green chiles.  I also use mostly chicken broth and very little water. Throw in some Black Beans and it's good to go for me! This recipe by itself is wonderful and a uniform recipe for tweaking.

Display Name:
ILoveToEatSouthernFoods

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1283255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was easy and great tasting, but I did switch up some things. I doubled the amount of corn, I used two cans of rotel (tomato and green chile blend), one 4oz can of diced green chiles, half an onion, and rice. I cooked the cilantro and green onion in with everything instead of waiting till the end. Also, I put the uncooked chicken in the crockpot in the beginning, but after about 4-6 hours into everything cooking that's when I shredded the chicken. I minimized the amount of water, and used both chicken AND veggie broth. 

The tortilla strips were made by cutting corn tortillas into strips, frying them, and lightly sprinkling them with salt. 
I topped the soup off with sour cream, avocado chunks, sharp cheddar cheese, and a crisp lime. 

TO. DIE. FOR. !!!!

text:
Will definitely make this again!  My adjustments:  took advice in other reviews and put two raw chicken breasts in the bottom of the crock pot, and shredded on a plate with two forks then added back to soup.  Instead of whole tomatoes, I used diced.  Increased garlic to 4 cloves, used 1 cup water, 2 cups of chicken broth.  Instead of frozen corn, I used a can of the "mexi" corn (corn with red & green peppers).  I did not add any salt (I figured between the broth and enchilada sauce, it wouldn't need any).  I also used medium spicy enchilada sauce, it gave it just enough kick that me and my family like.

Loved it.  Made a few minor modifications; used 2 cans of diced tomatoes with chilies (instead of 1 can of tomatoes and 1 can of chillies), used 1/2 the recommended amount of salt (really glad I did that), used 3.5 cups of stock and 1 cup of water (I wanted more broth for a soup instead of a stew), added a can of drained/rinsed black beans, and threw two chicken breasts in and cooked them with the soup then pulled them out, shredded and added back in.  Healthy, spicy, easy to make.  Definitely doing this one again.

text:
This was very good, but I think if you are using frozen chicken breasts you need to cook it for 7-8 hours otherwise it takes a lot longer for it to heat up.  I cooked this on high for 4 hours and the onion was very crunchy and I don’t like crunchy onions in my soup.  After cooking on high for about 6 hours, the onions finally softened and the flavors in the soup came out better. I did substitute a 14.5 oz can of chicken broth for the 2 cups of water and used a can of diced tomatoes instead of stewed tomatoes.  My husband and I both really liked this and I’ll be making it again, but probably sticking to cooking it for 6-7 hours,

text:
The soup turned out good.  I read some of the other reviews and took their advice and replaced the water for more chicken broth, I added 1 can of black beans, I replaced the whole, mashed tomatoes with 1 can of spicy Rotel, and I placed 3 raw skinless, boneless chicken breasts into the Crockpot and shredded it 5 hours in.

Next time, I will make a few modifications:
-Since I'm not a huge onion fan, I will likely only use half of an onion.
-I would add 1 more can of black beans (or another bean type to add more color and variety).
-I would also add some rice.   I love hearty soups.
-I may follow the original recipe and season/cook the chicken separately for additional flavor.  I may even play with using chicken thighs instead of breasts.

Display Name:
Kiri Korycinski

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3301814.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quick and delicious!

And since I can't make a recipe without making changes:
I put two bone-in (with skin for flavor!) chicken breasts in a pot with all of the ingredients.  Added one can of drained and rinsed black beans and an ear of corn and omitted the salt.

When I first taste tested it, it tasted very strongly of the enchilada sauce, which I wasn't a fan of.  I diluted it with some water and everything came out great! The first time I made this recipe, I took the soup off of the heat and stirred in some sour cream to add a little richness.  It's fine either way!

I let it simmer for about 1.5 hours, shredded the chicken, threw it back in the pot and everything was fabulous!

Pro-tip:  If you're a fan of boneless, skinless chicken breasts, use bone-in and skinned for soups...all the flavor and none of the bones or skin once it's shredded.  Also, waaaay cheaper!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-08-11T14:32:36.27
helpfulCount:

text:
My only complaint about this recipe is that we rarely have leftovers of this soup!  :)  To please the various palates and texture issues we have in our family, we made a few changes.  We omit the tomato chunks and just use  14 oz. tomato sauce with 1 tbsp of tomato paste, and we leave out the green chiles.  I also add a can of black beans, and I add an extra 1/2 lb chicken and more corn.  I also love that even if you forget to ready it for the slow cooker, it's an easy recipe to whip up in 30-45 minutes on the stovetop (although it tastes SO much better after it's been simmering all day!).    

This is a favorite in our household, enough so that my daughter has requested this for her birthday meal for her 7th, 8th, and 9th birthday.

text:
I basically follow this recipe only put two or three chicken breasts in uncooked and shred just before serving, add a can of drained and rinsed black beans, use a 16-oz. bag of frozen corn, add about 1/4 cup of chopped cilantro, omit water and salt and add chicken broth to the top of my slow cooker.  When ready to serve, shred chicken breasts and add salt to taste.  I serve with chopped avocado, grated cheddar cheese, sour cream, lime wedges, additional chopped cilantro and tortilla strips on the top.  A family favorite!  *I've made this on the cook top when I'm in a hurry and/or when I need to double the recipe.  Very easy, very good!

text:
I've made this several times and it's one of my husband's favorites! Of course, changed a few things to meet our tastes. I made this for company so I increased the amount of chicken to 2 lbs, cooked them whole and then shredded about 1/2 hour before serving (added back to soup at end). I used all very low sodium chicken broth instead of water + broth. Added more garlic (we love it), 1 1/2 tsps. regular chili powder and 1 1/2 tsps. chipotle chili powder. Also added a 4 ounce can of fire roasted green chilies, 1 can low sodium black beans, and used diced tomatoes with jalapenos instead of whole crushed tomatoes. I added the cilantro at the end when I added the shredded chicken and lime juice. Seems like I changed a lot but really just modified for the degree of spice and texture to what we like. Everyone loves this recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this 4 times now.  Of the 2 other recipes, this one is the easiest & best tasting by far.  I agree with many others that adding more chicken stock, or broth, helps the liquid base flavor become more robust.  I just add in an extra 12-15 oz of chicken broth on top of what is in the recipe.  Also, I did have to reduce the chile pepper, and this is coming from a Mexican food loving San Diegan.  I think the heat depends on the freshness and the intensity of the chilies used, both fresh and in the powder form.  So, if you don't like it hot, reduce the intensity &/or amount of chile & powder in this recipe by 1/2.  QUICK TIPS:  1.  shred chicken from an already roasted grocery store chicken.  2.  Just crumble up good quality tortilla chips, like blue corn tortilla chips.  Still tasts great, but is less work. 3.  Of course!  Add shredded cheese, avocado & some lime juice to finish it off.  It won't taste authentic without those elements.  Enjoy!

text:
I doubled this recipe and served at a potluck lunch at work.  For toppings, I served the soup with store bought tri-colored tortilla strips, shredded cheddar cheese, sour cream, and fresh cut limes.  I used chicken stock instead of broth because it has a stronger flavor.  Because I doubled the recipe and had to use two cans of enchilada sauce, I used red and green.  Everyone loved it and there were endless compliments!

text:
This was great! I did follow a few other reviews and made a few changes. I made it for a small family get together and I sent the leftovers and recipe with them! IF feeding more than 6-8 people  double the recipe. I though it could use a little more broth, I will do that next time. 

The changes I made were: 3 large raw chicken breasts in the crock pot, used all chicken broth and no water, added a can of rinsed and drained black beans. Squeezed a fresh lime in the soup about half way through cooking.  Turned out AMAZING! Will def make again!

text:
Loved it!  Was super quick and easy to make and came out perfect.  Used about 2 lbs of boneless skinless chicken breast.  No need to pre-cook, just throw in the bottom of the crock and shred with 2 forks about an hour before you are ready to serve.  I also added 1 diced seeded jalapeno for a little extra kick.  I skipped making tortilla strips and just bought a bag of pre-made ones at the grocer.  I served with some shredded mexican cheese on top and some more fresh cilantro.  In the future some sour cream, creme fraiche, cotija cheese, and/or avocado slices would be nice as well.  Should have served with some lime slices, woops!  Maybe adding some drained black beans in the beginning would work well.

text:
I made this for my Bunko group yesterday and they all loved it!  Rave reviews, went back for seconds, and requests for the recipe!  I will definitely be making this again.  The only change I made was to add the chicken breasts frozen and let them cook all day in the slow cooker.  I took them out, let them cool, shredded them and added back to the soup - fabulously easy! Oh, and I doubled everything for the larger group of 12.

momala

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my daughter's favorite soup, and I make it at least twice a month. Here are my modifications, since I own  Ninja slow cooker that allows me to brown meat and then turn it to slow cook mode.  1)  Brown chicken (with bone in, I use thighs).  Add onion and brown in chicken fat for a minute or so, then add garlic.  2)  Add the rest of the ingredients, but double the enchilada sauce and instead of using chicken broth, use the cans to add water then use chicken boullion cubes (I add three).  3) Add one SMALL head cabbage chopped then cook as directed.  4) Before serving, take the chicken out discard skin and bone and readd to the soup.  Made this way, the soup is very filling and satisfies my mother instinct to sneak veggies into everything.

Great recipe! Put in raw chicken tenders because it's what I had. They were actually frozen. Then red kidney beans instead of corn. This was SO good! I mostly followed the recipe, choosing hot enchilada sauce and hot green chili peppers - it added a tiny kick, but tame enough so that my 10 year-old enjoyed his meal. text:
The list of ingredients might be a little daunting, but this recipe is SO easy, just open up the cans and dump in the slow cooker.  You can easily save yourself some time by putting raw chicken in the crock and cooking it with the soup.  Just shred it up before serving.  The only other changes I make are using petite diced tomatoes instead of smashing the whole ones, and decreasing the green chiles as I don't like it to be too spicy.  This recipe is definitely a keeper!

text:
This is a wonderful recipe...and very versatile. I add rinsed/drained black beans. Serve with shredded cheese and sour cream. I've used frozen chicken, canned chicken, frozen corn, canned corn, added green chilies...basically, whatever is in the house at the time. It's ALWAYS come out wonderful! Easy to add extra ingredients (more broth, tomatoes, etc.) if you need to stretch it out to feed more. Freezes well (if there are any leftovers - ha!). I make it in my slow cooker, or if pressed for time, in my pressure cooker! Definitely a "must try"...and is always a top request by my family (kids included...they always ask for "taco soup").

text:
This is one of my all-time favorite recipes because it's easy to make, healthy, and delicious!

I've made the recipe exactly as stated and it was wonderful.  I've also substituted the water with more chicken broth, I've made it in a slow-cooker or (when no slow-cooker was available) I cooked it for less time in a big pot on the stove. Delicious any way I've made it!

The only thing I've changed after about 10 times of making this is that I don't cook the chicken first. For the sake of cleaning one less thing, I just throw the raw chicken in with everything else. Then about 15-20 minutes before I'm ready to serve it, I take it out, shred it, and throw the shredded chicken back in. I garnish with everything the recipe recommends, and sometimes add a dollup of sour cream too. Thanks for sharing it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great foundation for tortilla soup! These are the changes I made and it is SUPERB! 
I always boil chicken pieces with skin on. Long enough to get REAL chicken broth. Followed the basic recipe though. Place chicken (removed from bones) in the crockpot, along with all broth from the cooked chicken about 5 cups or so. Added 2 cubes of Knorr Caldo de Tomate bouillon, chicken base 2 tsp or to taste (I prefer the brand Better than Bouillon...so flavorful B-)  i added 2 chopped pickled jalapeno- didn't have green chillies in a can....plus its cheaper! Added 3 tsp. of McCormick Enchilada seasoning mix INSTEAD OF enchilada sauce! (You will find this in an envelope in the spices section of your local grocery store..also cheaper) Just remember...its not necessary to use can chicken broth when you boil chicken pieces versus plain breasts ...YUCK! Also....you can use MORE water and add a little more enchilada seasoning OR bouillon/ chicken base. I realize its more involved not using breasts...but it tastes like Authentic Tortilla Soup ...as we call it in Texas. Thanks for the recipe! Just love this KEEPER RECIPE!

text:
I've made this so many times now, and each time it's a huge hit! The first time I made it, I made a few substitutions on accident, but my family liked it, so it stuck. The recipe calls for a 10oz can of enchilada sauce, but I use the entire 28 ounce can. Also, I replace the water with chicken broth, and omit the green peppers. We like to buy some home made tortilla chips from a local Mexican market, and when it's done cooking, sprinkle those on top,  with a bit of cheese, and it's the best! This has become a staple for us!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only change to the recipe I made was to add the tortillas TO the soup, then give it another 20-30 minutes.  The tortillas soften, then devolve, giving the soup a thicker quality.

It is extremely important to stop cooking at that point or the soup will burn on the edge of the slow cooker.  Ask me how I know ;->

The soup freezes very well and keeps practically forever.
I am the only one in the house who eats it, and it keeps me going all winter.

Love this one!

text:
Made this for my boyfriend and we both loved it! I reduced the amount of salt and added some cajun seasoning (probably 1/4 tsp or so), along with a few dashes of chipotle hot sauce. I couldn't find enchilada sauce at the store, but Ortega taco sauce seemed to work fine. 

As some other users commented, I found it easier to throw in some raw, boneless skinless chicken breasts (I used almost 2 lbs for a heartier soup) then shred them towards the end. 

I also cooked some rice on the side and served the soup over it instead of using tortilla strips - stretches it farther and tastes great!
