text:
Delicious!!  A few simple changes but nothing that would change the overall recipe.  I omitted the water & used all reduced-sodium chicken broth instead.  We reserved the cilantro to put on top versus cooking into the soup.  I took another reviewers advice & put the chicken breasts in whole & shredded them after they cooked....very easy & not time-consuming at all.  I skipped making my own tortilla strips & just picked up a bag of tortilla strips from the store & they were great served on top.  *Slow-cooker friendly, perfect for a cool day, & a good pick me up when you're sick with a cold.  Will definitely make again.

text:
I tried this taco soup a couple of years ago and it has become one of our favorites. I have been asked for the recipe several times and was glad to pass it along.  It has also become one of my son-in-law's favorite soups. He cannot have anything that had milk or milk products in it and this fit the bill to a tee.

I put the chicken breasts in raw and let them cook until just before eating. then I take them out and pull them apart with a fork and put back in the soup.  Very easy to do.

None
text:
A good basic start. The best way to fix it when it's too watery is to crush up some tortilla chips and cook them in the soup to act as a thickening agent. I too put in frozen chicken breasts and shredded them just before serving.  I also use pinto beans rather than corn, so throw a can of drained pintos in just a bit before serving.  Throw on a bit of shredded cheddar cheese, a couple of avocado slices and garnish with chopped cilantro and crushed tortilla chips and you have a great main dish.

userID:
1480983
Display Name:
mariealicia
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
46
favoritesCount:
82
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this almost every Sunday and eat it for lunch throughout the week. I don't use a slow cooker or chicken breasts. 

To make this more economical (and tastier), I use about 1.5 lbs chicken drumsticks or legs. Heat a bit of oil in a stock pot, salt and pepper the chicken, and brown it (~6 minutes, then turn for another 6 minutes). Throw all the soup ingredients in (plus a can of black beans). I also do not use water, I use chicken broth for the entire amount of liquid called for in the recipe. Simmer for however long you'd like. I usually do 2 hours.

Then,remove the chicken with tongs, place on cutting board and shred with a fork or your hands, removing the fatty skin and then throwing the chicken from the bone back in the soup. Let simmer another hour and it's done. Really great. Thanks!
Review:

5

text:
This was a very easy soup.  I gave it 4 stars because I used an 11 oz can of corn and it was way too much corn.  I also would use chicken broth next time instead of the water.  You don't have to have cooked chicken on hand - you can cut boneless skinless chicken into spoonful sizes and add to crock pot.  Cook for 4 hours on high.  I also added cooked shrimp about an hour before done.

Super easy and I was actually surprised I had made it because it turned out so well. The only alterations I made were: used fresh roma tomatoes (chopped and squished), put chopped raw chicken breast straight into the slow cooker, left out the bay leaf, and used tortilla chips to top. It came out perfectly. Husband had quite a bit of it for dinner and he's usually not a huge soup person. I used a can of hot red enchilada sauce and it added a bit of a kick but wasn't too spicy. Will definitely make again.

natorade

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
To go with the easy method (which is great) I skip the extra water and add another can of broth. I don't us a crock pot as this works just fine on the stove top in under 90 minutes. I don't precook the chicken. I use a half quartered skinless chicken raw with half breast, a thigh, and a leg. Take the chicken out after an hour, discard the bones, and shred, then put back in for another 30 minutes. When I have more time I roast a chicken the day before and have half for that dinner, remove skin from other half and save remaining meat for soup. Boil the other leftover carcass with onions and celery for the broth. There is so much more flavor in fresh broth and meat roasted on the bone. Either way, it's a great recipe.

text:
This recipe was delicious! I made the chili sauce the way a previous person suggested. I added 4 ancho chilies to a saucepan with water, 2 cloves of garlic and a quarter of an onion. I boiled it then threw it in the blender with a small can of tomato sauce. I added all of it to my soup. I increased the amount of cumin and salt to maybe twice what it asked for. I used cayenne pepper and doubled what the recipe asked for as well. It had a nice spicy kick. I served it with some sliced avocado and muenster cheese. I am Hispanic and felt this recipe tasted very authentic!

text:
This is a favorite in our house, it's SO good!!  I add a can of black beans (rinsed). Also I'm not a huge corn fan, so I only add a cup of frozen and then also add a red pepper-diced and a cup of diced carrots.  If I want to speed up the recipe for a non slow cooker meal, I sauté all the veggies until tender and use a rotisserie chicken.  When I do slow cook I put in whole pieces of breasts and thighs and just let them fall apart in the cooking.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of our go to recipes at our house! I make a few changes, but they are just based on my families taste preferences. 
- use two cans of rinsed black beans instead of corn
-sub water for chicken broth
-sub crushed tomatoes for whole peeled 

The last thing we do that I think really makes it a hearty soup instead of a watery one is we add rice. Once everything is cooked I add a cup to a cup and a half of minute brown rice and cook it for 10 additional minutes. It absorbs a lot of the liquid so we've played with the quantity. Like I said very good recipe! This is just how we tailor it for our family.

Display Name:
KK

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe both by the book (mostly) and by substituting the enchilada sauce with dried peppers, per one reviewers recommendation - both ways were delicious, but using dried peppers gave the soup a deeper, more complex flavor. For the soup, I used two negro chiles (also known as pasillas or dried poblanos), and one chipotle, tops and seeds removed, then soaked in hot water and pureed (I learned how to make enchilada sauce from this recipe http://www.homesicktexan.com/2011/04/beef-enchilada-recipe-chili-gravy.html) Both times I added more cumin, one can of rinsed black beans, and I gradually added water, so that I could adjust as needed. You can do this recipe on the stove top if short on time, it's fine. Smoked sea salt made this recipe amazing, if using low-sodium ingredients. I always cook the chicken in the soup then shred it. A little fresh lime juice is a great addition, also.
Review:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great tasting soup, but be careful with the tortillas in the oven.  The recipe says 10 to 15 minutes but if you leave them in that long they'll burn to a crisp.  They only need about 7 minutes at 400 F.  

If you deep fry them instead of putting them in the oven they'll taste even better, but if the oil is too hot they'll burn in less than five seconds so be careful there too.

text:
I used this recipes to make dinner today and my family loved it. I did not substitute anything because I was nervous to ruin it. It could of used an extra kick of something (spicy) but I thought it would be too spicy with the green chile peppers. So now I know that for next time. I did make the chips from scratch with the tortillas which made a big difference versus the regular tortilla chips you buy at the store. We also added sour cream, lime and avocados to top it off on our bowls. I highly recommend this dish.

I agree it could use a little less water. Next time I make it I'll only put in 1 cup of water. I also added the black beans and used fresh chicken breasts and let them cook in the soup. I'll definitely be making this again!

text:
Good soup! First time making soup in my slow cooker. As I was adding all the ingredients i quickly realized my cooker wasn't going to hold it all so I omitted the water, instead just kept the liquid to 1 1/2 cups chicken broth. I added a can of kidney beans, and used 1 can of peaches and cream canned corn instead of frozen. I added a bit of tobasco and used the cilantro, plus monterey cheese and the tortilla strips as garnish. Delish!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
ok- I made a few changes based on reviews and what I had in the kitchen: I added brown rice, more hot peppers, and made the home made enchilada sauce that another reviewer suggested- although I didn't have ancho chiles,  just frozen jalapenos- I chopped and boiled- seeds and all the peppers w/ 2 garlic cloves, 6 frozen chopped tomatoes, salt and  cumin for the canned enchilada sauce. I also did not have cilantro, so subbed 4 frozen cilantro 'cubes'-  We had lots of cilantro this June, so chopped and pulverized in my food processor w/ water and froze into cubes in the ice cube tray, then threw into zip lock bags- wa la- fresh cilantro taste to anything...I also made home made chicken stock and added that instead of broth and water.. very very good soup! I plan on making this a lot with the chicken stock I canned, along with a few frozen chicken breasts and the seasonings and corn..it's a huge hit!! Even my husband can make it when I am out of town!!

Alright, I have 4 semi-picky kids including one that is gluten intolerant and another that has food texture issues due to autism and this was a hit!  Not too spicy, not too bland.  I had to omit cumin because I ran out, added more chili powder, added black beans, and used shredded rotisserie chickens because that is what I had available.  Served with a little shredded cheese and tortilla chips (kids love dipping).  Hit with the adults, too.

text:
Delicious! Cooked this on the stovetop instead of crockpot.  After reading other reviews, I threw in 2 uncooked chicken breasts and added the rest of the ingredients plus a can of black beans.  Brought it up to boil , then simmer for 1 1/2 hours.  The enchilada sauce is what makes this recipe.  I used Gebhardt, my fav.  Also, no water, just a quart of homemade chicken stock I had.  Everyone loved it.  thanks.

text:
Great soup and easy to make. I didn't cook mines in the slow cooker, simmered it for a couple hours. Used chicken tender breast and shredded after they were cooked all the way through. Sautéed by garlic and onions before putting them in the pot. Added a tomato cooking base from Goya in addition to the enchilada sauce and a little of coriander, and cayenne pepper. Also, watch the tortilla slices in 10 min. They turned into a burnt crisp. Garnished it with a slice of lime and a dap of guacamole.  Didn't have fresh avocado or sour cream. Will definitely make it again.

text:
This dish is so easy and delicious. I put it on before church, and it's done by the time we get out. Everybody in my house LOVES this soup. I make it like twice a month now!

The garnishes are a must: 
-Tortillas (We use a whole package (not just 10) and fry them in coconut oil
-Mexican Crema or sour cream
-Crumbled Queso Fresco
-Avocado
-Lime wedges

Thanks for this recipe!!!!

text:
This is, by far, one of the most amazingly delicious things I have ever tasted.  I am shocked.  I knew close to 3,000 reviews couldn't be wrong!  I will make this every week.  My husband loves it, too.  Oh, and could NOT be easier.  Throw everything in the cooker and plug it in.  I am not a cook and I screw up a lot.  I could do this again without the recipe it was so easy.

My suggestions - just throw the raw breasts in the pot and after three hours take them out, shred, and throw it back in.  I used store bought tortilla chips.  In the bowl top with avocado and shredded "Mexican" cheese.  Oh, and finally, I made my own enchilada sauce.  The stuff in the grocery store was full of ingredients I couldn't pronounce.   So I found a simple recipe online, took 20 minutes, and used that.

None
text:
Very good soup.  I used all chicken broth instead of some broth and some water, and it still needed salt, so no worries on it being too salty that way.  Started with semi-frozen chicken breasts and they were cooked and ready to shred on high in about 3 hours...so definitely no need to precook the chicken.  Also added the can of black beans, drained, as others recommended.  Added some additional cumin, served with limes, cilantro, shredded cheese, sour cream, and tortilla chips (didn't have time to make my own).  Pretty tasty, and reasonably healthy (except for high sodium content).

My fiancé loved this recipe!! text:
This was very good and super easy with a few adjustments.  I threw in 2 frozen chicken breasts with all the other ingredients.  Used all broth instead of water, added some diced peppers, just because I had some to use up, and added a can of black beans.  About 30 mins before serving I shredded the chicken and added it back in.  When serving top the soup with shredded cheese, sour cream, and avocado.  Also I used premise tortilla salad strips.  Hubby said it was better than my usual chicken tortilla soup recipe.  This is definitely ALOT easier so its a keeper.

text:
Loved this soup.  I am no expert on authentic latin soups but just loved all the different textures and flavors.  I doubled the cumin, chili powder, and cilantro.  Used frozen chicken and shredded about an hour before done.  I happened to have frozen okra and threw it in when I shredded the chicken and it was a perfect compliment to the flavors and added a nice new texture.  I did add a portion of white rice in a bowel before ladelling the soup on top, then added shredded cheese, sliced avocado, and some fresh lime on top.  I was able to get a different flavor and texture in each bite.  Yummy....

text:
I found that adding  roasted veggies to slow cooked soups deepens the flavor.. It is a way to counter the 'blandness' of so many slow-cooked dishes, in addition to sautéing ingredients and  adding your favorite herbs and spices. Here are my modifications--used trader joe's roasted tomatoes with roasted green chiles (for the mashed whole peeled tomatoes and can of chilies), 5-6 cloves roasted garlic, and roasted corn (frozen). I used 3/4 lb of chicken which was plenty. Quite a delicious, thick hearty soup. Freezes well. Will make it again.

I made the mistake of making a double batch of it the very first time making it, because of the high rating and I'm sorry I did.  Now I have a huge slow cooker full of really mediocre soup. text:
I LOVE this recipe! I did make a few modifications though. I used a 28 oz can of whole peeled tomatoes instead of 15 oz. and I omitted the 2 c. of water. I also added a 14 oz can of black beans (not drained) and the juice of 1 lime. I added 3 extra tbsp of cilantro as well.

And, instead of cooking and shredding the chicken beforehand, I just placed 3 boneless skinless chicken breasts in the pot. An hour before serving, I fished them out and shredded them and then placed them back into the pot. Delish! A family favorite!

text:
One of my favorite soups ever!  I have made this several times, and it is delish!  The first time I made it, I mistakenly picked up lemon pepper frozen chicken breasts at the store instead of plain.  I used them anyway as it was all I had, and it was amazing.  Now, I usually keep some in the freezer just for this recipe, but it is still good with plain chicken as well.  The only change I make is to leave out the cilantro until the end.  I use it as a topping instead.  I sometimes add a can of black beans, too.  Following one reviewers advice, I top with cheese, avocado, a dollop of sour cream, cilantro and lime juice.  Instead of making the tortillas, I purchase a bag of the salad topper tortilla strips found in the produce section at my store.

jbear84

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous recipe. Easy to make. My husband and I loved it! We like this type of soupy version better than the creamy version as some people have wished this was. We used chicken breasts instead of the shredded chicken, about 3 hours into cooking we took the chicken out and shredded it and put it back in to cook with the can of corn we used instead of the package (since the corn was fully cooked just needed to heat up). At that point it was pretty spicy, even he said so and he’s a spicy kind of guy! But an hour and a half of cooking more the flavor mellowed slightly and it turned out delicious. With cheddar cheese, sour cream, avocado, and the tortilla pieces it is definitely something I would make again.
Differences: 
--I used 1 can a broth and 1 cup of water since there was liquid from all the other cans and it was more than enough and had more flavor. 
--I did use skin on, bone in chicken which I won’t do again (it was in the freezer so I used it), it had a lot of oily fat from the skin and bones but the flavor was fantastic regardless! 
--I also would take the tomatoes and instead of just smashing I would dice them up or just use diced tomatoes because after 4.5 hours they were still too chunky, I had to take them out and chop them up.

text:
Fantastic! I love Mexican food and this recipe is great. I'm from the Southwest, so I know when I find a good one. I was surprised that this tasted so good with all of the canned ingredients. I skipped the corn, but did take the other reviewers' advice and used frozen chicken breasts, I've also made it with leftover chicken, and boneless, skinless chicken thighs. 

When I'm all out of chicken broth, I just use chicken bullion cubes. I always double or triple this recipe because it doesn't last long enough for my family of 5 to have decent leftovers if I don't. 

It's a versatile recipe - I've even added rice to it. Tonight I'm going to add black beans because I have some left over, I'll update and let you know how it goes.

Shortcuts are my thing, so we too use bagged tortilla chips. I've sliced avocado in it and a dollop of sour cream, sooo good! My kids love it - even the toddlers. :-) This one is a keeper! Don't judge it til you try it!

text:
4 stars for following the recipe exactly. When making changes, I liked it more. I used frozen chicken, doubled most of the spices, and added some beans. And I didn't bother with frying the tortillas - just used leftover chips I had lying around. Just use whatever is lying around, and you really can't go wrong with this one. Fresh avocado on top with cheese and tortilla chips - great for a chilly day!

text:
I have made this several times, although I make it on the stovetop instead of the slow cooker.  I don't like chunks of tomato so I use a can of crushed tomatoes instead of the mashed whole peeled tomatoes.  I combine all of the ingrediates and cook on the stove for approx 30-45 minutes.  The tortilla strips are very good with the soup (a pizza cutter is easy to use for cutting the strips.)  When I haven't had time to make my own, I have used hearty (thick) bagged tortilla chips, which work well also.

text:
I will give this recipe 5 stars with some changes that I made.  I never just add water when a recipe calls for it instead I add broth.  So I added chicken broth in replace of the water + yhr chicken broth it called for.  I doubled all the spices and added some jalepenos.  I saw some reviews complaining about it being too liquidy so at the end I added 1 cup of slow cook rice and also some frejoles negros (black beans) which added more substance.  It turned out amazing!  I topped it with crushed tortilla chips, shredded mexican cheese mix, green onions, sour cream, and cut up avocadoes.  Thanks it was easy to make and delicious!

text:
Easy and delicious!  I think the secret is the enchilada sauce?
Thanks to the reviewers, I put the chicken breasts in uncooked.  When I got home, I took them out and shredded them, then put them back in with the frozen corn until dinner time (about an hour more).
I had also added fresh tomatoes and a can each of kidney and black beans (next time I might even add more beans).
You could also add chopped zucchini or grated carrots.  Such a healthy, filling, fun treat for dinner - the kids loved it!
Thank you for a great recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My fiance and I loved this! We followed the recipe but made a few changes - instead of a canned whole tomato, we got two smaller cans of RoTel diced tomatoes and green peppers. We also added in a can of black beans and a lot of paprika and cayenne for heat (we love spicy food!)

Topping this with more fresh cilantro, avocado chunks, the tortilla strips, and colby jack cheese, and it was glorious. It tastes better than most of the tortilla soups we've had in restaurants, with the added bonus of homemade satisfaction. 

Next time we'll add in another can of the tomato chunks with peppers, and get a tiny thing of sour cream as a topper. We might also follow the suggestion presented by other people - using two cans of chicken broth rather than water. 

All in all, this is a great recipe. For just the two of us, it made a ton of leftovers. This would be a great recipe to bring to a pot luck or to share!

text:
Fantastic recipe! I made this for my husband and inlaws and they all loved it. I did change a couple of things: I used hominy instead of corn, diced tomatoes instead of whole, and I used El Pato and tomato sauce in place of the enchilada sauce (to give a brighter, fresher tomato tast). I have only made this twice and I am already getting recipe requsts from people who have only heard how good it is from my mother in law!  This soup also freezes very well.  I just put it into individual serving sizes, froze, then microwaved for a few minutes when ready to eat.

text:
I used uncooked chicken, cut into pieces, used diced canned tomatoes, all chix broth instead of water, and omitted the bay leaf (i was out), after 8 hours on low heat the soup was cooked but felt the consistency was a little thin and the spice overwhelming,  added Mexican blend shredded cheese to taste (i didn't measure, just added a little, stirred, tasted, i would guess between 1-2 cups in total) Perfection! Better than restaurant and very close to authentic, i actually like this version better than authentic because there is more chix and the addition of cheese and sour cream garnish.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to modify it to the point it no longer resembles that original recipe. First off, definitely add a squeeze of lime prior to cooking. Since most of ingredients are canned, I was wary of the salt content - l used 'no salt added' tomatoes and homemade enchilada sauce. Next, I doubled the onions (yellow) and doubled the garlic and spices. I added one packet of Sazon Goya w/ Safron. I used 1/2 fresh Jalapeno (chopped) instead of canned chilies. Added Hominy instead of corn per another user's suggestion on here. 

Also, I browned onions and garlic in olive oil before adding to crock pot due to habit.

None
text:
I didn't use a crockpot.  Also, I used chicken tenders that were partially thawed.  I cut the chicken tenders into small pieces.  I put the chopped onion, corn, chicken, a diced yellow bell pepper,chicken broth and water into the pot and boiled on low for 15 minutes.  Then I added all the other ingredients and brought back to a boil and then simmered on medium low for 20 minutes. I serve with tortilla chips and a grated mexican blend of cheese.  This is tasty a tasty soup that I will make again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1831198.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is by far our favourite tortilla soup recipe.  The broth base is just fantastic.  I did this quick on the stove top, frozen chicken and all.  Added a can of black beans as well.  We tried it over rice, but just not as good.  You have to do the real corn tortilla's baked in the oven, the chips just won't do and seriously alter the taste.  Also topped with a wedge of fresh lime, cheddar, avocado, diced tomato, fresh cilantro and the chips!!  Amazing flavour...oh the only thing I did change was doubling the liquid (broth no water and enchilada and spices) The 1st night it had too much chicken, beans, etc. with the liquid doubled it was perfect.
Review:

5

I love that this recipe doesn't call for packets of ranch seasoning or anything, because I like to be able to control the spices and salt in a dish, and this recipe's seasonings are perfect.  Definitely a keeper.

text:
This soup is amazing! I love how I can just dump it in the crock pot and be done with it.  Made a couple of changes just based on what I had in the cabinets. Used Rotel tomatoes instead of whole peeled tomatoes and used taco sauce instead of enchilada sauce, otherwise I made it exactly as stated.  When done I topped it with mozzarella cheese...DELICIOUS! Hubby absolutely loved and devoured the leftovers the following days...he even added pico de gallo for a little extra kick.

UPDATE: I've been using this recipe for years now, love it! I share it with everyone I know. Definitely add black beans and we use the salad topping tortilla chips to give added color on top.

text:
Great recipe with a few modifications. I cooked the chicken & shredded first before putting in slow cooker. Added black beans, extra 1/4 tsp of chili powder, 1 tsp of oregano & increased pepper to taste. Used only 3/4 cup of water & added 1 tsp of chicken flavor bouillon. Didnt use corn tortillas, just tortilla chips on top, with cheese & sour cream! cooked on high for 2 1/2 hours and was great! definitely a keeper!!!

This is an excellent soup.  I have made it twice now and each time it was fab!  Mine always turns out a bit spicy but that is how we like it.  Just depends on how much heat is in the enchilada sauce.  I did as others suggested and put my frozen chicken right in the pot to cook.  Shredded it just before serving.  This makes it so easy.  Dump all ingredients in the pot and go.  Also added black beans as other suggest.  Serve with sour cream, avocado, crushed corn chips and fresh cilantro.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We made this tonight.  It's great, but I dropped it a star because all of the alterations we made to it.  I still think it would be good the way it is, though.  I didn't use the crockpot, just made it at dinner time & it didn't take long at all.  As another poster said, it's all precooked ingredients, so the slowcooker isn't necessary but handy to have as an option.   Anyway, I used chicken stock I made from scratch, a can of diced tomatoes, a can of black beans and some frozen corn.  I didn't use enchilada sauce but instead minced some garlic and onion and threw it in, along with cumin and oregano.  Right before serving, I added the juice of a lime.  I put little bowls of "add ons", like diced avocado, baked tortilla strips, lime slices, shredded chicken, queso fresco, diced onion and cilantro.  And of course a bottle of hot sauce.  Everyone dressed up their own soup, which my kids were excited about.  It was so delicious, I had 2 bowls and about am about to burst.

None
text:
I love this recipe! It's quick and easy to make. I have yet to find a better tasting soup at a Mexican restaurant. I added 2 cans of fire roasted tomatoes instead of the whole peeled tomatoes. I also added 4 cups of chicken broth and one cup of water to give it more of a soup base. Like the other cooks I cooked the chicken breast in the slow-cooker, bone in, skin on, and removed the bone and skin, then shredded it after about 4 hours of cooking time. I also added chili flakes along with the chili powder because I like it spicy! I also left out the corn because I don't really fancy corn. Thanks for the fun recipe!

Display Name:
Amy Secretan
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/20.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and easy soup!! I used a whole chicken, put it in at the beginning, and let it cook on low for about 4 hours. Then I shredded it about an hour before serving, so it had a very good flavor! I added additional amounts of the chili powder and hot sauce, and we actually found it not spicy enough, so next time I will make it spicier! One note though, do not taste this before it has had time to cook and the flavors have blended, because the taste when you first put all the ingredients together is VERY different (in a good way!) from the taste of it after it simmers together! Check for flavor about an hour before you serve it, and make any additions to spices and such then! YUM YUM YUM, can't wait to make this soup again!

I made some variations. 1 Can black beans 1 Can green chili peppers 1 Can Pinto beans 1 Can Red kidney beans 2 Cans Rotel Salt Pepper 1 Pkg. Taco seasoning 1 Pkg. Ranch dressing 1 Lb. Chicken OR beef (if beef, cooked, if chicken rare is fine and shred later) 1 Can corn 1 Can or bottle beer Extra water as needed and extra taco seasoning if needed too.  Perfect every time, all the friends, family and neighbors beg me for it, it's my boyfriends absolutely favorite dish!  He prefers beef  ;)

userID:
1469285
Display Name:
Weezie
isPro:

42

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4526939.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good, very easy, and easily modified to suit your own tastes.  I cut raw chicken breasts into large chunks and put in at the beginning, shredded shortly before serving.  Per another reviewer, used 1 can Rotel 'cilantro & lime' flavor and 1 can Rotel 'Hot' (instead of separate tomatoes and green chili peppers), and added a can of black beans (undrained).  Used about 16 oz chicken broth and no water, and added about 3 Tbsp cilantro shortly before serving.  I find most soups just get better and better the longer they cook, so I cooked this on High for almost 10 hours and it was delicious.  Served with plain non-fat yogurt and a bit of lime juice. Bought chips would be fine, but the homemade are better. Thinking about adding okra next time, as this will become a regular at my house.  It would also be good for my vegetarian friends and family if I use veggie broth and eliminate the chicken.
Review:

5

This soup is delicious! I needed a recipe to get back into using my crock pot again and this one sounded amazing. I followed it pretty much as it reads, except that I added a can of drained black beans. I also put in two defrosted chicken breasts and then shredded them after about three hours. My husband and son both loved it! My two year old actually licked the bowl and ate every bit of it. For him, this is a very rare thing! Thanks for  a great recipe that I will definately make regularly for my family!

This is a super easy dish and it is a winner every time. I suggest putting thawed uncooked chicken breasts in the soup, removing the cooked meat before serving to shred--saves you a step. text:
I love this recipe. It is so easy to make and not time consuming at all. I throw in all the ingredients in the morning and by the afternoon it's ready. I've made it twice already. I like to use the rotiserrie chicken from costco and I like to add a package of powder enchilada sauce in addition to the can of enchilada sauce. I also like to squeeze the juice of one lime into an hour before I serve it. I like to use the Rotel tomatoes with chile pepper in a can I found at our grocery store. I will make this many more times.

text:
This was delicious! I gave it 5 stars because my husband and kids ate it and even ate the leftovers the next day!  I was worried this wouldn't taste right because I didn't have all the ingredients on hand, but the flavor was outstanding. I think it was because of the enchilada sauce! I did not cook the chicken beforehand.  I used 6 chicken breasts and put them in the crockpot with all the ingredients piled on.  Another recipe called for hominy, so I used 1/2 c since I didn't have corn. Instead of the tomatoes I used 2 cans of enchilada sauce, a large box of broth (6c) and used crushed tortilla chips and cheddar cheese on top.  It needed 5 hours on HIGH for the chicken to break apart.  Thanks for a great recipe!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
this was good. I used 2 chicken breasts with bone in, 1 sm can fireroasted diced tomatoes (in place of the whole peeled tomatoes), 1 sm can RoTel Tomatoes with Green chilis(in place of the can of chpped green chilis), 1 32 oz can chicken broth ( no water) and added 1 sm can rinsed black beans. I only used about 1/2 a medium onion. I cooked on high for 4 hours. The last 1/2 hour I took out the chicken, shredded it and then put it back in. I also very finely shredded some dark chocolate in at the end to add a little depth of flavor. Used store bought chips, sliced avocado and wedges of lime. Easy, tasty and looks good, too.

Display Name:
rascal34

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has become one of our "go-to" slow cooker recipes that never disappoint!   Like others, I substitute the water for all chicken broth. I also substitute the smashed tomatoes with rotel mexican (has the lime and cilantro).  Lastly, I add a can of drained black beans and one diced jalapeño. Take the chicken out one hour prior,shred with two forks and then place back in the pot.  Tostitos brand lime flavored tortilla chips work well if you don't want to make your own.  A dollop of sour cream and a few dashes of Sirracha top it off nicely!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
To make this heartier, I followed others' suggestions and added black beans and a bag of uncooked brown rice.  In the last hour, I transferred the soup to a heavy-bottom pot, brought to rapid boil, and then covered while it simmered.  This helped shred the chicken (I started frozen) and steam the rice.  I also added garlic salt and a cilantro base (Goya).  Lastly, I used the juice of a whole lime while cooking (and then at end for garnish with avocado and fresh cilantro).

text:
I forgot the chilis and it still turned out good.  Here are my modifications after reading others:  I used canned bay leaves, red pepper instead of chili powder, added a can of black beans, 2 cups of rice at the very end.  Also, I used 6 frozen chicken tenders and shredded them at the end.  I used 6 cloves of garlic.  I added a dollop of sour cream to each bowl and topped with tortilla chips. My aunt, husband and picky 7 year old cousin loved it!

text:
I doubled the recipe to freeze but there were no leftovers!  I took the suggestion of others and added black beans and all chicken broth. I also like a hearty soup so I cut up 5 corn tortillas into tiny bits and put it in during the last hour. It absorbed some of the liquid and made it heartier. Next time I'll add even more chicken broth to offset the lost liquid. Will also add more cumin and chili powder to make it spicier as my kids can handle it.  Great recipe. Will make again and again!

I made it with 3 frozen skinless chicken breasts, no water only chicken broth and I used a whole 16oz bag of frozen corn. I did not use beans because the guest of honor does not eat beans but I imagine a can of black beans would add a really nice touch.

text:
This is our go-to recipe when we want something hot and spicy on a cold winter night. If we don't have any leftover chicken, I will boil some chicken with complimentary spices, and then shred the chicken for the soup. We use more chicken broth and less water, less chiles, and add sour cream while eating. Lastly, we use Fritos instead of the tortillas. That part was too much work, and you get the corn/salty flavor added with the tortillas. I just dump it in around 10 AM, put it on low and serve it up at 6:30. Enjoy!

text:
I've made tortilla soup several times, but my family thinks last night's recipe was the best ever.  I made a double batch and shared it with a sick friend and her family.  I've got two crock pots, so it was easy.  The kids loved the smell when they came home from school.    I didn't have all of the ingredients and made the following substitutions:  1 can of Rotel and 1/2 can tomato sauce (instead of enchilada sauce, tomatoes & cannned chilis).  I used a heaping tablespoon of chili powder because I didn't use the enchildada sauce, regular tortilla chips (although I'd like to try this idea), an extra can of chicken broth, and 2 lbs of chicken instead of one.  Didn't have frozen corn and used a can of corn instead.  Oh, I also added a can of black beans (a must!)  We served this with cheddar cheese and sour cream.  The kids always like to cool their hot soups and chili down with cheese and sour cream.  Made enough for our family of seven with several bowls of leftovers.    Great!

text:
Great recipe.  As others had suggested, I added a can of black beans.  I substituted a can of diced tomatoes for the can of whole tomatoes so I could skip the "mashing" step.  I did not add as much water since I have a smaller crock pot.  This made it come out more like a stew, which I consider a plus.  I added a lot more than a tablespoon cilantro, and I added it near the end so it would remain fresh and green.  I ate it for a week and never got tired of it!

text:
We had our first snow here today, and this was the perfect soup for a cold day, just absolutely excellent!  I didn't have corn or cilantro on hand, so I omitted those items.  I replaced with one can of pinto beans and one can of white hominy.  I did precook my chicken as the recipe suggested.  Also, I needed it done faster so I brought everything up to a boil on stovetop, then lowered temp to simmer for one hour.  We garnished with crushed tortilla chips, bagged variety, and shredded cheddar.  My three year old ate his entire bowl, that's rare, and we thoroughly enjoyed it as well.  It's definitely something I will make again and again, simply delish!  Thank you for such a great recipe.

I chose to saute' the onions first, so they would be translucent and not crunchy in the soup. I am glad I did.  I agree with the others, the the tortilla strips were a waste.  The soup stands great on it's own, or with store bought chips if you must!  This soup will definitely be added to our short list!  YUMMY!  My husband loved it!

text:
I've made this recipes more times than I can count. It's an absolute favorite of my family. I strongly suggest you bookmark this one for leftover turkey and turkey broth after Thanksgiving! It's delicious! Sometimes I find precooked meat tastes dry after yet another day of cooking, so I usually just stir in the shredded precooked meat in the last 15-30 minutes before we eat. We also use crushed tortilla chips - blue or yellow - instead of making our own. Also - there is enough salt from the tomatoes/enchilada sauce/broth that you can omit the 1 tsp salt and it's plenty salty. Thanks for this awesome recipe!

I cheated a bit and used a store bought rotisserie chicken. I also switched the recommended amounts of water and broth, and added both rice and black beans.  Great topped with avacado and lime juice. You might kick up the spices a bit if you want some heat. Got rave reveiws on this one, and I'll definitely make it again.

text:
This needed a lot more salt than the recipe called for.  There were a few reasons for this:  Used organic strained tomatoes with no salt added, low sodium chicken stock(4 cups instead of using stock and water), no salt added drained canned corn, and sea salt.  I used a shredded rotisserie chicken, and cooked for 8 hours.  Once I added extra salt it was perfect.  I garnished with fresh cilantro, shredded cheese, blue corn tortila chips, and dollop of greek yogurt instead of sour cream.  Thanks for the recipe.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fantastic!  I did make changes, based on what other reviewers suggested, as well as out of convenience.  I pretty much doubled this recipe (froze half...not sure how that will reheat) because I had a 28-oz can of whole tomatoes.  I used 2 cans (14 oz each) of chicken broth, one can of chopped green chiles, one can of mild red enchilada sauce, and one can of green enchilada sauce.  I did not add water.  I added a can of black beans and golden hominy and used one can of corn instead of frozen-all drained.  I pretty much doubled the spices, garlic, and cilantro.  I added three large frozen chicken breasts and shredded them right before serving.  We topped our soup with lime juice, cheese, tortilla strips, and sour cream.  My 4-year old helped make the tortilla strips.  He brushed the tortillas with oil and used a pizza cutter to make the strips.  We had a great time and a yummy dinner (and lots of leftovers!).

country:
None
text:
Fabulous! I ate this for lunch and dinner 4 days in a row! I've been looking for a tortilla soup recipe that tastes like my favorite restaurant back in Texas, and this is better! I made a couple changes. I used 2 cans of Rotel instead of the whole peeled tomatoes. I also used 4 cups of water with 4 packets of powdered chicken broth seasoning. I also added 1 can of black beans the last hour of cooking. This was not mild or hot - perfect amount of spice in my opinion. I garnished the soup with avocado, shredded mozzarella, and tortilla chips!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
As our 1.5 year-old son said, "YUMMY!" This recipe was easy to make, especially following the advice of other reviewers to put the frozen chicken breasts in at the beginning and shred them later. We changed very little of this recipe and the flavor was exceptional. Our only notable variation was a 15oz can of enchilada sauce since we couldn't find a 10oz can at the store. We highly recommend this soup, topped with sour cream and cheese for optimal flavor.

This one was a big winner in my house.  I did put the chicken in frozen then shredded it toward the end.  We also used the last of the bag of tortilla chips (where they are all crunched up anyway). I will be making this one again at the condo on the ski slopes for a nice warmer up for lunch.

text:
Because some people in this household hate to see little chunks of onion or whatnot floating in a soup - this is what I did:  About 3/4 of the way into the cooking time, I took out the whole chicken breasts (that were put in frozen) and then I pureed the soup, put the shredded chicken, black beans and corn in for the remainder of cooking. I used HOT enchilada sauce - we like things spicy around here. EXCELLENT!!!!! Everyone loved it- even my picky children!  I will definitely make this a lot! Thank you for an excellent recipe.

text:
I made this exactly as posted except I did use frozen chicken breasts which I removed and shredded at the end (great, great, great idea! Thanks to everyone who suggeested this). After smelling this cooking all day and drooling over the scent, I was a bit disappointed.  We found this soup to be pretty bland.  I ended up adding extra cumin, extra chili powder and a packet of taco seasoning to make it more flavorful. My two-year old devoured it!  My husband and I like things spicy so we added hot sauce individually to our bowls.  I'd make this again but only with my own modifications.  Also, the tortilla chips were a fun, delicious alternative to bagged chips.  I recommend giving it a try if you have the time.

I made this, and it was very good. A few adaptations to note: Use a 32-ounce carton of broth instead of water. Putting frozen chicken breasts in at the start worked out fine. I added one can of drained black beans and used one can of canned corn. I like a lot of stuff in my soup, so next time I might be inclined to use at least 1 1/2 cans of each. I might also be inclined to use more cumin and chili powder, just because I like things spicy.

text:
We all enjoyed this very much.  I didn't have a can of green chiles, so I threw in a Serrano pepper.  I used green enchilada sauce and let it cook on high for several hours.  It seemed a bit thin to me, so I tossed in about 1/2 cup of rice to thicken it.  Now it tasted a bit bland, so I added some dry chicken bouillon.  Served with tortilla chips (from a bag!) and realized I didn't have to put so much rice in since the tortilla chips would have sufficed nicely.  Thanks for a great recipe!

This was the first thing that I cooked with my new slow cooker, and it turned out pretty well.  I put the chicken in frozen, as suggested by other reviewers and this seemed to work.  It was a bit spicy, and possibly a bit watery, however.  I am a fan of spicy foods, so this worked for me, but it was a bit too hot for some others.  I might try using the black beans next time to thicken the broth.  Leftovers did not last well in the fridge.  I will be making this one again though!

text:
My kids and husband love this recipe and it's easy, too! I don't add the chicken until later in the recipe. To get my children to eat all of the vegetables in the soup, I cook everything until tender (minus half the corn and the chicken). Then I pour the soup in the blender, blend and put back into the crock pot. I add the remaining corn, chicken and a can of black beans and let it cook a couple of hours longer. I serve it with chips, cheese and cilantro and everyone loves it. My daughter, who hates most vegetables, asks for this when it's her turn to pick what's for dinner.

text:
Great flavor.  Definitely put the chicken in raw and let it cook with the rest, then shred it an hour or so before you serve, makes the chicken taste great and be very tender.  I added two cans of pinto beans, but black would work even better (the wife prefers pinto).  Not spicy at all though, so if you want that, add more chili powder or maybe some fresh/diced jalapeños.

text:
Do not let the long list of ingredients fool you! This soup is quick, easy and most of all, DELICIOUS! I bake the chicken in the oven for an hour, shred, and refrigerate overnight. The next morning, I throw all ingredients in the crock pot and let it simmer all day. I fry up the tortilla strips and use shredded cheddar and a squeeze of lime to top off the bowl of goodness!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4591326.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I eyeballed most of the spices, but used 2 fresh tomatoes & 1 can condensed tomato soup since I didn't have canned tomatoes. I also used frozen "chuckwagon" corn-the corn with red peppers and onions, and that saved some time. Since I cubed and cooked the chicken in water before adding to crockpot, I added the fresh broth & left the chicken cubed. For the most part I actually followed this recipe and served with shredded cheese and rice as sides to add to the soup. It tastes great with cheese (of course!), but adds more body to the soup when adding a cup of cheese. The rice I made in my rice cooker, plain, no spices, and just added it to my bowl of soup--served buffet style to guests & family. The rice helped me stretch this budget meal farther.

text:
Great soup! Made this tonight for my bf and I. I made this last week for my dad (he was coming up to my place to work on a reodeling project so I wanted to have something hot for him to eat). Unfortunately, my dad forgot to put the slow cooker insert (with the leftover soup) into the fridge before he left. I got home around 9:30 that evening, and, to my dissapointment, the soup was still on the counter! I had to throw all the left-overs away!!!!! I love that this is so easy to prepare... literally, throw all ingredients into the slow cooker and walk away. Served with crushed blue corn chips (skipped the homemade tortilla strips due to lack of time/ingredients), a sprinkling of shredded Mexican blend cheese, some freshly chopped cilantro and a Sangria on the side, this makes for a truly "authentic" meal. I have made a similar soup (Chicken Tortilla Soup I by Star Pooley), and my bf actually likes this one better b/c it is less tomato-ey. I like both about the same, but do like the addition of hominy and black beans in the other one which this doesn't have (but I like the broth-like consistency of this one better also). All in all, this is a great recipe that anyone who appreciates convenience must try. I'll have to make more to see how well it freezes. Thanks for sharing!

text:
I prepared this recipe last weekend for my family and I and LOVED it. It is really easy! The only thing I noticed is that there was too much chicken and not enough liquid/soupiness. After I served it for dinner I noticed everyone had a bunch of chicken at the bottom of their bowl. So I remade this soup this weekend and instead of 1 pound of chicken I used 1/2 pound. I also substituted fresh corn from the cobb for the canned corn and omitted the 2 cups of water for 2 cups of chicken broth. I also added carrots because my husband asked me "Where are the carrots"? Overall this recipe is fantastic. I also recommend frying up your own tortilla strips. It just gives it that homemade touch!

city:

None
text:
Excellent Soup! I made on the stove-top, and it still turned out amazing. To adjust for stove, I made the following adjustments. 1.) Put chopped onion, green chilis and all spices in a dutch oven with a little veggie oil. Cooked until onions were soft and spices were fragrant. 2.) Added all other ingredients, except I reduced the water by at least a cup of water --- I then brought it to a boil, and reduced to a simmer for 30 min - 1 hour. 3.) I thickened a little with a flour slurry. Honestly, very little effort to make a wonderful dish!

userID:
2123623
Display Name:
Jill Hecker
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

6
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4424451.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh wow, this was good! As we all do, I made a few modifications. First, since it calls for shredded chicken, I put some chicken tenders in a dutch oven and added water about 2 inches over the chicken. I threw in a bay leaf, salt, pepper and a dried red chili. Then simmered until done. Not only did my chicken get cooked and flavored, but I had a nice broth to use in the soup. So I strained out the 'stuff' and added a little water to make the ammt needed. next time I will try to add more water to cook so I dont have to add water. but, there was no loss of chicken flavor. I added a can of crushed tomitillos which really made the flavor pop. I also added sliced baby carrots (they didnt cook completely through but the slight crunch made a nice texture). Yum. For the tortillas, I cut them in very thin strips, tossed them with pam, salt and chili/lime powder and baked them in a 350 oven for about 10 minutes or so until crisp. I set it up like a soup bar. I had the crock of soup, my tortilla strips, cheese, sour cream, sliced avacado and cilanto and let everyone build their own. My whole family loved it. Will definitely put this in my keeper file!

I'll definitely be making it again!

text:
I thought this was very tasty.  I didn't have a can of enchilada sauce, so used a packet mix made with water and tomato sauce.  I put all my onion, tomato, garlic and green chiles in the blender and chopped them all fine - I don't like a chunky tortilla soup.  We just crushed tortilla chips over the top and sprinkled some grated cheddar on top as well.  Yummy.  The kids even liked it.  The leftovers were just as good and a bit spicier after sitting in the fridge overnight.  Thanks!

text:
The absolute BEST Chicken Tortilla soup on this site or anywhere!  Follow the recipe to the letter and you will be very, very happy with your soup.  I change the beans to whatever I have in the pantry, but everything else stays the same. The only exception is that I boil my chicken and use the homemade broth instead of canned to keep this fresh and healthy.  If I've got a bag of tortilla chips, we just crush them up and toss on to the soup - with or without a spoonful of sour cream and a sprinkle of cheese.  No disappointment with this recipe - definitely a winner!

text:
This is a great recipe and very forgiving. I added sauteed celery, bell pepper, onion and 2 minced habanero's. I didnt have enchilada sauce but a can of tomato sauce, 1 cup water, 2 tbsp oil and 1/4 cup chili powder made a perfect substitute. My husband LOVED this soup. I served it with grated jack cheese sprinkled on top. The only thing I would do differently is bake my tortilla strips with less oil next time; they came out a little greasy and tough.

None
text:
The recipe was delicious!! I made a few changes: 1)Frozen chicken breasts and left out the water--once the chicken defrosts it lets out enough of its own. 2)I added 2 cans of green chilies and waaaaay more cilantro. 3)Left out the cumin (didnt have any) and added a can of rinsed black beans. 4)Used "Chuck wagon Corn" that already had red peppers, onions and green peppers in it but I still added more chopped onion. I also added a pack of ranch dressing mix--this really added some flavor!! I garnished with sour cream and Cheddar cheese and just put a few tortilla chips around the edge of the bowl for dipping/crushing. We all loved this recipe and I can't wait to have the leftovers for lunch. Thanks so much!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this- just had it tonight. I made a couple changes per our tastes. I threw the chicken breasts in raw (4 of them) and omitted the corn at the beginning. After 87 hours in the crockpot I removed the chicken and strained the soup.  I blended the tomatoes, onions and chilies and returned them to the soup, as my hubby doesn't like chunky vegetables in his soup. This actually helped to thicken as well, which was great. I shredded the chicken breasts (they fell apart easily) and returned them to the pot as well. I then added some frozen corn as well as a drained can of kidney beans. Cooked for another hour and a half and it was perfect. Topped with tortilla chips, sour cream, cheese and avocado. This is going to be a staple for us for sure!

text:
This is SO GOOD!  Super easy, really yummy, and filling.  My boyfriend and I ate until we couldn't take another bite, and still wanted more.  Then we fought over the leftovers the next day!  As far as the recipe goes, I made a few small changes. I used 2 frozen chicken breasts and shredded them halfway through, omitted the onions, used more chicken broth instead of water, used canned corn instead of frozen, added a can of black beans, and used a bag of tortilla chips instead of making my own.  Also, make sure to add a squeeze of fresh lime juice just before eating -- mmm, tasty!

This is delicious!  Following some suggestions from other reviewers, I made a few adjustments: used all chicken broth instead of water, and added some black beans.  I used tomato puree instead of whole tomatoes because I dont care for chunks of tomatoes and used 10 oz. can of Mexicorn instead of frozen corn. I also put the chicken in crockpot cut into strips but not cooked. 6 hours on low was perfect and garnished with sour cream, cheese and purchased tortilla strips.  I will definitely make this again.  Thanks.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
EXCELLENT!  First time cooking this dish and the recipe is fantastic!  I made very few changes, and it will require no further changes.  I threw the raw chicken breasts in the crock-pot with the other ingredients and cooked on High for 3.5 hours (as another reviewer suggested) then pulled the chicken out, shredded it with two forks, and placed it back in the crock-pot for another hour or so.  I used one can of Hot enchilada sauce, and in place of the water used about 1 cup of Mild enchilada sauce.  This gave the soup a nice thick consistency.  I had bought a bag of tortilla chips instead of making my own, but as I served the soup with a cheddar and green salsa quesadilla I totally forgot about the chips - still great!  I garnished with shredded cheddar cheese, lime juice, shredded lettuce, green onions, and avocado - YUM!  The best part of this dish is the mouth-watering smell that warms the house on a cool, rainy day!

Beyond super yummy!  I broke my crock pot at the beginning of summer and just got a new one this week and broke it in with this fabulous recipe. I used 1 1/2 lbs. chicken legs, frozen, that I put in the crockpot along with salt, pepper, and 2 cups chicken broth and let that cook 1 hour. My husband ate two huge bowls and my son ate three!  They loved it and it had great flavor that required no tweaking. This is unusual as my husband usually wants it spicier and my daughter thinks it is too spicy.  Not with this recipe.  Everyone thought it was perfect!  Great recipe!

text:
I would have given this 10 stars, and I'm not a fan of soups or mexican flavors.  I did leave out the cilantro and tortilla chips.  It needed more salt so I added another 1/2 teaspoon.  Served with a side of corn bread.  I also thought that 1 lb. of shredded chicken was not enough so I boiled a cut-up whole chicken in water with 3 stalks of celery, cut up carrots and an onion cut in half w/1 tablespoon of whole peppercorns.  Boiled it for about 2 hours or until the meat was falling off the bone.  Let it cool, discard veggies, shred.  Makes for a very hearty meal.

text:
I made this using the high setting for just under 4 hours and it was really delicious on a cold day.  I precooked 1lb. of thin sliced chicken breasts in a skillet and they shredded beautifully when cut/scraped on a diagonal.   While the directions didn't note to, I stirred the soup at least once per hour. I also tossed in shredded cheddar cheese and a tablespoon of sour cream to mix it up just before serving with the tortilla crisps and it was delicious.  It also reheats very well. This soup has quite a bite!

This is great soup and very easy.  I think the Enchilada sauce really gives it a nice flavor.  The only thing I would do different next time is to not mess with cutting up the corn tortillas and toasting them. The flavor in this soup is fantastic!! I was hoping for it to have the thickness of a stew rather than a thin soup. I did add the chicken frozen to the soup and shredded it once cooked through. Yum. Keeper in my book!

Display Name:
JENELLEBELLE
isPro:

12

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/45898.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
With modifications, this is definitely a 5-star recipe!  I made as directed, except I threw in 3 frozen boneless chicken breasts instead of the cooked chicken, added i can of drained rinsed (you do this to get the salt off them) black beans, 2T of lime juice, and omitted the bay leaf.  After a couple hours on high I checked on the chicken and it was just thawed and not cooked yet, so I pulled them out and cooked them in a pan on the stove, then shredded them and threw them back into the crock pot  for another hour.  The first day my fiance and I ate it it tasted delicious, but wasn't thick enough for my taste (I was looking for omething comparable to Max and Erma's :)).  The second day, I put the leftover soup back on the stove and whisked in about a cup of flour/water and cornstarch to thicken it.  We had it topped with Fritos and sour cream and it was AMAZING!!  Thanks for a delish recipe!

Very good soup.  Will definitely make again!

text:
Mine turned out thick enough and with plenty of kick. I used a fresh green chili pepper instead of canned.  I also added 3/4 cup of dried black beans at the start of cooking. As for spices, I added several dashes of ground red chilis, cumin, paprika, and chili powder. I also added two tsp of chili sauce (I love foods with a punch). I cooked it on low for 7 hours, then high for the last hour to make sure the beans were done through.

text:
This was absolutely wonderful!  My whole family enjoyed it, the kids included.  I followed all the directions except that I put uncooked chicken breasts in the slow-cooker.  I took them out towards the end of the cooking time to shred them, and then put back in.  I also cut my corn tortillas into thin strips and fried them in olive oil before serving.  I used cheddar cheese, chopped avocado, sliced olives, chopped cilantro, and lime wedges as toppings for the soup.  I will make this again and again!  It's healthy and makes for a very filling meal.
